review: An unremarkable film for a remarkable story. Nothing really impresses in this film, not the stilted acting, nor the unevenly toned screenplay. It's too bad--it's an important story to tell, but given a lifeless, awkward treatment.

It's a Spielberg film, crafted like a Disneyland ride to please the broadest cross section of viewers. All the tubes and wires are impeccably arranged and placed, the science intact, but the feeling? Where is the dandelion pushing through the concrete of Spielberg's relentless planning? Only the scene of the spy plane shot down invigorates. I have to see Munich as I have heard he shines therein.

Spielberg shows once again that, even with a strong material in his hands, he can't resist giving in to the usual lack of subtlety that has plagued his most recent works, and so this is a decent but heavy-handed film that is obvious even in its score and cinematography.

If you have been waiting for Spielberg to make yet another fantastic film, look no further. "Bridge of Spies" delivers an extremely powerful (albeit straightforward) story following James Donovan (Tom Hanks), an attorney sent to dispatch a plane to Russia to take photographs. After it is shot down in mid air, the survivor of the plane is then in negotiations to be traded for a supposed Russian Spy they have in custody. With a few more complexions, this film is the perfect amount of smart, witty, and serious. Written by the Coen Brother, Steven Spielberg was able to get quite a bit of comedy out of these actors, while they simultaneously deliver sharp dialogue. Terrific performances, brilliant direction, a story definitely Spielberg worthy, and beautiful cinematography work. If you are a fan of this genre, it is not one to miss. I loved every second of "Bridge of Spies" and I cannot recommend it more. Although, it is definitely not for everyone. It is a bit lengthy, but the pace was perfect in my opinion. After thinking long and hard about what could have been a flaw or issue with this picture, I simply could not think of anything. "Bridge of Spies" is what filmmaking is all about.

Bridge of Spies is a masterfully crafted Cold War drama from Steven Spielberg, one that perfectly blends thrills and a brilliant performance from Tom Hanks. The script is top notch and gives us characters we can cling to. Tom Hanks and Mark Rylance steal the show with their brilliant performances. I was fully captivated by their performances. Spielberg also continues his legacy of being one of the greatest directors of all time. His work is simply a gift to always behold.

Although it is a charm to watch given the Spielberg-Hanks reunion as well as a script which co-credits the Coen Brothers, BRIDGE OF SPIES proves to be an all-in-all solidly-made film that is entertaining and more or less satisfying, but unfortunately a piece that plays too safe to transcend. SPIES features some smart and masterful filmmaking - as evident in its strong visual storytelling, well-crafted one-on-one exchanges, and clever editing (some amazing match cuts as well as Spielberg and DP Kaminsky's usual soft, glowy lighting amidst beautiful end frames to precise camera moves) - in addition to a steady yet immersive performance by both Hanks and Rylance. However, the film lacks the much-desired impact upon its delivery of turning points; the narrative is fancied with surprisingly funny moments and pleasurable scenes but the plot becomes a bit too easy - the grip never holds on, the sense of danger never reaches its potential, and likewise the end result is not as powerful as it was building up to be (Hanks' character appears to negotiate his ways through obstruction that operates more on its bark than its bite; there is a Cold War level of fear that tags along as opposed to being imposed and infused - with a Spielberg staple, trademark sentimental music, that does little to help). In the end, taking into account the genre of Cold War spy drama/thrillers, Spielberg's latest is simply a solid entry that services quite well but falls short of greatness.

T. HANKS FOR THE MEMORIES - My Review of BRIDGE OF SPIES (4 1/2 Stars)Due to poor marketing, a generic poster and forgettable title, I initially had no interest in seeing BRIDGE OF SPIES. It reeked of sup-bar Tom Clancy with dime store espionage. Little did I know it was based on a remarkably true Cold War story about an ordinary lawyer who brokered a hostage deal with the Soviets and East Germans. Additionally, when I discovered the Coen Brothers did a polish on the script, my interest was piqued just a little. Now that I've seen it, I can say it's one of Steven Spielberg's greatest accomplishments, a quietly suspenseful, beautifully acted and shot, twisting, turning yarn with quirky, specific characters and acute relevancy to current international politics. Tom Hanks, in full Jimmy Stewart Everyman mode and knocking it out of the park, plays James B. Donovan, an insurance attorney who is quietly asked by the Feds to perfunctorily represent a Soviet spy they've captured. The film opens on said spy, Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance, giving an Oscar caliber performance) as he paints a self-portrait. It's a terrific opening shot, loaded with a wry sense of humor and multiple angles on the man to convey the layers to his character. There's no doubt from the outset that he is indeed a Russian spy, but it's the richness that follows which surprises. Soon, agents are pursuing him through the New York subway system in a bravura sequence of mounting tension, disorientation and stellar sound design. When Spielberg and his longtime collaborator, cinematographer Janusz Kaminski, become engaged with material as rich as this, it's a pleasure to watch. Once captured, Donovan is asked to give the appearance of caring just enough so that the American Justice System looks good, but not enough to prevent Abel from the electric chair. Donovan, however, has more compassion than they expected. What follows is a story which stresses the importance of maintaining who we are or would love to be as a country by how we treat our prisoners. It's so easy in times of terrorism to go the way of Guantanamo Bay and torture our captives, but perhaps more important to maintain our ideals of justice rather than surrender to barbarism. Ultimately, the story involves a more well-known hostage, Gary Powers (Austin Stowell), an American pilot commissioned by the CIA to spy on Russia. His capture provides another thrilling sequence, this one in mid-air. Without spoiling too much, Donovan travels to East Berlin to quietly swap hostages without any official U.S. backing. Complicating matters is the fact that another American is captures by the East Germans just as the Berlin Wall is being erected.It's in the passage that I saw something new, and clearly Spielberg is all in as we witness the wall going up brick by brick as desperate people attempt to escape the oncoming horrors of life in the other side of that border. It's stunning and told with such assuredness and clarity. Another unexpected bonus is the humor in this film. Matt Charman, along with the Coens, keeps each character grounded in reality and adds such wonderful touches as Abel's cousin joyfully coming to beg for his release, Donovan's nagging cold throughout, and Abel's fantastically dry response of "Would it help?" whenever Donovan asks him to present himself a certain way. The relationship between Donovan and Abel is the heart of this film, and both actors rise to the occasion. Abel is deceptively still and on-the-surface, an enigma. Rylance, however, brings such quiet heart to Abel, that it's easy to see this potentially dangerous spy as just a man serving his country. This is a no-brainer supporting actor Oscar nominee if there ever was one, and deservedly so. Amy Ryan as Donovan's wife is straddled with the "meanwhile back in the States scenes" but she meshes really well with Hanks, giving such a vivid portrait of a late 50s/early 60s housewife on the verge of asserting herself more and more. The film is not without its flaws. Clearly scenes were cut between Donovan's assistant and daughter, whose secret affair must have meant something to a story about sneaking around, but obvious not enough to matter. There's enough there to leave one hanging, perhaps because their scenes carry a lot of the early exposition of the story. Also, even Spielberg at his best can turn syrupy and obvious at the end of his films, and this is no exception. SCHINDLER'S LIST, which I consider a masterpiece, suffered from Liam Neeson's breakdown scene. Here, we get a way-too-obvious comparison between the lives of wall-hopping East Germans and free Americans. It's not enough to derail the exceptional film that precedes it, and Spielberg and Co. are wise enough to provide a crawl of what happened to each character over this scene....so the on-the-nose nature of it is slightly diffused...a minor step in this nostalgic, uplifting, classically told, perfectly written film.

Insane. Outstanding to the max. It's such a gripping thriller, yet the build up in the characters makes one marvel at the excellent film making skills of a Spielberg film, anchored on the acting brilliance of Tom Hanks. Bridge of Spies jumps to my top 5 list of best films of the year. I'm rooting for best film, best direction, best actor, best supporting actor. A must, must watch.

A feel-good movie about unsung heroes in the 50s espionage Cold War. Tom Hanks is magical once again and Mark Rylance is thoroughly and quietly charming. Unfortunately roles for women are quite thin as Amy Ryan shares five minutes of screen time with not much to do. Overall, however, Bridge of Spies is a great story that recognizes these men who may not have had a chance to have their story told. Spielberg has fashioned a comfortably old-fashioned yarn that one can snuggle up with a pot of tea on a cold evening. Rating: 84

An entertaining Bridge to the H'Wood studio days, this Spies game exemplifies Steven Spielberg at his treacly but satisfying best. The golden age of H'Wood are alive and well in the oeuvre of the maestro behind Jaws, E.T., and Jurassic Park, most noticeably in his latest brush with history, Bridge of Spies. Oh, this is not to say that his latest true story unintentionally comes across as old fashioned. Rather, the legendary director purposely exhibits an old-school approach to storytelling and workmanship that brings to mind the days of John Ford (The Grapes of Wrath, The Searchers), William Wyler (The Best Years of Our Lives, Ben-Hur), and - most of all - Frank Capra (Mr. Smith Goes to Washington. It's a Wonderful Life). There's his assured use of Steadicam sweeps and close-ups, as well as a celebrated leading man who radiates both trustworthiness and nationalism. Just look at the film's poster: the giant mug of American hero Hanks caught between the stars and stripes and hammer and sickle, grandstanding the values of life and liberty before the opening credits have even rolled. This process serves him well with a Cold War tale such as this but it also plays it a little too safe. As beautiful and striking as this sentimental film looks, it plays out too predictably, which takes some of the punch out of the more suspenseful moments.In this PG-13-rated thriller based on true events, an American lawyer (Hanks) gets recruited by the CIA during the Cold War to help rescue a pilot (Austin Stowell) detained in the Soviet Union. Calculatedly, the film feels like a family friendly product of the era that it represents, which is laudable on many fronts save for the multiple somewhat heavy-handed endings. For the auteur who chose to chronicle such a specific warts and all bent in the life of the 16th U.S. president with Lincoln, however, his Bridge of Spies ultimately comes across as lighter fare. With a reliably stalwart performance by Hanks, a knock-out turn by stage veteran Rylance as a captured Soviet spy, and quotable dialogue provided by the Coen Brothers, this throwback boasts enough winning moments of distinction that make it stand tall even in a familiar line-up. Bottom line: Spies Like U.S.

Steven Spielberg once again proves he can do no wrong, especially with real world material. Following the grand traditions of Amistad and Munich, Bridge of Spies is an incredibly fine, concise and versatile Cold War drama/thriller. With an impressively written script contributed oddly by the two and only Cohen Brothers, add to that under Spielberg's bold direction the film shines as one of his most finest films to date. Another big credit added towards the casting, with another impressive collaboration with Tom Hanks (making this their third collaboration), alongside the likes of other incredibly talented actors, particularly Mark Rylance (soon to be in Spielberg's BFG next year), and the gorgeously looking cinematography. The film itself, also tells it's story really well with minimal music by Thomas Newman, making this the third Spielberg film to be scored without John Williams. Overall, the film really challenges the rights of prisoners and country's laws and constitution in a time of great conflict where almost anything could happen. Lastly, it's a highly recommended film in which it's Oscar changes might be big.

Bridge of Spies is a Cold War thriller that is as subtle and understated as most of its characters. The narrative tells the little known backstory of Soviet KGB spy Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance) and his defense by American lawyer James B. Donovan (Tom Hanks) against the wishes of an unforgiving public mood. Later, we see Donovan in East Berlin successfully negotiating his exchange with captured U2 pilot Gary Powers and an American student imprisoned by the East German Stasi. Bridge has fairly average direction and Tom Hanks largely plays himself as is his habit, but then again that's the advantage of being a national treasure. Spielberg and Hanks can give in rather perfunctory work and it will stand out above many others simply by default. I'd argue that Mark Rylance is the true gem of the picture and his simple, quotable dialogue, weary but observant expressions, and stoic demeanor make him the most memorable element. That and it features a fairly strong script written by the Coen Brothers. In summation, Bridge of Spies fails to reinvent the genre but it didn't need to - it tells a story more Americans and Russians need to learn and it tells it well.

Another one of Spielberg's political morality plays . . . like "Lincoln" it's a mix of of old fashioned idealism and hard, real world truths. Some of his usual sentimentalism is on display but it's mostly kept in check by the screenplay (no doubt due to the Coen's involvement) and the tight pacing that never lingers too long on emotional moments. If this performance doesn't solidify Hanks as our generations Henry Fonda than I don't know what will.
A superb acquirement: a cinematic masterpiece that looks effortless, with great casting, writing and cinematography - it would make an excellent double bill with Argo.

Interesting narrative with a strong performance by Mark Rylance. Spielberg brings this Cold War saga to life but too often lacks for nuance and subtlety. Hanks was good but not great as the saintly lawyer. (10-24-15)

Steven Spielberg's engrossing period drama which is based on a true life incident, in 1957 the Soviet spy Rudolf Abel, impressively played by Mark Rylance was capture in New York City, his defense is assigned to American lawyer, James B. Donovan, played magnificently by Tom Hanks, he makes a selfless sacrifice out of his sense of patriotic duty, but then is recruited by CIA director Allen Dulles, well-played by Peter McRobbie to secretly negotiate and arranged a prisoner swap of Abel for U.S. pilot Francis Gary Powers who's U2 spy plane was shot down over the Soviet Union by there armed forces. Masterful direction by the great Spielberg, with extraordinary cinematography by Janusz Kaminski. great supporting performances by Alan Alda, Domenick Lombardozzi, Amy Ryan, John Rue, Billy Magussen, and Henny Russell, but its Hank's searing performance of great dignity and total conviction that steals this film completely. A taut thriller and fascination motion picture, one of the year's very best. Highly Recommended.

Bridge of Spies offers al we've come to expect from a Steve Spielberg picture. Good subtle direction, strong performances, great music and captivating costume and set designs. It also contains a screenplay that is a little too light-hearted and way too dramatic lighting effects. It's solid as solid can be, and Rylance will likely earn quite a few wins for best supporting Actor.
A solid film from start to finish.
Very light-weight, considering the issues depicted. Nevertheless, good acting, well filmed, entertaining.
Profound is the word. Not only is the subject pertinent to resurgence of the US-USSR rift, it is supremely delectable and uplifting story-telling. Spielberg and Tom Hanks, take a bow!

Though its classic American hero vibe and Spielberg's conventional directing style is evident, Bridge of Spies manage to pull it of due to poignant subtext about friendship and tenacious courage for doing the right thing.

Brilliant movie, with an excellent Tom Hanks -and quirkily fascinating Mark Rylance as the spy he tries to exchange. The story based on the life of an amazing lawyer, James B. Donovan (who later freed over a thousand of American prisoners in Cuba - after Bay of Pigs invasion) is nn important part of American history,, told as a thriller.
One of Spielberg's best and a welcome return to the screen for Hanks and the Berg!
Tom Hanks! *drops mic*

A well-made movie based on a true story that stays true to the facts, sometimes at the expense of needed drama. The acting is superb, Mark Rylance is a standout. At a time where most movies are all visual fluff with little to no substance, this one is worth seeing.

This movie makes me feel proud of my country for producing a great citizen like James Donovan the true hero of this movie. Hanks does a very credible job of portraying him. Sure there are some corny scenes at the end that are designed to get our tears flowing, but heck tears can be therapeutic too. Overall, I was very happy to have seen this movie.
A beautiful historical piece with fantastic performances by Tom Hanks and Mark Rylance.
Fantastic performances by all the cast. Well worth watching.

Fascinating as expected, with Tom Hanks really shining throughout the movie. An old-school thriller with contemporary acting, with a nostalic and unforgettable atmosphere from behind the Iron Curtain.
Exceptional storytelling.
It's got Hanks in it, it's gotta be good!
You can never go wrong with Spielberg/Hanks -team.

"Aren't you worried?" "Would it help?"Gripping, thrilling and enjoyable, Bridge of Spies is a brilliant old-school Cold War spy thriller which benefits from powerful direction, top-notch performances and a story of friendship, personal values and determination. With a fascinating story and an overall visual style that brings back the classical spy-thriller film-making of previous decades, the movie is a most welcome return to the genre roots while it remains incredibly up-to-date despite a topic which could be considered nowadays far from being modern. Based on the true story of James Donovan (Tom Hanks) and his memoirs, Bridge of Spies tells the most curious events surrounding the conviction of the Soviet spy Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance) and the following negotiations exchange which take place in East Berlin. It is not only a story of incredibly interesting events, but also a clash of values, of personal integrity and reflection of a period when values and constitutional rights were challenged. To the great delight of all viewers Steven Spielberg has returned with a flawless delivery that combines convincing cinematography, sober, but impactful visuals, amazingly convincing performances and of course a story that even though it is well know, still contains enough twists to keep you fully engaged. Without further spoiling what is all about, I would only say that Bridge of Spies has "Oscar Awards" written all over it. With 6 nominations, among which for Best Motion Picture, for Best Supporting Actor of Mark Rylance and Best Screenplay of the Ethan and Joel Cohen, this spy-thriller might not be a big winner (due to its earlier release date), but it could already be considered a contemporary classic ! A must see movie !
A brilliant Tom Hanks, great set up and great camera work. I liked the message of the whole story too. Its quite a while a go when i said "great cinema" the last time.
The movie did a very good job of creating the "cold war" fear and tension that permeated our society. Tom Hanks was his normal outstanding self. My wife and I both loved it.

The Coen Brothers, Spielberg, and Hanks Oh MY!! Beautifully shot and well-acted, and riveting feature that keeps you entertained from start to finish. It's weird hearing a Spielberg feauture without a John Williams score. Thomas Newman filled the role here as Williams was ill. In the end, despite a couple odd scenes that could have been edited out, Bridge of Spies is satisfying. You oddly care about the Soviet spy brilliantly played by Mark Rylance. Hanks is Hanks. When he finds the right role, he's spectacular. Nice small role from Alan Alda who is solid as always.

No other American director has made more movies audiences have billed as "just plain good" more often than Steven Spielberg, who, for his decades long career, has managed to warm our hearts, move our souls, make our eyes misty, thrill us, tease us, like a storyteller who can transport us into a different dimension with the snap of a finger. Like Hitchcock, simply hearing his name is enough to evoke a certain emotion, which, in most cases, is a feeling of home, of sentimentality, at least when putting such classics as "Jaws," "E.T.," "Raiders of the Lost Ark," and "Jurassic Park" into perspective.  But more recently has he begun to focus on more humanistic issues, covering and bringing to life (sometimes more vividly than we'd like) such issues as the Holocaust ("Schindler's List"), war ("Saving Private Ryan"), and even the Munich massacre ("Munich"). Clearly, Spielberg is one enamored with the idea of making a movie out of dramatic events of days past - some stories are meant to be told and heard on an international level, but deserve to be helmed in a way that provides them with the justice they so unmistakably warrant. Spielberg, time and time again, does a magnificent job of retelling real life events with theatric suppleness while still making a certain story more than just a story: a miraculous sense of importance is left intact. So I was surprised by "Bridge of Spies," which is well-made, well-acted, well-directed, and well-shot, but is ultimately more textbook interesting than it is cinematically engaging. With a lack of dramatic haul, it has the wow factor of a documentary but not the heart-thumping majesty of "Argo." Everything told is so inevitable, so unsurprising, that we are left notably impressed by the bravery of its central figure but never moved by the story. It's a tale of heroism without any twists and turns. As suggested earlier, "Bridge of Spies's" events would, perhaps, be more investing when captured within the walls of a documentary setting, where things are supposed to be predictable (though compelling) from the beginning. The film, set in 1957 at the height of the Cold War, stars Tom Hanks as James B. Donovan, a relatively small-time lawyer (he mostly specializes in insurance settlements) given the difficult task of defending Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance), a Soviet accused by the American government of being a KGB spy. Donovan isn't so convinced that this is necessarily the truth - everyone involved in the case is predisposed from the beginning - and so he fights to at least get the man out from under the umbrella of death row, which he successfully (though controversially) does. But the plot thickens when Francis Powers (Austin Stowell), a CIA pilot, is shot down by the Soviet Union mid-flight and is soon captured, and when Frederic Pryor (Will Rogers), an American student studying in Germany, is arrested for espionage by government officials after causing a tumult during the building of the Berlin Wall. In response, Donovan is proposed with the unthinkable - what if a trade is made, America giving Abel back to his home country, Powers back to the U.S.? It is an interesting proposition only to increase dramatically in its intensity after Pryor becomes part of the deal. Sent to negotiate with East German and USSR officials, Donovan overcomes his humble roots and does the extraordinary. At a time where most Oscar nominees seem to be relatively feral and imaginative (just look at "The Revenant" and "Mad Max: Fury Road"), "Bridge of Spies" seems conventional and safe, told with a traditional and old-fashioned flair that leaves it easy to look at and understand but sometimes insipid to watch due to its lack of any real suspense or stylistic risk. It is beautiful to gaze upon, though: the camerawork is glossy, reminiscent of Old Hollywood, and Spielberg conjures the iconic allure of a forgotten era. Hanks is a dependable leading man, trustworthy and strong, and Rylance is very good as the quirky Abel. But "Bridge of Spies" languishes from the fact that it never packs any punches - we wait for something jaw-dropping to occur to leave us emotionally stunted, but nothing ever does. We're affected by its story yet never dazzled by it; it sits there flatly as we wonder if it will ever become larger-than-life. A striking true story it is. I'm just not so sure big-budget, Hollywood treatment was necessarily the right place to go.

Aww Spielberg, you're officially too old to be cool. This is a nice film, sentimental and capably acted. It's also a film that should have been made in the 1960s. Here's what was missing...conflicts and tension! I felt no worry or care for any of the main characters. Not best picture worthy

Bridge of Spies is a great film. I'm always interested in films that are based on a historical event and I like getting the idea of what it was like during that time, which is how you're supposed to feel. Everyone delivered fantastic performances, but Mark Rylance was absolutely phenomenal. He made you feel for that character and what he was going through, which makes it even more effective when you realize that he's portraying a real person. The film is also wonderfully shot. Steven Spielberg really wants you to feel like you're in the scene, as he does with a lot of his other films. My overall enjoyment of the film was not what I wanted it to be. Negotiations that are portrayed in film does not interest me that much, and this film is all about that subject matter, though I acknowledge that it is done very well. There is also a lot of political dialogue that made it a little difficult to follow, at least for a first viewing. If you can get the plot of the film, you will follow it better. I expect that some people would be really bored by this film, which is understandable, it's not for everyone. Bridge of Spies is not one of my favorite Spielberg movies, or even one of my favorite movies of the year. But Spielberg's directing and the actors' performances made me enjoy it enough. It's one of those movies where I liked it, but I wouldn't really want to see it again.

While at first I was skeptical for this film's Best Picture nominee status, as I was under the impression it was just given to it because it was directed by Speilberg and written by the Coen brothers, it did eventually win me over by the end. Of course, first it had to get through a Cold War version of "To Kill a Mockingbird" before that, but once Tom Hanks' character got to Europe, things got interesting. Clearly, the direction and writing on this film is what gave it the nomination it deserved.

The first half of the movie covers familiar ground with the average guy attorney fighting for civil liberties for his client, a suspected Russian spy. The second half is the same attorney in East Berlin making a prisoner swap. Hanks is in his wheelhouse after a few missteps lately. The rest of the cast is also good. Otherwise it's a pretty standard Hollywood movie and probably too talky for the genre. There are a few memorable cinematic moments, but also some too obvious moments.
Spielberg delivers! Great mix of suspense, intrigue and (surprisingly) humor.

For this viewer, "Bridge of Spies" renews a tired and over-tread time period and subgenre. Post WWII/Early Cold War espionage is brought dazzlingly back to life as New York insurance attorney James Donovan (Tom Hanks) is elected by US Government officials to defend a captured Soviet spy, Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance). A gesture made more for illusion of justice in a time of fear and propaganda. A move that comes at a personal cost to Donovan and soon finds him drawn into larger events that pull him from the heated halls of American justice into the freezing streets of a Berlin embroiled in political strife at the inception of the Berlin Wall.Steven Spielberg recalls for us his ability to wring tension out of what might have passed quietly below our radars in less capable hands. Making momentous of the minuscule. Tom Hanks turns a performance that should surprise no one, with Mark Rylance filling in the gaps with disarming quirk and poignance. Matt Charman's scripting is as tight as a drum, likely due in part to the involvement of Joel and Ethan Coen working beside him. Regardless of palate, "Bridge of Spies" is not to be missed.

Driven by Tom Hanks and the beautiful cinematography from Steven Spielberg Bridge of Spies is great drama that successfully delivers on its intentions, however its pacing at times doesn't complement its running time to an extent. In the end, Steven Spielberg Cold War movie is good.

A solid script and safe acting make this period piece about Cold War spies an enjoyable movie, but nothing really special. After two solidly, slightly-above-average movies, "Bridge of Spies" and "The Martian," I'm a bit worried about what constitutes an Oscar-worthy Best Picture nomination.

I don't know why more people aren't talking about this film. As far as I can tell and in my estimation, it is in every respect a masterpiece. The direction is so subtle, mature and wise that only an elder'y Spielberg could have pulled it off. When I saw Joel & Ethan Coen's credit in the screenplay I was delighted but not ultimately surprised: their masterful touch is evident throughout the work. Tom Hanks is absolutely at the top of his game but he is also surrounded by an impeccable cast, not least of which is Mark Rylance, who exudes the integrity of his character from the first frame. The soundtrack is perfect, as is the cinematography, costumes, production design and pretty much everything else. I rarely write reviews for films I have seen, but when I do it's because I am impelled to do so. I do believe I loved every second of this remarkable film. Everyone involved in making it should be proud.

Basic values of human life(s) & the everlasting stagnation of war through "growing walls rather than people", are present traits of Spielberg. Tom Hanks continues to outperform, he deliver a very relatable James Donovan. He could have had more maturing, & it's not a film for the drama-hater, but there isn't that much more to criticize about. Well written dialogs are on the other side shockingly character fitting, & the metaphoric images throughout the film only strengthens Spielberg's position among today's filmmakers.Personal rating: 78/100Critical rating: 96/100

Steven Spielberg's 2015 effort, Bridge of Spies, displays the veteran director's best film in a decade. Written by Mark Charman and the Coen Brothers, the plot depicts the United States' frosty relationship with the prominent nations that (unofficially) participated in The Cold War and when spies from both opposing countries are caught, we see efforts to go about the diplomatic way to solve things. Part drama, part thriller-the script has the perfect tone to be light-hearted enough when it needs to, while also packing a very humane level of drama. The skill on display from a technical standpoint is one of the films many strong suits-be it the cinematography from Janusz Kaminski or the production design from Adam Stockhausen-that will have the film stick with you like a spy following a target. In a story featuring spies and courtroom bias, Spielberg alum Tom Hanks (on their fourth collaboration) evokes the good-natured enthusiasm the filmmaker is known for. Spielberg-famous (or infamous)-for being able to make even the darkest subject matter have an optimistic outlook directs the film with the perfect balance of intrigue, gravitas and entertainment, crafting a very acquainted, yet fulfilling film experience

Spy thrillers. You're either going to dig them, or you aren't. They can be stuffy, they're usually long, often set in the 50's and often revel in themselves speaking above the viewer's head. I had to watch Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy three times before I felt I had a grasp at what exactly was going on in that beast. Trying your damnedest just to keep up with the plot can suck some of the enjoyment out of watching the thing in the first place. Bridge of Spies doesn't speak in as many riddles as TTSS, but it is a spy flick set, when else, at the height of the cold war. Tom Hanks plays Tom Hanks essentially, it doesn't matter what his character's name is, and this time around he is an upstanding insurance lawyer. You know, the type that would do whatever it takes to ensure a high moral parameter is set. And as unrealistic as his character can seem, he does happen to be based on a real person. In Tom Hanks' capable hands though, he just becomes Tom Hanks. In this movie Tom Hanks is tasked with providing a reliable defence to a man suspected of being a Russian spy, on trial for his life. Hanks does a good job, too good for some, and when one of America's own spies is caught and held, Hanks is appointed to facilitate the exchange of bodies. That's about it. There isn't a great deal of suspense in the movie until the actual exchange is to take place and at over two hours, it takes its sweet time getting anywhere in the plot. But despite occasionally dragging and suffering an overabundance of dry talky talk, the film kept my interest well enough. Of course, there aren't two more reliable men making movies these days than Tom Hanks and Steven Spielberg. With Hanks in front and Spiel behind the camera, at the very least you know you will be getting something that's well made and well acted. And it is that. It looks very pretty, thank in no small part to the lighting capabilities of frequent Spielberg collaborator Janusz Kaminski. And while Hanks' performance is reliably good, it's also, on the downside, overly reliable. There isn't much adventure in it. You don't sense that things could go sideways at any moment or doubt a proper outcome because Hanks is at the helm and even when he isn't playing it safe, he's still Hanks and that's safe enough. Actually, the standout performance in this film for me was Mark Rylance (who?) playing the Soviet spy. I found myself wanting to see more of him and less of Hanks as the movie wore on. So, Bridge of Spies is a spy flick. It's very well made, very well acted. It's based on a true story, one I don't know much about so I can't comment on how close to the page Spielberg stuck, but he can't have run too wild with it as the story itself is really rather simple, predictably so at times. I don't doubt it will win a bevy of awards season nominations when the ballots are cast, but outside of Rylance and Kaminski, I don't think it deserves to win any of them. At the end of the day, I'd say Bridge is closer to a War Horse, or Lincoln Spielberg, rather than a Munich, Saving Private Ryan or even Empire of the Sun Spielberg. Which doesn't equal someone crapping in your Cheerios by any means. But it doesn't equal someone crapping gold in your Cheerios either.

Oh how I wish Mark Rylance had taken more to screen acting earlier in his career. With this film we have Spielberg performing at his usual reliable level (excluding the baggy last 10 minutes, which is arguably Spielberg at his lowest). Tom Hanks and his famed 'everyman' quality also make an appearance, this film serving as just another reminder that he is quickly approaching Jimmy Stewart levels of relatability. The screenplay by Matt Charman is quite straightforward in its narrative structure, but in terms of story does get deliberately tricky at times (but always understandable) as Donovan's (Hanks) enemies try to befuddle him.The true star of the show is of course, Mark Rylance, who gives a performance that is laced with dry wit and irony, which only at the end does he break and let us know is all for show. His performance is one that speaks volumes by doing very little, but it is not understated, as it outshines Hanks' performance often.The only real problem I have with this film is that once the actual story ends and everything stops moving forward (which it does with a decent pace throughout) there are a sequence of scenes at the end that seem to be Spielberg letting his sentimental side shine through too much, evidenced by my whole cinema laughing at the obviousness of it all when Donovan sees children jumping fences and has flashbacks to people being killed at the Berlin Wall. Oh, and not to mention the fact that Amy Ryan has been gven a thankless role as a housewife who's only real job is to encourage the main character. Can we not do that anymore, please?

'Bridge of Spies'.. A Drama/Spy Thriller Biopic.. Directed by Steven Spielberg.. Written by the Coen Brothers.. Starring Tom Hanks.. Seriously, this film deserves WAY more love and attention than it got. This film told the story of James Donovan, a lawyer who defended a captured Soviet spy and was then thrown into the middle of the Cold War where he was responsible for organising an exchange: a captured US pilot for a Soviet spy. This was an incredible movie all across the board, Spielberg as usual has done a fantastic job at directing this film and Tom Hanks puts in one of the performances of his career (It seems as though everything he does is 'one of the performances of his career') as they tell this story in the most captivating way possible. One thing you must know about this film and the thing i loved the most about it is that this is, from start to finish, is a dialogue driven film with fantastic visuals to make you feel like you are in East Berlin. You don't get any high stakes action scenes, and no fast paced violent depictions of the Cold War, this is a very focused story about one man and his mission to organise a trade between two opposing governments. And at first it may seem rather boring, you may ask; How are they going to fill 2 hours and 20 minutes with conversations and discussions about a trade for two men in a 'Spy Thriller'? Well by utilising amazing and incredible dialogue, they manage to capture your attention at every moment and you are fully engaged the whole time so that the film goes by really quickly. I cannot express enough, how amazing the dialogue is to be able to carry the film all the way through without needing any big exciting events. The dialogue is so smart that you start picking up on the little hints that tie in to things said an hour prior and start noticing moments of foreshadowing and it only goes to show the amount of attention and thought from the Coen Brothers that went into crafting the dialogue in the film. There are a few scenes in the film where Spielberg creates the feeling of tension extremely well without using any dialogue or little music, just visuals. These relatively quiet moments were so powerful and managed to get the message across without any exposition, that it is another testament to Spielberg's incredibly diverse directing abilities. Tom Hanks was just absolutely amazing in this film as James Donovan. This film showed why he remains as one of my favourite actors of all time. Especially in these dramatic roles, the way he embodies the character and their traits and personality, you never feel like he is just playing the same character over and over. The dialogue alone isn't enough to captivate an audience, you need a top tier actor to put in a stellar performance and make it all seem believable, imagine Adam Sandler delivering the same lines, it simply would not work, and would just turn into a shitty comedy. Tom Hanks it seems can be anyone, need a Captain Phillips? Walt Disney? James Donovan? Hanks is your go-to guy. If i was to pick out anything i think could have been done better i would be nit-picking because it is a variation of minor stuff. But there is a brief moment around a third of the way into the film where there is a shift in the overall focus of the film and i thought it happened a little too quick and would liked to have seen it drawn out a little, but seriously, just a fairly minor thing. So in the end, this is a film you should definitely check out, a Dramatic, Suspenseful Spy Thriller that takes out the big action set-pieces and replaces them with interesting and captivating dialogue delivered by Tom Hanks to perfection. - 8.2/10

The film's imagined 1950s is a conservative's wet dream. In the US, Stepford wives fawn over their hero husbands, and no black people cross the screen. In the Soviet bloc, state officials and soldiers are callous or duplicitous; torture is wantonly practiced; and all colors appear to have been expropriated from the screen, leaving the Soviets portrayed only in shades of grey.Shades of grey are likewise absent in the politics of Bridge of Spies. It is liberal agitprop, reenacting the pivotal manoeuvre of Cold War liberalism: train the spotlight on one's staunch and self-righteous support for liberal values while accommodating conservative forces and conjuring up humanitarian reasons for expanding Washington's imperial clout.

Bridge of Spies tells the story of James Donovan a New York attorney who gets caught in a game of Spies. American public in late 50s and 60s were increasingly getting obsessed with 'Godless Communists', the Soviet spies who were planning to nuke big American cities and so on. During this age of paranoia an actual spy was caught. To ensure him 'due process' an insurance lawyer was chosen as the defense attorney. As an attorney Jim Donovan does his job quite well and ensures that the spy actually gets a valid defense but at a great personal cost. Later he gets involved in the unofficial negotiations for the exchange of spies and the innocents between the Americans, Russians and DRG (East Germany) and culminates with Mr. Donovan saving the day.

I really wanted to like this more but somehow I was left with an empty stomach. That's not to say the banquet before my eyes didn't look delicious ... I just wasn't able to dig in the way I wanted to.(Food analogies, I must be hungry). 'Bridge of Spies' finds Spielberg at his most classical. The man is a master at his craft and there isn't a frame that seems out of place - but the whole thing feels too polished, too controled. Too positively American.What's on offer is a lot of shady conversations in stylishly lit rooms between impeccably dressed men. And while that may be truthful to the spy-game in reality - vague legal banter doesn't exactly make for exhilerating viewing.Spielberg manages to sneak in tiny sparks of tension throughout (without them really catching on fire) and Hanks delivers solid work as could be expected. It's just more of a sizzle than a bang.But to be fair, a screenplay like this (however well written) would've been disastrous in lesser hands.

As is the case with any period piece, if it historically accurate, then there's not much to tel. If it is not historically accurate, well, then it's not historically accurate. Here is a film that promises much, but for me, is a little thin on the delivery. I found this movie to be disappointingly formulaic and very predictable. Surprisingly funny and light for what appears to be, at first glance, a heavy political drama. This cold war-era thriller succeeds on all marks. Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks, in their 4th collaboration, prove themselves to be a productive team in terms of cinematic quality. The sharp script, cast, and directing are all commendable. But what really hit it out of the ball park, was Mark Rylance, who plays the spy with astonishing realism, as Rudolf Abel. It strikes me perhaps the most, and I can't stress enough how well Spielberg pulls this off, is that we feel a touch of sympathy for the "traitor". Bridge of Spies succeeds on many layers. The actors all did a fantastic job, Tom Hanks and Marc Rylance had incredible chemistry. The script is sharp, the dialogues are witty and the visuals are of high quality. The movie is filled to the brim with intensity and emotion. Whilst the film had spectacular sequences, it never forgot its place in remaining as realistic and character driven as possible, something that has been missing in Spielberg's recent films. Although the Music Department did a good job I particularly miss John Williams here.Despite the rather shady title, this is not the flamboyant gunslinger action ala James Bond or the intense operation like Argo. It is, strangely and also effectively, a light foray into the otherwise dark world of espionage. The pace is utterly calm and I absolutely loved that! Capturing the weight and gloom of an era, Bridge of Spies is equally a biopic and an unexpected light drama. Rather than using typical war buildup, the movie gives faces to each party, thus humanizing them in incredibly identifiable way. There's a lingering intensity, especially concerning the world of secrecy, yet it's a fascinatingly accessible story with subtle refined humor. This is meant to inspire instead of evaluation of ideologies, showcasing that humanity still resides beyond the other side of border or wall. This is Spielberg's best move in quite a long time. He didn't do anything bad, I like most of his movies, but Bridge of Spies is the first in a long time to remind me what I love about him and what a passionate artist he is: his fine instinct for transporting emotions through the screen to the audience.Anyway, the unexpected result is a reason why this film scores on every level. I highly recommend everyone to see it.

What is the common element of all Steven Spielberg's films? Whether it's ET calling home or a lawyer negotiating with Russians during the cold war, the story is presented in an absolutely epic way, like depeche mode use increased decibels to power up their music.The first part of the movie is a courtroom drama featuring the story of a professional lawyer with some strong personal ethics defending the "evil" Russian spy and it reminded me of "Philadephia" (also starring Tom Hanks). ?he second (and longest) part of the film is the espionage/film-noir one, featuring the negotiations of the lawyer with East Germany and Russia to the exchange of the Russian spy with Americans. The story is largely based on true events but of course there is always room for some subtle American propaganda and epic dramaturgy, Spielberg's specialty. Tom Hanks plays his role with great maturity and efficiency and the story is compact, despite the long duration of the film (141 mins). I guess the point of the film is that ethics and common sense are rare qualities that can really change the world. Still, the fact that the film is after all a strongly presented biography doesn't allow it to be a really classic film-noir film. Nevertheless it's worth watching.

Spielberg has managed to craft a film that feels like it's come straight out of the "Golden Era" of American filmmaking where not a minute of screen time is wasted and where images show you all you need to know thanks to clever editing combined with bold cinematography. It's bound to be nominated come awards season so give it a watch if you have the chance!

-Bridge of Spies is een 2015 Amerikaans historisch drama-thriller film geregisseerd door Steven Spielberg uit een screenplay geschreven door Matt Charman en Ethan Coen en Joel Coen. De film sterren Tom Hanks, Mark Rylance, Amy Ryan, en Alan Alda. Op basis van de 1960 U-2 incident tijdens de koude oorlog, de film vertelt het verhaal van advocaat James B. Donovan die is belast met de onderhandelingen over de vrijlating van Francis Gary Powers-een piloot waarvan de U-2 spionage vliegtuig werd neergeschoten boven de Sovjet-Unie in ruil voor Rudolf Abel, een gevangene Sovjet KGB spion vastgehouden onder de voogdij van de Verenigde Staten.-Bridge of Spies werd geschoten onder de werktitel van St. James Place. Principiele fotographie begon op 8 september 2014 in Brooklyn, New York City en tot produktie overgegaan in de Babelsberg Studios in Potsdam. De film werd uitgebracht door Touchstone Pictures op 16 oktober 2015 in Noord-Amerika en gedistribueerd door 20th Century Fox in andere gebieden. De naam van de film verwijst naar de Glienicke Bridge waarmee Potsdam, het vroegere Oost-Duitsland, verbonden werd met het westen van Berlijn, tot 1990 de enclave West-berlijn.--Kritische ontvangst:  -Bridge of Spies heeft lovende kritieken ontvangen, met name lof voor Hanks' en Rylance's prestaties, evenals Spielberg's richting. Op Rotten Tomatoes, de film heeft een score van 92%, gebaseerd op 225 reviews, met een gemiddelde score van 7.8/10 -. De site's kritische consensus luidt: "Brug van spionnen zoekt nieuwe leven in Hollywood's klassieke Koude Oorlog spionagethriller formule, dankzij betrouwbaar uitmuntend werk van Steven Spielberg en Tom Hanks." Op Metacritic, heeft de film een score van 81 uit 100, gebaseerd op 48 critici, met vermelding "succes". Op CinemaScore, publiek heeft de film een gemiddelde cijfer van "A" op een A+ tot F-schaal.-Een positieve recensie kwam van Steve Pulaski van Influx Magazine, gaf de film een B en verklaarde dat de meer meditatieve structuur van de film "vermengd met enkele subtiele periode cinematografie en een sterke Hanks performance (is) een fascinerende volwassen drama dat, hoewel niet zo gelaagd als het zou kunnen, is een verrijkende ervaring." De A.V. Club's Ignatiy Vishnevetsky beschreef het als "��n van de mooiste films van Spielberg's laatste dagen fase, en misschien wel de meest welluidende...Bridge of Spies verandert een geheime gevangene uitwisseling tussen de CIA en de KGB in een gespannen en vaak ontwapenend grappig kat-en-muisspelletje," besluitend: "Een ode aan vasthoudendheid aan morele principes, geopolitiek wees vervloekt, een uitbarsting van ouderwetse big-screen verhaal vertelling."

1957, it's the height of the Cold War and anyone could be a spy, especially if you're Senator McCarthy.There was good reason for Red Paranoia - there genuinely were spies lurking in the depths of idealised America. Bridge of Spies is based on the true story of lawyer James Donovan (Tom Hanks) and how he, firstly, defended Soviet spy Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance) and then exchanged him for CIA recon pilot Gary Powers (Austin Stowell). Rave reviews have followed since the release of Bridge of Spies. If you want to know why then look no further than the acting. Tom Hanks does what Tom Hanks does best. But Hanks's acting is standard compared to Mark Rylance's Abel, who is the true star of the show. Praise to the Coen Brothers (the scriptwriters of the film) for making a Soviet spy one of the heroes of an American film - that's a massive cultural step forward. The rest of the cast are on point, though I will scrutinise Scott Shephard, who plays spy 'Hoffman'. He exaggerates his character when there's no need - he's playing a spy. Spies are meant to be inconspicuous individuals that DON'T GET TANTRUMS IN THE MIDDLE OF GODDAMN BERLIN DURING THE COLD WAR. Realism can go a long way sometimes. Spielberg has created a film with little to no flaws - it's a technical masterpiece that tells a story well. However, you get the feeling this is very 'run of the mill' Spielberg: basic metaphors flushed out by acting talent. You get the sense the Cold War isn't taken seriously - the scenes that intentionally contrast Soviet territory and America are a little clich�d. It's a very 'Hollywood' film in that regard. Anyone and everyone will enjoy the film, but just expect to see it doing the rounds on TV during Easter or Christmas in five years. There are certain combination of film makers & actors that make you confident, before watching a film, that you are not going to be disappointed. With Steven Spielberg directing; Tom Hanks taking the lead (worked together on Saving Private Ryan, The Terminal, Catch Me If You Can) & written by the Coen Brothers (Fargo, Burn After Reading, No Country for Old Men), such a combination was without doubt destined to succeed. And guess what? They do, marvelously! By presenting an absolutely riveting and edge-of-your seat Cold War story. While there are no car chases and no gun-fire exchanges, the story is as compelling and suspenseful as any by Spielberg and the Cohen brothers. They are masters of the well-paced scene in which we the audience are never sure how the events will resolve. Even during the final climactic event of the film, which is largely understated, not much actually happens, but our anticipation of what might and might not occur keeps us glued to every gesture and expression & remains utterly captivating. Working from a screenplay by Matt Charman, rewritten by Joel and Ethan Cohen, Spielberg makes largely minor departures from the actual occurrences as they unfolded and recreates history with atmospheric spontaneity. While it may seem anachronistic to make a film about the Cold War, the points made in Steven Spielberg's film are just as relevant today. Like Spielberg's Lincoln, it is a film about values, about standing up for what you know to be right instead of succumbing to your fears, not an examination of the rights and wrongs of international intrigue or the merits or demerits of the Cold War. The Cold War is of course the perfect time period for any political thriller story (a real one at that). There are moments of manipulations, lies, and deceit. Yet through all that a trust has to be built to have any movement in the talks. How the characters try to build that relation for mutual benefit is what intrigued me the most. The story follows Brooklyn insurance claims attorney James Donovan (Tom Hanks), who is selected by the New York Bar Association wants him to serve as a defense attorney to Soviet spy Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance) so nobody can impugn the American justice. Abel had maintained a low-profile as one of the top Soviet spies in America. Masquerading as an artist, he collected sensitive information without calling attention to himself. The Soviets relied on what are known as dead letter mail boxes. Information could be stashed and retrieved, without it being apparent to most people, in innocuous places. Even Donovan's wife, Mary (Amy Ryan), nor his children share his principles of going about by the book & representing the 'Most Hated Man' of America. Even though everyone is convinced Abel is going to receive the death penalty, Donovan convinces Judge Byers (Dakin Matthews) to display some compassion and sentence the Soviet to prison rather than the electric chair. Byers heeds Donovan's advice despite frenzied public opinion after he delivers his verdict. In the meantime, the CIA recruits U.S.A.F. pilot Francis Gary Powers (Austin Stowell) to fly a high altitude jet to conduct aerial reconnaissance over the U.S.S.R. A Soviet SA-2 surface-to-air missile cripples Power's plane. He bails out, but fails to obliterate his U2 plane. Of course, the Soviet capture Powers, convict him as a spy, and sentence him to prison. Not long afterward, Donovan receives a letter from the Soviets and finds himself flying to Berlin as a private citizen to negotiate a prisoner exchange: Abel for Powers. Donovan gets the royal runaround between the Soviets as well as the East Berlin authorities. Nonetheless, he proves himself to be a shrewd man with a bargain, and he pits the Soviets against East Berlin. Ultimately, he never gives ground during these complicated negotiations. The catch is he must negotiate between the superpowers as a private individual rather than an official American envoy. However, as events play out, the two men's destinies will become intertwined. Eventually, Donovan travels to Berlin where he'll see first-hand the creation of the infamous Berlin Wall. While the first half is a legal drama, the second half is a political thriller & director Spielberg does an exceptional job of condensing and cross-cutting these events with utmost consistency. The film also looks authentic with its multiple locations in American and Europe. Steven Spielberg is the type of director you never know what you're going to get and I'm talking about the type of film making he uses. Steven Spielberg's direction here is absolutely superb, because every scene is so perfectly crafted and Spielberg knows when to cut to a emotional reaction with the characters. The Coen brothers, I think brought a sense of realism to things, but also a certain style; the way characters talk at times there's a lot of things where people try to figure the other person out, which is fascinating to watch. When Donovan arrives at the first part of the mission he's given in the second part of the film, to do this exchange of the Russian for an American pilot caught by the enemy, he goes to the Russians and doesn't talk to the lawyer (who he thought to talk to) but some other official. Spielberg covers this expertly, going in on Hanks and other actors at just the right moments to emphasize things getting tenser - another young American, a student caught up in the mix of things (it IS East Berlin, after all) - but the script dictates a lot of the momentum here. And at the same time the Coens aren't necessarily making it 'Coens-y', in a manner of speaking; they serve their filmmaker extremely well, giving a light air to a good number of scenes in a way that keeps the tension and suspense in a good balance. In terms of the performances, everybody was flawless. Tom Hanks is one of the most lovable and respected actors of are times, as in every role he dose, he never disappoints. This is he's fourth collaboration with Spielberg & Hanks once again deliverers a magnificent and believable performance. This is an Oscar worthy performance as he made his character so relatable, funny and very likable. The character Donovan is unwavering when it comes to his duty as a lawyer, even when he has to defend an enemy of his country. He believes in the importance of unbiased justice, so strongly that at first it may come off as naive. However, there are understated moments where we can see clearly his resolve being tested to the limits. Mark Rylance as the Soviet spy, is a man of few words but with that limitation he is able to convey so much about the character. He is defeated and fearful for his life, but when Donovan shows that there is still hope he will crack a joke. The key here is subtlety, that brings the power into the more dramatic moments without it feeling forced. I didn't feel like I was watching actors, I felt like I was watching real people. Amy Ryan & Austin Stowell play their parts well. On the whole, 'Bridge of Spies' is a well crafted espionage drama with excellent performances, fantastic direction and great writing. Bridge of Spies is the best Cold War thriller I've ever seen & is one of the best films of the year!
Excellent film. All concerned at their very best ????
It's not as intriguing as it wants to be but Bridge of Spies is still a well made and, thanks to Tom Hanks, very well acted biopic.
Spielberg + Coen Brothers + Tom Hanks = Cinematic Gold
Cold War time capsule. Good flick

With Steven Spielberg returning to both historical storytelling and collaborating with Tom Hanks, Bridge of Spies sounded like an intense collaboration of strong acting and directing.The Cold War espionage thriller is a genre which has not been in its heyday for decades so the timeliness in Bridge of Spies is not precisely as relevant. As a result, it makes it easier to pick up on the less entertaining elements of the film There is no denying that the dialogue is very intelligent, but there is just so much talking that the film can drag on. The thing about Bridge of Spies is that when you consider everything closely, not all that much happens in the story. The relevance lies not so much in what has happened but rather in the political and historical context that it occured in as well as how the characters decide to deal with the situations in such a context. As a result, those who cannot find themselves embalmed in the screenplay and acting are more likely to find themselves bored than others. For me, I could see both sides of the spectrum because the story develops based on a lot of little things that happen with the characters which is conveyed almost entirely through the dialogue of the film, yet at the same time the language in the screenplay was certainly well-crafted. There is a balance between focus on the events consistently moving forward and elements of the character's individual perspectives on what is happening ensuring that the film is faithful to both the real historical events and the people involved in it all. There are minimal subplots in Bridge of Spies. Though the characters all have their own personal lives, they are used simply to contribute to characterization as supporting blocks to the more major themes of the story. In that sense, Bridge of Spies keeps clearly focused on its goal of getting its characters to safety without messing around all the time. In all essence, Bridge of Spies serves as a well-written collaboration between the legendary Coen Brothers and Steven Spielberg.Even though the film is very much driven by script, this does not interfere with Steven Spielberg's ambition to ensure that Bridge of Spies is still a spectacle of some kind. There are some scenes which boast top notch production values such as the sequence in which Francis Gary Powers is shot down over the Soviet Union, but the majority of the film boasts a visual style in other ways. For one thing, the film easily conveys an effective production design which is able to grasp the historical context of the story with stylish appeal thanks to the appearances of the characters' costumes and their vehicles. But as well as that, I found myself intrigued by the fact that even though there was very much a lot of monochromatic colour in the visual field it never felt dull. There was a wide variety of monochrome so that the film was both colourful enough to be visually creative yet dank enough to be realistic and grim, reflecting the general mood of the film. The cinematography also works to ensure that there is strong imagery captured in everything, carefully working to emphasize the facial expressions of the actors to convey their state of mind or capturing the violent events happening at the Berlin wall. Whether the scenes are small or large in scale, there is always a beautiful sense of imagery in Bridge of Spies and you could expect no less from Steven Spielberg.Like I said, Bridge of Spies is a very talkative film and so it requires a truly talented actor to carry it as the lead. Predictably, with someone as skilled as Tom Hanks in the lead role there are no complaints to be made. Tom Hanks has proven many times to work brilliantly with Steven Spielberg, and Bridge of Spies is of course no exception. Tom Hanks takes on the role of James B. Donovan, a lawyer determined to do right for the world in every way. Neglecting social pressures, James B. Donovan follows his own conscience as a human being and Tom Hanks is able to convey this easily. His sophistication carries him through all the material with intelligent understanding of the material while his charms allow viewers to see into the human side of him. He grasps the determined edge of James B. Donovan with dedication, fearlessly wading through the material with a strong sense of consistent development and grasp over his emotions. Tom Hanks never drops out of the role and keeps focused during every conversation, never losing sight of what he is talking about or failing to keep audiences engaged through his charismatic interpretation of the language, so he ultimately reminds us that his dramatic flair has not decreased one iota in his years of acting.Yet it is Mark Rylance who truly deserves critical praise for his acting more than anyone. As a convicted Soviet Spy, Rudolf Abel should be seen as the villain of the story. Yet there is nothing antagonistic about him. From the first moment, he conveys a sense of human frailty which makes him easily sympathetic, yet contrasts it with a strong spirit not to succumb to the pressures of the US. He is vulnerable, but he is a man who cannot be broken which makes him both sympathetic and admirable. Mark Rylance's restrained line delivery allows him to have an impeccable chemistry with Tom Hanks in which the two are able to strip away their personas and simply converse as human beings, giving an impressive sense of feeling to the film. As the story progresses, we see more of Mark Rylance's vulnerabilities as he becomes more emotional bit by bit. It gets to the point where Rudolf Abel is no longer a spy but simply a human being, and the film depicts how the people of the US were so quick to forget that in times of Cold War paranoia. Rudolf Abel becomes the most human part of Bridge of Spies which is unexpected considering its subject matter, so Mark Rylance's performance is clearly one of the greatest assets to the film.Amy Ryan is a friendly presence, and it's nice to see Alan Alda return to dramatic form.So Bridge of Spies relies on a dated genre and is packed full of more talking than anything, but with Steven Spielberg's eye for imagery, an intelligent screenplay and brilliant performances from Tom Hanks and Mark Rylance.

One of the best films of 2015, Bridge of Spies has all of the Spielberg staples in their best incarnations so far: One-takes, saccharine melodrama, an eye for historical detail, incredible frame depth and rich worldbuilding. It also has a masterful, engaging script that crafts tense moments and complex, believable characters even in the ethereal affectations of Spielbergian worldbuilding. Most importantly it has a great cast, helmed by a Tom Hanks at peak form, an unbelievable scene-stealing, career-(re-)launching performance by Mark Rylance, who I'm ashamed to say I had never heard of before and with a large array of wholly believable, impeccably cast 'those guys' playing off Hanks' everyman with skill. The story, co written by the Coens, creates a dispassionate image of America during some of its darkest times and wrings out patriotism and nobility from Hanks' Insurance Lawyer while giving us an even-handed account of espionage games from an outsider's perspective without any of the us/them excesses, both story and action-wise that makes every aspiring writer giddy at the very mention of spies.It is safe to say that Bridge of Spies would have been my favourite spy-movie in a world devoid of Tomas Alfredsson's masterful's Tinker, Tailor which is perfect in every way and one of my favourite movies of all time. It is still one of the very best spy movies I've seen and one of the best movies to come out this year. Also, possibly my favourite Tom Hanks performance.Highly Recommended.

Tom Hanks delivers a masterful performance in this Cold War thriller directed by Steven Spielberg.Hanks plays James Donovan an insurance lawyer assigned the duty of defending Rudolf Abel, a man charged with being a Russian spy, played wonderfully by British stage actor Mark Rylance. Mark Rylance's portrayal manages to be both evoke sympathy and likability as well as being able to steal every scene that he's in and when you're in the same room as Tom Hanks that's hard to do. Rylance makes his character seem like he's not got a care in the world even though he could face the death penalty for his crimes and is brilliant when Tom Hanks repeatedly ponders why Able does not look worried and all he replies with is, "would it help?"However the film is not a straight forward court case and Hanks is soon drawn into a cat and mouse game with both the Russian and East German officials over the release of a captive American pilot and a student accused of being a communist. What follows isn't high on action but the dialogue manages to ramp up the tension and you'll be on tenterhooks right up until the end.

Bridge of Spies. Steven Spielberg's new Cold War Thriller follows the story of James Donovan, a Lawyer responsible for the transfer between Rudolph Abel, an alleged USSR spy, and an American pilot. The cast includes Tom Hanks and Mark Rylance as our protagonists, and a host of supporting characters.It is abundantly clear that this is an Oscar film. It doesn't attempt to hide this in any way, the actors, script, directing, cinematography, styling and music are all clearly designed to win awards. I don't have a problem with this, as long as the film is good.The performances in the film are pretty good, honestly not terribly exceptional however. Hanks, who looks way more like Hooch than Turner nowadays, is fittingly witty and sturdy. His character is immediately likeable, reflecting our modern attitudes towards the legal system and social morality. Hanks brings a warmth to the role, and his confident and strong presence goes along way when the audience need to sympathise during his hardships. The golden rule, however, is that only he could play this character, and I think others could. As Long as that actor has the same warmth that benefits from a beloved actor like Hanks. The rest of the cast again is good, but not great. Donovan's wife and children, fairly standard, the CIA and KGB Agents all standard (yet not stereotyped, which I respect) and the American military all square jawed heroes.The one exception is Mark Rylance. as supporting actors go this performance is certainly Oscar worthy. The Rudolph Abel character never actually reveals he is a spy to Donovan, and I suspect there was supposed to be an element of mystery as to his innocence, however we do quite clearly see him taking part in espionage activities, and the soviets do actively seek to get him back. Unless not even the soviets new who their spies were? This was lost on me personally. Rylance is a shorter man, not elderly but older and as far as imagery goes he is the whole package; frail, physically weak. But it is in the characters emotional and mental strength that he absolutely shines, and I couldn't replace Rylance personally.As for the direction, it can't be faulted. Working from a brilliant and meaningful script (Kudos to Matt Charman and the Coen's) every scene is shot beautifully, and Spielberg uses colour, weather, imagery and characters in perfect harmony. The framing is very close for the most part, keeping us in Donovan's vicinity. Smooth pans and zooms are used constantly, to the extent that by the last few scenes I had started to count them. It does add drama and the movement gives a progressive feel to Donovan's endeavour, but this is Oscar styling at its most annoying, despite the obvious quality poured into it.The film is essentially a series of negotiations, from Abel's Trial to the final transfer on the, all together now, bridge of spies. Again the use of location and distancing perfectly matches the delivery of the actors and I don't think I could fault a single scene, the tension mounts to the climax in each scene very naturally, and it is always apparent who is in control, even behind the smoke and mirrors.This is where my first gripe is. The plot doesn't even try to not be obvious, we know exactly how the whole scenario will play out. There's no mystery. No red herrings. As the credits rolled I found that I'd seen exactly what id expected. This sucked to be honest. It is a true story so I can't really complain that there was no twist ending, but there was no underlying tension. Throughout the film we know the end result and essentially just go through the motions and back-and-forth's it takes to get there. There isn't really a problem with this and again the film is enjoyable on a scene by scene basis. Just a little bit of actual thriller may have been nice though, instead of basically a really great biopic.In fact, if the film was marketed as a biopic I would definitely say it was best picture worthy. Alas, they said thriller, and I wasn't particularly thrilled.The other big problem is that there seems to be a need to add these scenes that just don't fit. The one I will mention is the scene where the plane gets shot down (this is in the trailers and you see it coming from the start). It's an action scene. It doesn't suit the courthouse, suspenseful drama underneath. And this continues throughout the whole film. The biggest fraction of this is the American's pilots story, which is unnecessary. There's a whole message about how we should treat POW's there but the film is Donovan and Abel's story. It shouldn't have to be cut up by this whole other plot.The complaint I'm seeing a lot around the internet is that it's too much of a legal drama. This really isn't a complaint. I'd say about a quarter of the film is full on legal battle, but it's really well done. It fits fluently into the story and is a catalyst for the themes of the film. Also its wonderfully accurate. As a law student I'm a stickler for improper portrayals of courtrooms and statute. But frankly Bridge of Spies was really nice in this regard, despite being a little glamorised.Finally, a short word about the soundtrack. There's not really a huge amount to say. The horns and strings make for a regimental, reverent and hopeful soundtrack, but sometimes in feels out of place. My feeling in the last scene was thoroughly opposed by the soundtrack, but musically was very atmospheric and enjoyableOverall Bridge of Spies is a great film. I would recommend it to any film fan as an exemplar work of film. In short is elegant, mature and smart, though more mainstream fans may find it a bit of a slog. As far as Oscars go I'm expecting supporting actor, original screenplay and director nominations. This is one Spielberg's better films.

Having only going to see this because I had to, the trailer didn't make me want to watch it, I was very surprised at how my I enjoyed it. Focusing on the trial of an accused Russian spy in an American court room, it quickly becomes a case which could have serious ramifications on the paranoid relationship between America and Russia. This is brilliantly directed by Speilberg, who in recent years has made some very bad films. Tom Hanks is always perfectly cast and does a tremendous job. I was also surprised at how much humour there was in this, being about the cold war, you don't expect to be giggling and laughing at all. Well made, acted and directed. A must see and will more then likely be nominated for a few awards.

There are cinematic memoirs that simply slip through the cracks of time and there are movies that retell a historic event the way it should be remembered. Bridge of Spies is the latter.

As a piece of storytelling it is absolutely marvellous - elegent, intelligent and hugely enjoyable. Tom Hanks is magnificent, and Mark Rylance is subtly effective with his minimalist charm and wit. When you have the best story maker in the business at the helm, in Steven Spielberg, I expected it to be great - but this really is superb.

If I go into a film knowing the ending (as I did here) then I really want the director and screenwriter to cook up some tension and surprises. What you get with this film is just about everything else. A funny, intelligent script, universally good acting and beautiful visuals. Trouble is, it's just not that thrilling a ride. Solid as meatloaf.

We had to wait, but it was worth it. This classic tale of the Cold War is brought to life with impeccable performances from a stable that could hardly fail. Indeed, criticism of Messrs Speilberg, Hanks and the Brothers Cohen is tantamount to questioning the actions of a top surgeon under the operating lights. Everything works here as it should, although there are times when we wonder when the Cold War will heat up. That said, Tom Hanks and Mark Rylance bounce off each other so well that they are perfectly capable of creating several masterful moments. This is a film about understatement. Hanks proves once more that he is one of the best actors in the world, in that he, to quote Tony Curtis: Does Not Act! Mark Rylance is the same, hence we get a wonderful scene about the Standing Man - one amongst many - concluding with the Bridge in question. This is the third of three great films this year (Carol and Sicario being the other two). It does not disappoint, making this is a bridge worth crossing for any genuine lover of great films.
