Mark Rylance deserves an Oscar for supporting actor. Great performance.

I love anything to do with the Cold War and I gobble up espionage thrillers like they're delicious tubs of hummus, so I was excited to see this after I saw the trailer. It's a good film, plain and simple. Tom Hanks and Steven Spielberg are probably the most trustworthy cinematic partnership around and have proved that for the last couple of decades. This is brilliantly acted and directed for the most part. The story is engaging, or at least it was to me because of my previously mentioned Cold War fetish, and it's inspired by true events so that makes it doubly interesting. Now, "inspired by" true events can have many definitions, but nothing ridiculous or unrealistic happens in this that makes you question the believably of the story, but I wouldn't be surprised if I find a few inaccuracies after doing some research of my own. It's set in 1957 so if you enjoy that sort of aesthetic you'll definitely get a boner when watching the first half which is set in the USA. Things are a stark contrast in the second half as the story moves to East Berlin during the construction of the Berlin wall, and you really do feel a shared sense of culture shock with Tom Hank's character after leaving the fuzzy warm colours of 50's America in exchange for the biting cold and monochrome portrayal of Soviet controlled Germany. If I had some criticisms they would be the following. I think the first 15-20 minutes are a little slow. Now I don't mind slow films but it just felt like a while for things to really click into gear. The CIA and Russian negotiators have a hint of "mustache-twirling villain" about them, which cheapens some scenes a little. Finally, Spielberg can't help but inject some cheesy sentimentality in places which I'm never thankful for, but the majority of the film plays it straight down the middle and it's only really noticeable towards the end. Overall this is a well made thriller with an interesting story and an immersive setting. It's not for everyone (I saw a few people nodding off during the 2 hours run time) but if you have an interest in the source material you'll get a lot out of it.
Fantastic movie....best one I've seen this year. Even better than the Martian.

A well told espionage thriller that comes together nicely at the end, but lacks excitement or truly gripping scenes due to its slower pacing. The acting and story are good, as are the sets based in Berlin, but the Cold War atmosphere could have been a lot stronger and more imposing.

A Cold War spy movie starring Tom Hanks and directed by Steven Spielberg equates to ridiculously high expectations. However BRIDGE OF SPIES lives up and possibly even exceeds them. I walked out of the theatre having felt a range of emotions and a real sense of fulfillment from the experience.I have to admit that these days when a movie has all the ingredients to be great there is always some skepticism that it will disappoint. Maybe this deep seeded pessimism is what helped makes this movie such a thrill rather than just satisfactory.The story is gripping, fascinating, entertaining and even educational. The acting is top-notch both by Tom Hanks and his supporting cast. While BRIDGE OF SPIES will be a strong contender for various Oscar categories I feel strongly that Mark Rylance as the Russian spy deserves serious consideration for Best Supporting Actor. He perfectly manages to convey a sense of wise calmness without ever misunderstanding the larger things going on around him. His chemistry with Tom Hanks also works splendidly.Beyond tension and intrigue, this movie delivers humor, historical significance and even some unexpected emotional moments (for me at least).Finally, the message in the first 1/3 of the movie about how the USA owes it to itself to stick to its values even when faced with terrible events resonates strongly in today's geo-political context.BRIDGE OF SPIES is a must-see 2015 movie.
Not my kind of movie but it is very well made.
a proper spy film, so atmospheric and well acted

This is a better spy movie than Spectre. A-
If I could I'd give it more than 5!

What a delightful old fashioned spy film from Spielberg and starring good old Hanks. Rylance nearly steals the film from only nearly. Its beautifully shot and wonderfully acted. A lawyer helps a Russian spy find his way back home in exchange for a an American pilot. Quite simply this could be a film of the year

Old master Steven Spielberg delivers a lot of information in this 2 hour plus movie. Tom Hanks delivers a lot of nice little moments and carries a lot of the screen time but it's Mark Rylance who steals the show

Even despite the film's methodical pace (which I had no problem with), this is an enthralling espionage thriller filled with terrific direction from Steven Spielberg, outstanding writing, and a knockout performance from Tom Hanks.Studios: Walt Disney Pictures/20th Century Fox/DreamWorks Pictures

I thought the movie was based on a book but it was not. Screenwriters have done an amazing job and movie is just a modern Classic. Direction of the film reminds me of " the secret in their life". A true piece of cinematic art and the film is unexpectedly funny.

Hanks as always is really enjoyable to watch. Rylance is the balls. Loved that final scene. The story is solid and it flows along nicely. However, if Speilberg wasn't attached to this, I recon their wouldn't be as many critics wanking over it.
Really well done. Little action, little violence, and no sex. Just a really solid historical drama. Tom Hanks was great...as he almost always is.
It was ok but I feel it was trying for Tinker, tailor, soldier, spy but is too whimsical and nostalgic to pull this off.

Steven Speilberg usually goes in two different directions when making a new film. the first direction are epic fantasy/adventure films that anyone can enjoy at any age such as Jaws, E.T., Jurassic Park and the Indiana Jones movies. The other direction which was started with 1993's Schindler's List are war-time bipocs or fictional stories revolved around war whcih are usually a lot more sodre in tone. Bridge of Spies falls into thw latter catergory although it isn't as instese as those other films.Based on the true events of the 1957 prisoner exchange during the Cold War, this screenplay written by the Coen Brothers is very well excuted thanks to the preformaces of Tom Hanks as James Donovan and Mark Rylance as the Russian prisoner Rudolf Abel. Although thery have great chesmisty, the film itself, does take a more episodic sturcture, as after the trail is over, James has to deal with an American getting captured by the Russians, which unlike the snore-inducing Lincoln film of 2012, is actually vvery entertaining and tense to watch.The cinematography and costume design are also outstanding,capturing the look and feel of Berlin, America and Russia during this tense time period and Thomas Newman's score is really emotinal as alwasy in his presvious works on Finding Nemo and Saving Mr Banks.Overall, Bridge of Spies is another gem to add to Steven's ever-growing classic pile and I look forward to see what he and Mark Rylance can bring to the world of Roald Dahl next July

While not especially suspenseful, much like Spielberg's "Schindler's List," the "Bridge of Spies" tells a story of a real event during the cold war between the United States and the USSR. What makes the film a Spielberg great is the ability he has to produce a period piece that makes you feel as though you were there at that time even if you did not know the authenticity of the sights and sounds of the film. A story well told, well acted, well written and presented in a dramatic historical perspective. The two hours will pass quickly.

Inspiring and teaching espionage thriller Bridge of Spies brings the cold war era perfectly to the big screen. Spielberg and Coen brothers along with Mark Rylance and Tom Hanks all did perfectly well, but sometimes the film felt little overlong because of many conversation scenes. Anyways, the audience gets to see another piece of cinematic greatness by Spielberg with a brilliant true story. And lots and lots of talking.

Although it is a little too funny and PG-13 and contains a misguided score from Thomas Newman, Bridge of Spies is still an expertly made and thought-provoking film that is worthy to sit alongside any of Hanks' and Spielberg's best. James Donovan makes for a completely sympathetic and heroic character, and the film will remind you of a great, old-fashioned Jimmy Stewart picture - the kind Hollywood just doesn't make anymore.

Spielberg can't help but portray the Russian spy as most ethical character. Tom Hanks as usual is outstanding. Proves once again that he is in top group of actors. Telling that his character in this film doesn't care whether the Russian Spy is guilty or not (he obviously is). He is more interested in getting him off via a technicality. Nonetheless overall tone of film is that America is better than the commies (duh) and the real life person Hanks portrays must have been an interesting fellow.
Really good flick! Shows what America was like when citizens actually loved their country and treated it with respect. Pre-PC era!

Steven Spielberg's dramatisation about a historical prisoner swap more than a half century ago is undeniably well-crafted and technically detailed - looking good as usual - but lacks depth, not-so-gripping and naively presented.
Spielberg and Hanks together craft Bridges of Spies to be compelling & thrilling enough to comfort the fluff.
A thrilling, emotional and utterly compelling cold war drama with excellent performances and masterful direction by Spielberg.

All five stars as I cannot imagine this made any better. Just plain cold war spy movie without all the fakery of Bond. It is a strong story and it is time to remember the coldest of cold of the war. Tom makes you believe he is the guy in the story. The Soviet spy is also so believable. Again, as good as it gets and must see if you like anything spy. Amazing to see East Berlin recreated.

Great, exceptional, fabulous job by the role of Tom Hanks as Gary powers who won't settle for the release of one person.. However, you've ordered a rare steak and what comes out is a medium steak. It's the same food, and you'll eat it, but it's not what you ordered. This was a diplomatic thriller, when I expected it center more on espionage. I was OK with that. Really engaging. Finest performance Tom Hanks has had a long time. Witty dialogue (The Coen Brothers co-wrote this). My main gripe is Janusz Kaminski's tired use of the "bleeding light" coming in through each and every window, no matter where the characters are (even on a train in East Germany). Its distracting, and he needs to either change his style, or Spielberg needs to find another cinematographer (he yo-yo'd between a few before he found Kaminski for Schindler's List).

An entertaining Bridge to the H'Wood studio days, this Spies game exemplifies Steven Spielberg at his treacly but satisfying best. The golden age of H'Wood are alive and well in the oeuvre of the maestro behind Jaws, E.T., and Jurassic Park, most noticeably in his latest brush with history, Bridge of Spies. Oh, this is not to say that his latest true story unintentionally comes across as old fashioned. Rather, the legendary director purposely exhibits an old-school approach to storytelling and workmanship that brings to mind the days of John Ford (The Grapes of Wrath, The Searchers), William Wyler (The Best Years of Our Lives, Ben-Hur), and - most of all - Frank Capra (Mr. Smith Goes to Washington. It's a Wonderful Life). There's his assured use of Steadicam sweeps and close-ups, as well as a celebrated leading man who radiates both trustworthiness and nationalism. Just look at the film's poster: the giant mug of American hero Hanks caught between the stars and stripes and hammer and sickle, grandstanding the values of life and liberty before the opening credits have even rolled. This process serves him well with a Cold War tale such as this but it also plays it a little too safe. As beautiful and striking as this sentimental film looks, it plays out too predictably, which takes some of the punch out of the more suspenseful moments.In this PG-13-rated thriller based on true events, an American lawyer (Hanks) gets recruited by the CIA during the Cold War to help rescue a pilot (Austin Stowell) detained in the Soviet Union. Calculatedly, the film feels like a family friendly product of the era that it represents, which is laudable on many fronts save for the multiple somewhat heavy-handed endings. For the auteur who chose to chronicle such a specific warts and all bent in the life of the 16th U.S. president with Lincoln, however, his Bridge of Spies ultimately comes across as lighter fare. With a reliably stalwart performance by Hanks, a knock-out turn by stage veteran Rylance as a captured Soviet spy, and quotable dialogue provided by the Coen Brothers, this throwback boasts enough winning moments of distinction that make it stand tall even in a familiar line-up. Bottom line: Spies Like U.S.

Our primary motivation to see this film is our dear friend Jane Helmchen's involvement as a historical consultant in Berlin. BRIDGE OF SPIES is ultimately a well-crafted procedural whose central theme is that diplomacy is driven by human relationships. The film's most pleasant surprise is one of those relationships, between Hanks's attorney and the alleged Soviet spy he is assigned to represent, played by Mark Rylance. The period and local details are exquisite.
Masterfully written, directed, acted, and shot, this film has it all and is a perfect contender for best picture at the Oscars this year.
Although some liberties were taken with the historical details, Bridge of Spies is nonetheless an amazing espionage thriller.
Tom Hanks, Impeccable

??????? ????? aka James Donovan as played by Tom Hanks is an insurance lawyer turned international diplomat in this brilliant real world cold war story about spies, the CIA, the GDR, the KGB and all the other sinister organizations that you'd want in a suspense thriller.We can certainly say Steven Spielberg has not lost his touch for bringing war stories to life on the silver screen. What a brilliant performance all around from everyone involved. I had absolutely no idea what this movie was about and randomly picked it based on Rotten Tomatoes rating and I wasn't in the least disappointed. Now, I'm more interested than ever to read the real story on which this is based.Tom Hanks really harks back to his "Wilson" days with this performance. Singularly lifts and moves the entire plot and does it with aplomb. Not a single scene was misplaced or felt like it was over done. He was pitch-perfect. The supporting cast is no slouch either. Mark Rylance as the alleged Soviet spy is not only steadfast in his performance but his timing and delivery are wonderfully satisfying. Alan Alda (as Tom's boss), John Scott Shepherd (as the CIA agent), Dakin Matthews (as the trial judge), Mikhail Gorevoy (as the KGB chief), and Sebastien Koch (as GDR attorney) all turn in impeccable performances and hold their own in every scene with Tom Hanks. Such powerful acting by the supporting cast makes the lead actor look even better.The story is inspired by true events and if you're into that kind of thing (which I am) you'll be inspired to go investigate more for yourself. It's a slice of history that everyone should be aware of certainly and Steven Spielberg's storytelling is compelling and entertaining throughout. The cinematography, the costumes, the background score, and script really are some of the most satisfying things you'll see on screen this year. This is high-caliber movie-making. Worth every cent of the $12 I spent to see this movie in the theater.If you liked "Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy" you will absolutely love this movie.

Good story but nothing surprised at the director. A cliche plot, so-so story teller and even more worse the American hero idea. cliche and boring as usual when Spielberg wants telling a big story or wants to win an Oscar too bad. Very disappointed to Steven Spielberg. He might never breakthrough to any higher level.

As usual, I think the true answer lies somewhere between both helping foreign refugees and strictly defending Americans and helping homeless vets. But each side continues to want their politics to come out on top, instead of considering the other side may have some "right" in their ideas too.So, in a great instance where art imitates life, I recommend Steven Spielberg's "Bridge of Spies" movie, now playing in theaters. It is one of the year's best, featuring some great performances from Tom Hanks and Mark Rylance, and dares to believe patriotic duty and humanitarianism don't have to make strange bedfellows.

Spielberg can be action packed, like Jurassic Park, or he can be slow and methodical, like Lincoln or Terminal, or even A.I. There is also some middle ground, with balls to the wall action and then moments of character development (see Schindler's List and Saving Private Ryan). Bridge of Spies falls somewhere in between the two categories. Yes, it has action, but its mostly a drama where things move at a slower pace. That sometimes can hurt a film. The film spends the first half dealing with a Russian Spy who is captured in the U.S. and everyone believes Hanks can defend him in a court of law. Then we shift to Berlin, after the U2 is shot down over Russia. Hanks is brought on board to negotiate a transfer of prisoners, the American shot down over Russia for the spy living in NYC. The film picks up speed in Berlin and it stays until pretty much the end, which is a nice change in pace. Honestly, I had problems with the pacing, but they were minor. Some of the acting wasn't the greatest either, and I think this isn't Hanks' best film, nor is it even Spielberg's. SPR, E.T., and Jurassic Park still hold the title as my favorites (with E.T. being #1). Hanks is looking old, and worn out. He reminds me of my dad minus the mustache. The setting is ok. Cold War U.S. looks as it should. We explore the beginnings of the Berlin Wall which I thought was awesome, plus the sequence with the U2 was probably the best in the film. Overall it was slow, but still worth it. We saw it in the VIP seats at Marcus Theaters which means this film is probably not going to be showing much longer - this may even be the last week. The issue I had with the VIP seats was that they stick up too high, cutting into the screen as you look forward. Plus everybody and their brother always has to sit in front of us. Bridge of Spies is worth a shot though. As I said, Spielberg has better films, and so does Hanks. Look out for a cast member from Band of Brothers in the film as well. He plays a German kid. Next to see... Spectre of Flatulence.

Nobody wants foreign spies to catch a break in America. Most of us would rather see them shot on sight. Some would like to have them waterboarded then shot...or hung, or dropped in acid. In the interest of acquiring a poker chip amid the Cold War, Tom's character lawyers a deal so that a Russian spy gets 30 years instead of the Electric Chair. Came in handy when it was time to trade for Francis Gary Powers, our downed U-2 pilot shot down over Russia in 1960, right about the time when the Berlin Wall was going up. Watch one gentle man's harrowing experience as he leaves his cushy comfort zone in America and ventures into a play-for-keeps game of cloak and dagger intrigue in East Germany, at the risk of his own life and reputation. 5 Stars.
Just because its based on a true story does not mean it is exciting. Nice story but just a legal drama. Held my interest to the end, Just.

Loved this film for the cinematography and the script! The delivery was both realistic and heartfelt. One of my favorite film genres - it didn't disappoint! "Would it help?" There's more I want to say, but I hate spoilers. So just go see the film yourself, and then we can talk! :D
Enjoyed movie - a go see
Absolutely brilliant! Classic filmmaking! Historical masterpiece! Totally riveting!

Although it is a charm to watch given the Spielberg-Hanks reunion as well as a script which co-credits the Coen Brothers, BRIDGE OF SPIES proves to be an all-in-all solidly-made film that is entertaining and more or less satisfying, but unfortunately a piece that plays too safe to transcend. SPIES features some smart and masterful filmmaking - as evident in its strong visual storytelling, well-crafted one-on-one exchanges, and clever editing (some amazing match cuts as well as Spielberg and DP Kaminsky's usual soft, glowy lighting amidst beautiful end frames to precise camera moves) - in addition to a steady yet immersive performance by both Hanks and Rylance. However, the film lacks the much-desired impact upon its delivery of turning points; the narrative is fancied with surprisingly funny moments and pleasurable scenes but the plot becomes a bit too easy - the grip never holds on, the sense of danger never reaches its potential, and likewise the end result is not as powerful as it was building up to be (Hanks' character appears to negotiate his ways through obstruction that operates more on its bark than its bite; there is a Cold War level of fear that tags along as opposed to being imposed and infused - with a Spielberg staple, trademark sentimental music, that does little to help). In the end, taking into account the genre of Cold War spy drama/thrillers, Spielberg's latest is simply a solid entry that services quite well but falls short of greatness.

Steven Spielberg once again proves he can do no wrong, especially with real world material. Following the grand traditions of Amistad and Munich, Bridge of Spies is an incredibly fine, concise and versatile Cold War drama/thriller. With an impressively written script contributed oddly by the two and only Cohen Brothers, add to that under Spielberg's bold direction the film shines as one of his most finest films to date. Another big credit added towards the casting, with another impressive collaboration with Tom Hanks (making this their third collaboration), alongside the likes of other incredibly talented actors, particularly Mark Rylance (soon to be in Spielberg's BFG next year), and the gorgeously looking cinematography. The film itself, also tells it's story really well with minimal music by Thomas Newman, making this the third Spielberg film to be scored without John Williams. Overall, the film really challenges the rights of prisoners and country's laws and constitution in a time of great conflict where almost anything could happen. Lastly, it's a highly recommended film in which it's Oscar changes might be big.

A serious minded adult film with outstanding work from Hanks and cinematographer Jausz Kaminski, Spielberg can't seem to help himself when it comes to oversentimentalizing unecessarily. But like pizza, even B+ Spielberg is still head and shoulders above most else.

In a year, FILLED with over-blown, action-oriented secret agent films, Bridge of Spies comes along to remind us that films about espionage can be just as entertaining with crackling dialogue, brilliant acting, and tense scenes and don't require explosions and car chases to keep you invested. Steven Spielberg helms this true story about a Brooklyn lawyer who's tasked with defending a Soviet Spy in court and negotiating his safe passage home in exchange for an American P.O.W. and it is simply EXCELLENT! The script was co-written by the Coen Brothers and their snappy/hilarious dialogue was a joy to listen to, perfectly delivered by a talented ensemble cast with the always-outstanding, Tom Hanks leading the charge. The film is broken up into two distinctive parts with the first half being the court case and the second half taking place in Berlin with Hanks negotiating the swap of prisoners on the aptly named: "Bridge of Spies" and it was so refreshing to see a film so evenly balanced. Hanks' calm, collected performance as a man who truly believes everyone deserves a fair judgement, whether an immigrant or not, was captivating to say the least and the verbal chess he plays with many opposing parties were easily the highlights of the film. Another stand-out actor is the Soviet Spy, played by an actor I've never heard of named, Mark Rylance, and this guy had some of the best line delivery in the entire film and his acting seemed effortless. Unlike Spielberg's last historical drama, Lincoln, which bored me to death, this film keeps the pace going with fantastic editing between the numerous characters and also manages to make the history come across highly interesting! The two hours and twenty minute run-time flew by and I have to hand it to Spielberg for keeping me completely invested in an action-less film (save for one incredible plane crash sequence) and though it is a dialogue-driven film; boy does it drive!
Great old fashioned thriller !

An entertaining, yet conventional film about an insurance lawyer who has the difficult task of defending a KGB operative who is accused of espionage. The film is shot in hushed tones, which portrays a sense of dread. Tom Hanks does a good job bringing his charming personality to a difficult time of fear and paranoia. It's never too bogged down, but it can be guilty of being overly sentimental. Overall a good film.

James Donovan: "Aren't you worried?"Rudolf Abel: "Would it help?"Bridge of Spies takes place during the Cold War, an American lawyer is recruited to defend an arrested Soviet spy in court, and then help the CIA facilitate an exchange of the spy for the Soviet captured American U2 spy plane pilot, Francis Gary Powers. So I finally just watch Bridge of Spies and it was pretty damn good. Steven Spielberg once again made a great movie, and just like I said about Ridley Scott about how great it is that we still can go to the cinema today and see a new movie directed by an icon. Steven Spielberg is the type of director you never know what you're going to get and I'm talking about the type of film making he uses. Spielberg will always make a well directed movie even when some of his movie are not great or something you'll never watch again, it will be well directed. Steven Spielberg's directing in Bridge of Spies was absolutely superb, because every scene is so perfectly crafted and Spielberg knows when to cut to a emotional reaction with the characters. These a couple of scenes in this movie that I didn't notice was all in one long wide take with no breaks, and that's because I was so locked in on what was going on with the characters and the scene itself. Spielberg brilliance is still present today as he's masterful style of film making is still alive today. If you love that kind of film making that's so masterful, perfect and old school directing, then Bridge of Spies might be the movie for you. This is one of the best directed films I've seen so far this year.  Tom Hanks is one of the most lovable and respected actors of are times, as in every role he dose, he never disappoints. This is he's fourth collaboration with Spielberg after: Catch Me If You Can, Saving Private Ryan and The Terminal, and in Bridge of Spies Hanks once again deliverers a magnificent and believable performance. This is an Oscar worthy performance as he made his character so relatable, funny and very likable. Without spoiling anything, there's a scene in this movie where Tom Hanks character (James Donovan) gets followed by this unknown figure and at one point Donovan goes to sit at this restaurant to confront this man and the scene itself is just amazing, because Donovan knocks this guy to the ground with no action, just dialogue. Tom Hanks was amazing in this movie. Another performance that blow me away was Mark Rylance as the soviet spy. I have seen this actor before in the hit TV show "Wolf Hall", and he was great in that show, but he impressed the hell out of me in this movie, because Mark Rylance was absolutely fantastic. This guy deserves an Oscar nomination for best supporting actor and I hope he dose, because it would be a huge sub if he doesn't get nominated. Mark Rylance was fan-freaking-tastic in this movie.The cinematography was excellent, the score was great, the dialogue is outstanding and the story was really good.Now for the problems: These a couple of scenes around the second act that wasn't that interesting to me.If you don't like talky movies then you may not enjoy Bridge of Spies, because this whole movie is nothing but talking and I know some people may not find that enjoyable. I'm the kind of person who likes dialogue driven movies and that's why I enjoyed this movie, because of the movies excellent dialogue and I how locked in I was while watching it, but I know it's not going to be for everyone and if you think this movie is boring because it's a talky movie then that's fine.Overall Bridge of Spies isn't Spielberg's greatest movie compared to his other ones, but it is a well crafted movie with excellent performances, fantastic directing and great writing. Bridge of Spies is the best Cold War thriller I've ever seen.

For a military brat who came of age in Germany at the end of the cold war, it was a real treat to experience the German dialogue without subtitles. Hanks and Rylance were outstanding. I cared more about the fate of the Russian spy than the American pilot. The Coen brothers were credited, though I did catch in what capacity. The color of post-war East Berlin looked like it had their touch.

Absolutely riveting film. Who'd a thought we'd be nostalgic for the Cold War but this movie puts some very human faces on that paranoid and bizarre era in America and overseas. Tom Hanks gives a great performance and will no doubt be nominated for an Oscar. His role of an insurance lawyer thrust into defending a known Russian spy and then brokering his exchange for Gary Powers is sometimes surreal, sometimes emotional but always with a touch of presence not often seen these days. Surprisingly little blood and what there is is very well done. All of the characters are pretty fully realized since they are based on real people, some of whom are probably still living. That's the thing about this film. While some of it is stylized for dramatic effect, most of it really happened...it's history you want to watch! An amazing film with terrific acting, sets, and a riveting, plausible story-line especially to those who remember those times. If it doesn't sweep the Oscars there is no integrity in cinema IMHO.

Even though I went into the theater very excited, it still exceeded my already high expectations, and I would recommend this movie to anyone who is curious to learn an accurate representation of how people were treated during the Cold War.
Mark Rylance is amazing in this reserved performance.

Interesting story of 50s intrigue. Of course Hollywood presents the Soviet spy as a kind, humorous, faithful and heroic figure is spite of representing an ideology that murdered 150 million people. Most of the Americans were painted with a McCarthyism brush. Thats showbusiness.

Steven Spielberg. Tom Hanks. The Coen Brothers. Any of these people alone would be enough to get me in the theater; but combined are a recipe for greatness. Greatness, however wouldn't be the word I'd use to describe Bridge of Spies. This film is good, mind you. Very good. Tom Hanks is very Tom Hanksy. And it feels very much like a Speilberg film. Both great things. It serves as a very interesting look at the Cold War: espionage, paranoia, and a witch-hunting culture of America at the time. The scenes in Berlin were quite compelling, and the score helped a very sentimental ending to tear up most in attendance. ~ B+
A well done film. Great acting and a compelling story. I plan to take my sons.

Great movie its a little dumbed down but still one of the best this year.

I thought this film looked like your typical Spielberg/Hanks Oscar film so I wasn't in a huge hurry to rush out to see it (don't think I'm alone as it is doing okay at the box office, but didn't start out amazing or anything). But I did end up liking this film quite a bit and it wasn't 100% predictable (only like 80%). Tom Hanks is great in this and I loved some of the old shots of Germany and the Berlin wall, but it was Mark Rylance, who really stole the show for me as I felt like pulling for the Russian spy more than anyone else. I haven't heard his name out there for Oscar nominations just yet (maybe it's too early), but he would definitely have my vote as of right now. Overall, Bridge of Spies was a very good film that exceeded my expectations.
This intense spy movie is lead along by a civilian lawyer played by Tom Hanks. Charming and occasional light comedy to break the tension that is the Cold War. Great movie that isn't too dark.

Really really really solid movie. Tom Hanks is great and really carries the film. Quite frankly this would probably suck overall with a lesser actor. The best parts of the movie are the scenes between Mark Rylance and Tom Hanks with the exception of their final scene which is a bit heartbreaking but also a bit nauseating because of the forced Spielberg sentimentality which normally works but not so much here. However, I would still strongly recommend this movie.

Loved this movie. I think this is the best picture I've seen this year. An important story that really happened, and that most of us have never heard anything about. A lot of people know about when Francis Gary Powers was shot down and released for some russian spy. Few if any of us know the details. Beyond that this movie is about our system of justice, and lack thereof at the highest levels. It shows the end of the 50's with wonderful detail, and sense of political sentiments at the time. The production is first rate. the acting is top notch. I won't say anymore other than this was one of the best Spielberg movies, with writing that excelled by the Joel and Ethan Coen. At some point, this movie should be required viewing for all Social Studies students.

Hanks, Spielberg and I believe the Cohen brothers may have been involve or not, but a must see. Should be an Oscar contender and a Best Actor nod for Hanks. This movie is like reading a good book you can't put down.

This cold war historical drama contains good solid performances and realistic, detailed period settings. While the film kept my interest (mainly from an historical perspective) and tried to build tension and suspense, it didn't quite reach those heights. It was often predictable, overly patriotic and too long for me to make any real connection with the characters. And somehow I felt like I'd seen it all before.
Well-crafted and stylish.

A tour de force for Tom Hanks. Being older this brought back memories of a time that most either aren't aware of or have forgotten. A most see for those that want a taste of the 50s in America and Berlin. Also the Berlin Wall saw many give their lives in their attempts at escape. So that just places emphasis on the reality of a time when the dark side was much more obvious than it is today. I believe that this film is a Oscar in waiting.
Just got in from seeing this movie. Tom Hnks was great!!! Very well done all.Don't miss this one.
Phenomenal movie. Great acting and storyline.

A first-rate suspenseful spy thriller/historical drama in the grand tradition of epic Cold Ware tales. Director Steven Spielberg has produced one of his best films in ages, avoiding the bloated, tedious style characteristic of his more recent efforts. With BRIDGE OF SPIES, Steven Spielberg has crafted an effortlessly engrossing drama of human interaction, backroom dealing, and moral fortitude on the geopolitical stage. Far from being a dry account of events, the movie is a vital and engaging work of cinema, showcasing Spielberg still at the height of his powers and in full command of the cinematic form. Anchoring the story is Tom Hanks' work, and it's an incredibly inspiring performance, one that presents the character as a man of remarkable integrity; there's nothing splashy about it, simply a decency and moral authority that few (if any) other actors could convey as well as Hanks does. Like Atticus Finch or Jefferson Smith before him, Hanks' Donovan is a true believer in the American process and fights for it, even as he knows that he might not emerge truly victorious. Mark Rylance also makes a very strong impression in a performance that I consider a masterclass in understatement; so much of what Rylance does is deeply internalized, and that makes him a fascinating presence to watch. The production design - which is Oscar worthy - completely puts the audience in the time and place, and the presentation of East Berlin is particularly striking. The screenplay rather deftly weaves together its plot strands, and the second half of the film, which details the various intertwined and entangled agendas that Hanks' character must navigate, is absolutely enthralling; the script is also not without humor (of the very charming sort), which grounds the movie - which is otherwise about spycraft and the confrontations between the United States and the Soviet Union - with a degree of warmth and humanity. Some may see the movie as being lesser Spielberg; I would disagree, but even if that were the case, "lesser" Spielberg still tends to be pretty damn great, and BRIDGE OF SPIES is one of 2015's best films.

Bridge of Spies is the latest in a long line of Spielberg movies. It tells the story of Jim Donovan (Tom Hanks) an insurance lawyer who is hired by the government to represent Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance) an accused Soviet spy during the cold war in the 50s. And afterward that case, Donovan is recruited by the United States government again to negotiate a prisoner trade of Abel, for american's held in the U.S.S.R.Things I Liked:Tom Hanks. Hanks is continuing to be one of my favorite actors. His work in this has great moments and they feel both like things you love about a Tom Hanks performance but also new things that show his growth as a performer and really make him stand out. He carries the movie well and really has a good sense of how big what he is doing is but also lighthearted moments that make us keep our eyes with him the entire film.Mark Rylance. Rylance is a virtual unknown in the movie world, but if you look at this stage credits you understand why this guy is so good. Rylance has this charm and calm demeanor that allows him to steal the scene. He can win your attention without saying a word, and when he does speak he take control of your attention and steals the movie. Rylance is brilliant in this movie.Things I Didn't Like:The Plot. The story of this movie is a little split focus and a bit cliched. The first half is Donovan defending Abel and it has all of the person does a thing no one likes and is forced to deal with the consequences moments that you see in other movies. The second half is the exchange and you don't spend enough time with the Americans Donovan is trying to win back, to care about them. The movie needed more time or needed to cut half of it's premise out and really focus on one part or another.Overall:Overall, the movie is a performance driven movie. All the cast is strong and the characters are all really well done. But the plot suffers from a number of issues that keep the film from really being a powerhouse. If the plot had just been about the relationship between Donovan and Abel this movie could have been spectacular but the way they split that with this second plot moment detracts and if not for the strong lead performances, particularly Hanks and Rylance, the movie would suffer.

The notion that Spielberg is "too sentimental" is a claim that critics fall back on far too often, to the point that it's become an empty clich� in and of itself. Spielberg's films are rarely ever sentimental to the point of feeling cheesy or maudlin, simply settling comfortably in the realm of the old-fashioned, almost always to excellent results; Bridge of Spies fits into this niche well.There is legitimate craft to this work that people will intentionally overlook in order to write it off as "just another biopic" or as "Oscar-bait", both claims banal in their erroneousness. Spielberg utilizes mirrors as a subtle visual flourish to nod at the nature of perception, a theme that a film about spies and nations engaged in a battle of presentation through bluffs and propaganda would deal with extensively. He makes a poignant statement about the indoctrination of children in regards to their internalized fear and hatred of whomever is considered to be "the enemy" at the time, a relevant idea given the current political climate and the fact that one of the most popular candidates in the race for president in the Republican party has largely staked his campaign on demonizing the other to great success. It's absolutely gorgeous to look at. To put it bluntly, there are nuances and a depth to this film that need to be acknowledged as opposed to the trite trading of hackneyed, stock criticisms.This said, there are a couple of flaws that keep it from achieving perfection, namely its four endings that, while all well-done and intelligent in regards to the screenplay's construction, feel unnecessary and hokey in a way that the film as a whole had successfully avoided. The length is also a problem, not because it ever feels dull, but because there are some sequences that could be excluded in order for the production as a whole to feel tighter and more economic. However, these are minor, and given the fact that Hanks turns in an excellent performance and the direction is uniformly intelligent in every other regard, they can certainly be overlooked.

To wit, the tacked-on ending, a specialty. Really, the same people are on the train and just have to give him a sickly smile? The best part is Rylance, a treasure. And the production design and other technical credits, all flawless as we have learned to expect from Mr. S. During the height of the Cold War in the late '50s, insurance lawyer Jim Donovan (Tom Hanks, in his most casual, least "actor-y" performance in years) is enlisted to defend a Soviet agent apprehended in the US (Mark Rylance), and finds himself brokering a spy trade for two captive Americans in Eastern Europe. Jarringly low-key outing from Steven Spielberg is compelling and gets the period detail dead right, but at 141 minutes the film moves at a glacial pace, which isn't exactly thrilling, and lacks the emotional thrust of Spielberg's other "grown-up" pictures (particularly "Saving Private Ryan" and "Schindler's List"). Nevertheless, it's a well-made drama that offers fine acting all around and some dry humor around the periphery (likely courtesy of co-writers Ethan and Joel Coen).

What's Spielberg without war? He continues pushing out film after film involving some war story and somehow we can never get tired of it. We never feel like he's beating a dead horse. It's because the man encapsulates the classic ideals of cinema, and one of the last of his kind to do so.Spielberg's way of directing is the kind that invites you to come aboard, but never forces you to. He doesn't beg for your attention--you just can't help but give it to him--sometimes without even realizing.Bridge of Spies is a story about espionage, human rights, societal opinion, understanding your enemy, and American pride all wrapped up into one. It's at its very best when themes conflict and contradict with one another--which happens all throughout. Taking place in New York in the 1950s during the Cold War, it stars Tom Hanks as James B. Donovan, an insurance lawyer chosen to represent captured Soviet spy Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance). Obviously, Donovan becomes one of America's most hated men, meanwhile developing a friendship with Abel and truly understanding his life and choices. Then tables are turned as now the Soviets have captured one of our own spies and Donovan must use Abel as leverage to trade back what is ours.Bridge of Spies constantly reminds us that at our worst we are still better than the Soviet Union. It acts as a good reminder of our humanity, even during the times that are most bereft of it. Perhaps it even satirizes our willingness to change our minds. While our viewpoints may be skewed at times by the media or even the government, it reminds us that we never quite know the whole story--although we're wholly convinced that we do at times. The first third takes place in America--presumably on purpose. It's a little darker than many other period pieces may depict it as--say even this year's The Man from U.N.C.L.E.--obviously a very specific perspective of the era. Then the last chunk of the film features the most depraved East Berlin. But the thing is, here we don't see it as any exaggeration. It's exactly how we've always envisioned it during that time. That's how it was--glum and depressing--another reminder.Spielberg uses juxtaposition to its finest potential, transitioning between scenes of Americans and Soviets--an American spy going to sleep in his cell after being tortured by Soviet soldiers cuts to Abel, the most hated man in America, being woken up respectfully by American prison guards.I will say, however, that there is something missing with the absence of a John Williams score in the film, but Thomas Newman's style fits nicely with the project adding the right amounts of emotion.The film adequately captures the misinformed fears of the early Cold War and uses them to get its points across. It's last reminder, and perhaps its strongest, is that you never know the whole story. When you stop thinking independently you begin allowing others to control you--much like the Soviets tried doing. It's crazy. Our fear was inadvertently becoming what it so desperately tried to avoid. How can you not love Spielberg? He brings magic back into the movies when we feel, at times, it may be gone forever. Bridge of Spies is superb--one of the year's best. This is why I go to the movies.Twizard Rating: 100

Bridge of Spies is directed by Steven Spielberg and stars Tom Hanks as a US attorney who is tasked with negotiating the release of a US spy in exchange for a Russian spy. Except for one sequence, the whole movie features Tom Hanks talking to various people and thanks to a compelling story and sharp writing the movie is extremely engaging from start to finish. For a 2h 15min movie its perfectly paced and there isn't a single scene that feels boring. The direction by Spielberg is terrific as he turns such a straightforward story into something so interesting and the script by the Coen Bros surprisingly has quite a bit of humour that works really well. Tom Hanks delivers a fantastic performance as always and his character is extremely likeable. Mark Rylance who plays the Russian spy is also great in the film. My issue with Bridge of Spies is that the scenes showing the american spy being captured in Russia wasn't as good as the ones with the Russian Spy. The character of the american spy wasn't really fleshed out and there was a particular scene which showed the Russians torturing the US prisoner before cutting to the US prison officials treating the Russian spy prisoner nicely. I am sure in real life both sides treated the prisoners harshly. However, these are minor flaws in an otherwise near perfect film. Bridge of Spies is one 2015's best films and is definitely a must watch. A

The marketing force behind Spielberg's recent work labels "Bridge of Spies" as a cold war thriller. There is an argument to be made that this label might be slightly misleading (perhaps in line with the trailers that turn the 2 hr and 15 minute full future in to a fast paced two minute summary... which in itself is somewhat ironic given that Spielberg has fused the 5 years that exists between arrest and exchange of the American/Soviet spies in to a conveniently brisk narrative). In truth the film is less thriller and more of a social commentary (of the cold war era) and patient character film. There is not much in the way of action (the narrative itself is almost entirely dialogue driven), rather the film moves forward primarily through the development of the relationship between Abel (Rylance) and Donovan (Hanks). With possible mixed expectations aside, Bridge of Spies as a commentary and as a character film, Bridge of Spies is a very good film.  The reality of the Cold War was less about military force and more about competing ideologies. Spielberg deftly navigates this particular dynamic with a sharp and intentional examination of American patriotism (or patriotism in general) that moves beyond flag waving to the heart of what it means to be truly free (which, as Donovan points out in the role of Abel's criminal defence lawyer, is about erasing the lines that divide our Irish, German, Russian backgrounds and learning to live on equal ground with equal rights).The most interesting part of the film (for me) is the relationship between Abel and Donovan. There is a scene at the end that finds Hank's character returning to his homeland and looking out at a few kids who are jumping a fence in their backyard. The scene is intended to bring us back to the horrifying picture that he is leaving behind of the concrete fence of Berlin. For all that this scene conjures emotionally, Spielberg has assured that we are able to interpret it through the lens of the Abel/Donovan relationship. It is interesting to note that the film has no real villain, reminding us that in the ideological battles of the cold war that there are no real winners, no real sides to take when human lives are the ultimate causalities. In the end there are only the ideals themselves, the things that hold us together as a Country and as a world. This is what Abel and Donovan represent. What makes these two characters so interesting is their competing performances. On their journey towards a mutual understanding and respect, their respective paths are expressed uniquely. In both cases they are faced with the complicated questions of loyalty (in respect to the ideologies they are protecting), and in both cases they must carry the weight that appears to hangs in the balance of their particular case. For Donovan, on the surface this is the unsettling of his job, his family and his life/safety. His character remains fairly transparent, and he wears his concern on his sleeve. The character of Abel is much more complicated, offering a counter to Donovan's emotional clarity. In many ways Abel is the one who embodies the tension that moves the discussion of patriotism forward. He reminds us that what is on the surface (a British accent and a mysterious background) is not always the most accurate picture of what lies underneath. His seeming lack of concern for his own life hides some deep set emotional response to Donovan's compassion. This is meant to remind us that for all that we do to erect the walls that divide us in this world, there is nothing more penetrating than acts of compassion. On a purely historical level, the film does a wonderful job of bringing to stark realism of watching the wall go up brick by brick. While the story of the American spy ultimately sits in the background (as a less interesting subplot), the trajectory of the narrative itself manages to bring us in on the tension of the era. There is a wonderful scene between Donovan and his son in which his son is desperately preparing for the eventual nuclear attack. It is this sort of fear that seems to persist in modern day terrorism and nuclear pacts. It is this sort of fear that sits behind our tendency to stereotype demographics and cultural groups in to victims and enemies, heroes and villains. Spielberg represents a timely and timeless dialogue on what it means to exist together in a complicated landscape. For as dark and important as all of this is, the Coen Brothers credit as screenwriters deserves mention. They keep the film light hearted and humorous as it moves through some heavy history and themes. They bring a knack for humorous dialogue that makes the film (dare I say) fun. Combined with Spielberg's visual vision, Bridge of Spies is understated in many ways in terms of how smart it actually is. It deserves multiple viewings (I think... I have only seen it once to date) to allow some expertly crafted scenes and clever and fast moving dialogue to fully sink in. The film resonates, but behind the film are many memorable scenes. And what pulls it all together is the transparent nature of Hank's acting skills and his likeable nature. It is easy to believe in what he stands for, and he is in great form in this return to a Spielberg/Hanks partnership. Rylance likewise fills in the counter balance with a wonderfully intriguing performance that makes (what is less screen time than Hanks) every moment count. Bridge of Spies reminds me less of some of Spielberg's older works, and more of something along the lines of Monument Men, or maybe even something like Catch Me if You Can. Important but fun, patiently paced but fast moving dialogue. Dark but illuminating in terms of historical drama. Interpreting an event or era through its dominating theme (in the case of Monument Men, exposing what hangs in the balance of the destruction of our world's art; and in the case of Bridge of Spies, interpreting the affect of the Cold War on our ideological divisions). Most importantly though, the film is memorable, and is a nice addition to Spielberg's long list of successful films.

This is a very well directed movie. The production design is very good, the cinematography is also very good and the actors are great in their respective roles. But if you are not the slightest bit interested in the Cold War and the espionage between the United States and the U.S.S.R during this time, then you will be bored out of your mind. Luckily for me, I do like history and enjoyed this movie for what it is. I realize that I am not the demographic for this. After the screening I attended, a bunch of elderly ladies stood up in front of me and said, "It's an amazing film because we were alive when it happened. Weren't we Susan?" That shows you that this is a historical drama, not an action war film. So don't go into this expecting Saving Private Ryan. Also, Steven Spielberg's signature magic was not front and centre. You don't realize you're watching a Steven Spielberg film until the credits roll. You just think you are watching a well-made historical drama. If negotiation dialogue is your forte, then this film is for you. As for me, I'm glad I saw it, but doubt I will see it again.

Bridge of Spies is an old fashioned, conventional espionage thriller that is a treat for cinema lovers. Set during the climax of the Cold War, Tom Hanks convincingly portrays an insurance lawyer caught between two ferns. As we have come to expect from Hanks, he is outstanding whilst paired with Steven Spielberg. Mark Rylance is particularly noticeable as the Soviet agent. He is able to conceal his emotions but at the same time he evokes a strong sense of empathy within the viewer. One of the only faults with the film is that there isn't an abundance of suspense. The plot follows a straight-forward path, but the spectacular acting and definitive direction cover up any other flaws that the film has.
Spielberg and Hanks do it again in this Cold War thriller.

Steven Spielberg is by far one of the most prolific filmmakers in modern history, from suspenseful adventures like the Indiana Jones franchise and Jurassic Park to heartwarming classics like E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial and Schindler's List. The list goes on and on. Tom Hanks on the other hand is known for films such as Big, Forrest Gump, and Apollo 13. He also played the voice of Sheriff Woody in the Toy Story films. Both men are committed liberals, but what differentiates them from others in their ilk are they're Americans first, and lift-wingers later. That's one of the reasons why their latest film together, Bridge of Spies, puts political posturing aside to focus on an exchange of a Russian spy named Rudolph Abel for American soldier Francis Gary Powers.Hanks plays James B. Donovan, an attorney who in real life mainly did not work on defense cases. That all changed during the cold war. In 1957, KGB spy Rudolph Ablel was arrested in Brooklyn by the FBI after retrieving a secret message from a park bench. Now, it's up to Donovan to defend him at all costs. You might think that Spielberg is sympathizing with the enemy here (since he made the Russian Czars the enemy of the Jews in the 1986 animated film An American Tail, only the Czars were cats and the Jews were mice who want to move to America), but that really isn't the case. The film's goal is to show the risks lawyers have to take. Defense lawyers have to do whatever it takes to defend their clients in the most controversial of instances, even if it means having to exchange a Russian spy for an American soldier. Eventually he successfully gets his wish, and consider that a spoiler alert, because history always spoils itself - even in film).No doubt, this film proves Steven Spielberg still has the skill and the ambition that made him a huge star in the 70's and 80's. The script was a great fit for him, and I don't know anyone other than Spielberg who can. This is by far the best film out of this year's Oscar contenders. With Spielberg's name on it though, it's more than just a crowd pleaser - it's a film any adult can enjoy instead of just arthouse elitists.

Even with hardly any action going on for this political spy thriller, which is driven mostly by courtroom dialogue and legal speak, it still manages to be a very engaging story. Tom Hanks is in fine form as always, but it was Mark Rylance's performance as Abel and his underlying thoughts that is the heart of what drives the stakes of the story.

Highly recommended. RT SCORE: 4.5/5, IMDB SCORE: 9/10.

Bridge of Spies is an amazing movie that will be brought up during the awards season. Yes, Tom Hanks does an amazing job, but Mark Rylance (who played the accused Russian spy Rudolph Abel) owned every scene he was in. Bridge of Spies shoots straight into Spielberg's collection of great films. I wouldn't say it's his best (if you don't know Spielberg's directorial library, I don't know what to tell you), but if almost any other director did this, it would immediately become their greatest film ever. The script, casting, cinematography, and acting were all top-notch. Tom Hanks brings his character, James Donovan, to life. If the supporting cast, especially Mark Rylance, weren't up to par, Hanks may have stood out more, but everyone involved was fantastic. The only things for me was that there was a lot going on and as the story jumped from one idea to the next, and it took a few seconds to process and fit these scenes into the story. There were also a couple of times where it seemed to get a little long, but the scenes were all necessary to get ideas across and make the ending work the way it did. For fans of great film making, Bridge of Spies is a must see.

Brian Tallerico's review in the Chicago Sun Times best captures the essence of BRIDGE OF SPIES in his keen observations on the first scene: "Steven Spielberg's 'Bridge of Spies' opens with a shot of a man looking in a mirror as he paints a nearly-complete self-portrait. The man is shot from behind. We are not really seeing 'him.' We are looking at two reflections, one in glass and one in watercolors. The truth is in the middle. This duality of perception vs. reality and, eventually, the concept of those three triangular points of interest (reflection, man, painting)-which look similar but aren't quite-will resurface in 'Bridge of Spies,' a daring, studied, mannered true story that is at once remarkably genuine and deeply cinematic at the same time." Spielberg's newest historical film does a remarkable job of capturing the tensions of the cold war by using a case study of a covert prisoner exchange. The writing talents of the Coen Brothers combined with brilliant acting (especially from Mark Rylance), editing/pacing, and cinematography make BRIDGE OF SPIES one of the most well constructed movies of the year as well. The story is about an American attorney (Hanks) secretly employed by the FBI to negotiate a prisoner exchange with Russia that neither government wishes to publicize. All along the way, political dialogue that may be relevant to contemporary affairs is surfaced. Spielberg's resume proves he is definitely in the "if you don't learn from history, you are doomed to repeat it" camp. While sometimes the messages feel perhaps a little too overt or are maybe a bit too much of a slap on the back for good old 'Merica, there are also great moments that are both acknowledging of United States' flaws and hopeful that people will ultimately try and do good. The concept of "good" is a bit complicated in this movie about spies, but the complication makes things interesting. On one hand, the protagonist is adamant that rule of law be the ultimate marker of righteousness and fairness, whereas, on the other, he is a bit deceptive, often insubordinate, and has a tendency to do what he thinks is right whether that matches well with the authorities' opinions or not. Sometimes he is a bit like modern superheroes, who bend rules while avoiding explicitly breaking them. The kicker for this narrative is that the protagonist's rule bending is always out of sympathy for his fellow man - no matter where they are from or who they represent. In short, he wins battles in a war with virtually no weapon except kindness. This reminder is sorely needed and every audience can benefit from ruminating on it.

Bridge of Spies is a reliable comfort blanket if it can be said for a politcal thriller/negotiation film based at the height of the Cold War focusing on Tom Hanks insurance lawyer who is brought in by the US government to negotiate the release and exchange of a Russian spy in american holding for a spy plane pilot grounded above Russian controled airspace. More minimalist and space compared to other Spielberg films in keeping with his milennial look and technique, Master Steven hold the tension well and Hanks holds the screen well as the idealistic Jimmy Stewart type fighting for the little guys against the big Governmental cogs,and what is most remarkable is that Thomas Newmans score ducks into the proceedings without skipping a beat as if he had always been the composer for Spielberg and not John Williams. Outside of one interesting scene quirk that is a total Coen brothers tribute, given that this was worked off of a Coen brothers screenplay, this fits nicely into Spielbergs filmmography.

Bridge of Spies takes place in the 1950's--when two-tone Buicks with fins flash around the United States while in East Germany they drive tan Talbots without radios. Nikita and Ike spy on one another's nuclear arsenals. Colonel Abel is a chain- smoking Russian mastermind communication expert who is "ratted" out by an incompetent Russian agent who defects. The FBI nabs the Colonel --dressed only in his undershorts--who resembles your Uncle Herman in the Bronx.  James Donovan (Tom Hanks)is assigned to defend the laconic Colonel.Despite a decent defense, the Colonel Abel is found guilty and awaits sentencing--quite possible execution. "Aren't you ever worried ?" asks Donovan who is perplexed by Colonel Abel's mild demeanor. "Why be worried" --answers Colonel Abel, "Would it do any good?" Donovan has a strategy that may spare the Colonel--why not spare him for a swap. This brilliant cold war chess move keeps both sides from checkmating g each other and ends in a draw. He is eventually swapped for our civilian weather pilot who strays into Russian territory with three brownie cameras scotch- taped to his piper cub who mistakingly thinks he's in Kansas.  StevenSpielberg directs so nicely that we forget we are watching a film. The Coen Brothers helped script the irony of MAD (Mutually Assured Destruction).

Bond of men in the coldest of times.Capturing the weight and gloom of an era, Bridge of Spies is equally a biopic and an unexpected light drama. There's a lingering intensity, especially concerning the world of secrecy, yet it's a fascinatingly accessible story with subtle refined humor. This is meant to inspire instead of evaluation of ideologies, showcasing that humanity still resides beyond the other side of border or wall.Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance) is an alleged Soviet spy, he's caught and set for a trial. For his defense James Donovan (Tom Hanks) is unceremoniously selected, mainly for the purpose of procedure. After a while Donovan becomes invested on defending his client despite the unusual circumstance, it then takes him on a journey to help CIA save their own agent.Despite the rather shady title, this is not the flamboyant gunslinger action ala James Bond or the intense operation like Argo. It is, strangely and also effectively, a light foray into the otherwise dark world of espionage. The pace is utterly calm, credit goes to Mark Rylance as Abel, who occasionally shows the pettiness of worrying.He and Tom Hanks have incredible chemistry, both of the characters practically have nothing in common aside from the mutual respect towards each other. Donovan himself is avid negotiator, he pushes his objective with verbal aggression, yet the movie almost never resorts to violence and even on few occasions that it does venture to bleak territory, it does so with sophistication.Rather than using typical war buildup, the movie gives faces to each party, thus humanizing them in incredibly identifiable way. It also deals with the issues of the era head-on while maintaining composure and suspending judgment. Lastly, it offers a soft touch of comedy along the way. The unexpected banters lighten the mood with timely cynical quip, it doesn't undermine the theme and still gives polished interaction between the supposed stoic personalities.Bridge of Spies is perhaps one of the most accessible depictions of a war. It might set in Cold War and showcase the grim reality of it, yet it never falters on presenting honor, duty and the best side of humanity in less than favorable time.

My favorite duo is back! Spielberg and Hanks (favorite director and general filmmaker and favorite actor)! Oh yes! The cold war is not at the top of my list in terms of most interesting time periods but that's personal preference as this half century or so of the 20th century is chock-full of stories from the neighborhood to the warzone. In this film, the neighborhood is the war zone, or at least it could have been. That was the interesting and exciting thing to me - watching a man fight for what he believes, fight for great principles even when the country he's fighting for doesn't understand, his family doesn't understand, his bosses don't understand, even his client doesn't understand. In an era of fear, he rose above it to dispense justice. But the film moves on from the trial of the spy to the prisoner exchange which isn't as interesting to me as the defense of the spy was. This was 2 movies put into one and even the master, Spielberg, whom I still believe can do no wrong, can't make it thrilling and heart-pounding all the way through. I look back and think that there aren't many scenes where I was feeling the tension. This movie could have racked up the suspense and the uncertainty a LOT. Having said this, it's still a well made film and none of the performances will leave you wanting more. It's simply the story that will and the experience. More of a slice of history than a full blown piece of drama.

There's no denying that Bridge of Spies is a flawlessly executed film. Spielberg is methodical and relentless in his search of film-making perfection. Hanks is the perfect acting multi-tool, properly slotting himself into a role and becoming that role as well as (or better than) anyone in Hollywood. The problem with this film and with Spielberg as a whole is that flawless execution simply doesn't, in and of itself, make a classic, all-time film. And that is all that Bridge of Spies has going for it. The movie is 100% risk free. It is a politically correct (as of just recently), all-American film that properly serves to appease white upper class Americans with visions of an imaginary utopia of traditional families and American values. There was no way this couldn't sit well with critics or financiers and that attitude has defined Spielberg ever since he attempted to finish A.I. for Kubrick. The fact of the matter is that there is nothing to define his latest film from the rest of crowd this year. Bridge of Spies is dull, by-the-book and an ultimately disappointing entry from a director that used to be among the great innovators in Hollywood.

BRIDGE OF SPIES is a solid Cold War period drama with interesting characters, but what it isn't is exciting. It acts like it wants to be a great political spy thriller, but it's all politics and no thrill. It sets itself up to be a great courtroom drama, but then skips all that to get to the politics. And while the characters are interesting, the most engaging part of the movie is the setting, which is masterfully done. The set design alone is a work of art. Where Spielberg is normally a master at emotional manipulation, in this case, I feel he falls a little short of his usual genius. For all it's potential drama, it's a very quiet movie about men doing their jobs. Donovan does his job in New York. He goes to Berlin to do another job. He meets men there who are doing their jobs. There's a little intrigue involved in the manipulation of the events, but in the end, it's all very matter-of-fact, and Spielberg seemed to direct it with that same sort of approach. Honestly, had I not known Spielberg was behind this one, I wouldn't have been able to tell it was one of his movies.BRIDGE OF SPIES gets a "Netflix It" on Talon's Movie Scale.

[10/25/15] Steven Spielberg proves once again that he is a master at his craft. His efforts, apart from being some of the most famous and influential, are always easy to appreciate, and "Bridge of Spies" is no exception. I almost made the mistake of not seeing this in theaters; I was supposed to see "The Martian" (and I will at some point later) but I'm glad I got see Spielberg's latest masterpiece. It's damn near flawless, of course, I may be biased when I say that since I'm somewhat fond of the Cold War. As usual, no spoilers. And I'm not going to summarize the plot (I never do anyways). But I will say this, for a movie with scene after scene of dialogue and more dialogue, I was totally into the film. Tom Hanks is, god, he's amazing. I mean, if there were ever a Church of Tom Hanks, you'd find me praying there. All kidding aside, yeah, "Bridge of Spies" is a political thriller that gets done what it needs to get done. There is no filler in this movie, every scene plays a role in getting us to the pivotal point of the film. Spielberg somehow knew what to show us and what to leave out. There is a great, Great scene between Hanks and his character's son in that it represents the fears and concerns of the country (U.S) as a whole. It's not that long but, again, Spielberg knew that all we needed was a short scene. And speaking of Hanks, the first time we're introduced to his character--there is a long take where Hanks talks for about a full minute, uninterrupted, and it was just a great shot. Everything he says in that one take tells us almost everything we need to know about him. Talk about making an entrance. Also worth mentioning is that one of Spielberg's long-time collaborators, composer John Williams, was unable to score the film due to a minor health issue. So, Thomas Newman stepped onto the plate and provided a score that has a touch of Williams while tending to his own style. It's not a detriment or anything like that, but it was something that showed up in various articles when first announced because the Spielberg/Williams train has been rolling without a break since 1985. Interestingly, there's not a whole lot of music to be found here, I mean, the first 20 minutes or so have no music. Overall: "Bridge of Spies" is one of the year's best films and that's really all that needs to be said.

Spielberg, Hanks, Coen Brothers. Rarely have there been so many members of the Hollywood royal family working together on a single motion picture. With this calibre of talent involved the expectations are unsurprisingly sky high; unfortunately this Cold War true story lands in the 'good, but not good enough' category and subsequently feels like a missed opportunity. At first it's difficult to pinpoint why the spark is missing as all the ingredients for an old-school espionage yarn are present, but after careful contemplation it seems to me that Spielberg may be going through the motions. His direction is purposely understated to be sure, although there is a distinct lack of oomph in his narrative propulsion that is strangely un-Spielbergian. There's also never any real sense of Hanks' American attorney being in danger, despite spending large chunks of time in war-torn Berlin liaising with shadowy Russian diplomats and volatile German soldiers. Nevertheless, this thriller predominantly satisfies thanks to another heartfelt performance from main man Hanks. His put upon lawyer is righteous but grounded, intelligent but humble, fearful but optimistic, all with a welcome dash of wit. In fact it's the Brooklyn-set first act that proves the most entertaining, when it's mostly a two-hander between Hanks and Mark Rylance's dryly-humorous Russian spy, the latter damn near stealing the show right from under Hanks' nose. With regular Spielberg collaborator Janusz Kaminski on hand as director of photography, the movie looks utterly spectacular too, the glowing courtrooms of New York just as impressive as the snowy streets of a war-ravaged Germany. Bridge of Spies is a solid Cold War thriller with a compelling protagonist, yet with the Tinseltown heavyweights involved I can't help but think it's also somewhat of a disappointment.

Bridge of Spies is Spielberg's best film in at least a decade, a Classic Hollywood throwback made with distinctive expert craftsmanship. The excellent cast gives great performances across the board, particularly Hanks in the lead (doing his best Jimmy Stewart) and Mark Rylance as the accused Soviet spy he must defend. The script, co-written by Joel and Ethan Coen, shows a surprising degree of their influence mixed with Spielberg's trademarks, resulting in a story that's as surprisingly funny as it is earnestly inspiring. This is a film that can easily be recommended to just about anyone, showcasing one of our biggest (and greatest) directors continuing to work at his A-game.

This film takes longer to get rolling than the average Italian government lasts, but once it gains its momentum, it sustains it beautifully and turns into a beautifully-crafted, extremely satisfying drama.
