Saw Bridge of Spies tonight. Technically flawless, writing, acting, direction; all lush and inviting. I think the way Spielberg tells the story, almost from a perspective of a misty-eyed innocence is the most compelling aspect of the film for me. From the lavish use of diffused, almost dream-like lighting to the film-maker's nods and winks to us like graphically including the audience in circles of conversation and an almost pedantic use of diegesis of both lighting and sound, Spielberg creates a world of spies that almost certainly did not exist in anything other than movies, a world that he captures perfectly in a capsule of rich detail and short, concise phrases that move rapidly along through a time soon to be all but forgotten. Spielberg almost never offers us the taste of the actual poison at the center of the capsule except for a brief pas-de-deux depicting the raw brutality of The Wall, and a man's memory of an event there who's power has diminished with time. I am not sure what the film will mean to me over time, but I suspect that it is another of Spielberg's museum pieces designed to capture forever in one of his magical snow-globes, a gift to those of us that will never truly understand what our fathers and mothers had to go through to give us what we may take for granted from time to time. 9 out of 10 Hankses.

4/5 With any Spielberg film, one can expect impeccable craft in all areas, and Bridge of Spies certainly has that. I can't say, however, that the film measures up to Spielberg's best, or even comes all that close. It's a good film for sure because of the witty screenplay from the Coen brothers, and the craftsmanship makes for an entertaining thriller. But the story is flawed and it lacks the kind of spark you get from Spielberg's best. The film starts out great with a thrilling music-less chase sequence. Mark Rylance as the captured soviet spy, Abel, is excellent, embodying a mysteriously compelling character whose presence dominates the film's first act. Tom Hanks will meet your expectations as the American lawyer hired to defend the soviet spy. The conflict between Tom Hanks and the rest of America as Hanks tries to give Abel a fair, constitutional trial in the first act is very engaging. Not only that, but the film's beginning also features a tension between the quiet and observant Mark Rylance and Tom Hanks that we hope to see develop in the rest of the film. Abel is so mysterious that we naturally want to find out more about his character and watch a relationship between him and Hanks unfold. Unfortunately, the film's second act almost entirely abandons Abel and the initial storyline when Hanks goes overseas to try to swap captured spies with Russia. While still entertaining, the story lost the promise of digging into Abel and has a less compelling story that feels oddly disconnected from the first. Sure, in both Tom Hanks is working for justice, but the difference is that he initially fights for constitutional justice and later just wants to bring home two Americans instead of one by being persistent, a less complex thing to honor. Throughout, the film is kept afloat through the screenplay, the final draft of which was edited by the Coen brothers, and it really shows. I loved the way that humor was woven throughout the film. The dialogue was consistently witty, and the jokes were surprisingly funny. Had the dialogue not been so fun, the film may have been boring, but thankfully it never was. It's also great that we have Tom Hanks in the lead because he nails the comedy. As usual, Janusz Kaminski and Spielberg create splendid visuals with full compositions and lots of backlighting (some of which felt excessive and purposeless). The art direction and music everything was great, but none of it felt used in an original way, or a way that hasn't been done better in Spielberg films before. Abel comes back in the end of the film, but it's hard not to feel that we didn't know him as much as we could have. It's also hard to pinpoint exactly what about Hanks' character we should celebrate. It's clear that he's a hero, but there are two different things that he does that are heroic and they don't connect that well. You'll leave the film with an approving eyebrow raise followed by a shrug. It's not a particularly heartfelt film and doesn't have much Spielberg magic, but it's definitely good, and that doesn't quite cut it for Spielberg. Hopefully The BFG will be more magical.

Bridge of Spies is quite simply a masterpiece. I suppose a movie directed by Steven Spielberg, starring Tom Hanks and written by the Coen brothers was always going to be masterfully crafted but this goes well beyond that. It literally reeks of authenticity and tells an extremely complex story in a very simple way. Mark Rylance, so brilliant as Thomas Cromwell in BBC mini-series Wolf Hall, steals the picture in my opinion as soviet spy Rudolf Abel and the scenes of an about to be split-down-the-middle Berlin are almost newsreel like in their realism. If you are only going to see one movie this year I urge you to see this one because you will see nothing better.

An old-school spy thriller from Steven Spielberg where he employs his skills at building tension? Sign me up. Bridge of Spies won't exactly win over the Transformers crowd, but it's a potent historical drama crafted by experts. Start with director Steven Spielberg and star Tom Hanks, working from a script by Matt Charman that was polished by no less than the Coen brothers. The subject is the pivotal moment in the Cold War when an American U-2 spy plane was shot down over the Soviet Union in 1960 and the U.S. had to negotiate the release of its captured pilot, Francis Gary Powers (Austin Stowell). The only way to do it, according to lawyer James B. Donovan (Hanks), is to exchange Powers for Col. Rudolf Abel (the terrific Mark Rylance), a British-born Russian spy working undercover in Brooklyn until he's caught by the FBI and jailed on conspiracy charges in 1957. His capture, excitingly staged by Spielberg, begins the movie on a high note.Then things get a bit harder to sell. Start with the insistent score by Thomas Newman in for Spielberg regular John Williams. Even the trailer does the film a disservice ('In the shadow of war, one man showed the world what we stand for.')That one man is Hanks, an actor with infinite gifts for understatement (just check Spielberg's own Saving Private Ryan). So really that rah-rah and trumpets are highly unnecessary. Donovan works as an insurance lawyer with a wife (Amy Ryan) and children. When his boss (Alan Alda) volunteers him to represent Abel, Donovan is suddenly reviled as the man trying to free a traitor. Hanks expresses Donovan's quiet heroism with amazing restraint. The script does him no favors by pushing for more cheer, with Abel dubbing him 'the standing man' who gets back up to do right when knocked down.Bridge of Spies is best when it steps more into the gray areas, such when Donovan sees Abel and Powers as patriots simply doing the bidding of their respective countries. It resonates best when Spielberg delivers on action that defines character, as in Donovan's Berlin trip where he's nearly killed as a result of conspiracies. During the climactic prisoner exchange on the Glienicke Bridge there are moments when we cannot tell good from bad, and the cliches of spy movies suddenly become potent and provocative.

When you team up the Cohen brothers as writers with the masterful storyteller and director Steven Spielberg, you expect to get something special. And BRIDGE OF SPIES is just that - something special. It's the true story of James B Donovan (Tom Hanks), a lawyer with no criminal trial experience, who is asked by the US government to defend a Russian spy, Rudolf Abel (played by Mark Rylance). It's a great story of a great man who served his country with integrity, despite the personal costs to himself. It's gratifying to see a true hero on screen in contrast to all the fantasy heroes we are used to seeing of late. The pace of the movie is subdued, but it is engaging and finishes with us on the edge of our seats. The cinematography is excellent and portrays the Cold War period well along with the story that breathes new life into this genre. Hanks is excellent in the starring role and all supporting cast are good. A solid spy drama that tells an important story. Go see it!

Bridge of Spies is a Cold War thriller that is as subtle and understated as most of its characters. The narrative tells the little known backstory of Soviet KGB spy Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance) and his defense by American lawyer James B. Donovan (Tom Hanks) against the wishes of an unforgiving public mood. Later, we see Donovan in East Berlin successfully negotiating his exchange with captured U2 pilot Gary Powers and an American student imprisoned by the East German Stasi. Bridge has fairly average direction and Tom Hanks largely plays himself as is his habit, but then again that's the advantage of being a national treasure. Spielberg and Hanks can give in rather perfunctory work and it will stand out above many others simply by default. I'd argue that Mark Rylance is the true gem of the picture and his simple, quotable dialogue, weary but observant expressions, and stoic demeanor make him the most memorable element. That and it features a fairly strong script written by the Coen Brothers. In summation, Bridge of Spies fails to reinvent the genre but it didn't need to - it tells a story more Americans and Russians need to learn and it tells it well.

Spielberg delivers again with the excellent Cold War thriller, BRIDGE OF SPIES. The direction and performances make BRIDGE OF SPIES another Hanks/Spielberg success. Hanks's turn as Jim Donovan, insurance-lawyer-turned-prisoner-negotiator, was truly riveting to watch. Hanks once again shows why he is the most likable actor in the business by showing the motivation and courage to do what he believes to be right, while also adding wit and charm to help the audience relate to the character. Hanks displays one the best performances of his career. The biggest suprise in the film was the performance by Mark Rylance. As good as Hank's performance was, in my opinion, Rylance stole almost every scene he was in. Rylance portrayed accused Soviet spy, Rudolf Abel, with such heart-warming emotion and charm that he made the audience feel sympathetic for a SOVIET SPY during the Cold War. While the story is gripping, I left the theater wanting a little bit more. I guess I expected a Spielberg directed, Coen Brothers written, and Hanks starring movie to blow my expectations. I feel that the strongest parts of the film were when it was focused on the trial and defense of Abel, but this only lasted for the first 40 minutes. It felt like there wasn't enough in the movie to make me fear for Donovan and his family in America. Overall, BRIDGE OF SPIES is an excellent film that is defined by its wonderful direction and performances. Spielberg and Hanks do not disappoint and create yet another success. (3.9/5)

Spielberg and Hanks have done some great work over the years, and this fact-based spy thriller is no different. There is nothing flashy about its story or characters, but with Spielberg behind the camera and Hanks giving one of his best performances of his career, the movie is compelling drama at its best. Extra kudos to Mark Rylance as the imprisoned spy. Both he and Hanks give Oscar-worthy performances. Grade: A-

There are a lot of good things with Spielberg's latest which, technically speaking, might be his most accomplished film since Minority Report. That's why it saddens me to observe that Bridge of Spies is, nonetheless, hypocritical and patriotic entertainment that never really enlightens or lives up to the message it tries to uphold. Skating in the thinness of its message - which intends to be of duality and reasonable thought-process-, the movie is quick to remind Americans of the constitution and even quicker to showcase Russians and East Berliners as evil figures and a threat to the American way of life. Considering the potential depth and impact of such story to the unification of beliefs, Bridge of Spies feels like a missed opportunity.

T. HANKS FOR THE MEMORIES - My Review of BRIDGE OF SPIES (4 1/2 Stars)Due to poor marketing, a generic poster and forgettable title, I initially had no interest in seeing BRIDGE OF SPIES. It reeked of sup-bar Tom Clancy with dime store espionage. Little did I know it was based on a remarkably true Cold War story about an ordinary lawyer who brokered a hostage deal with the Soviets and East Germans. Additionally, when I discovered the Coen Brothers did a polish on the script, my interest was piqued just a little. Now that I've seen it, I can say it's one of Steven Spielberg's greatest accomplishments, a quietly suspenseful, beautifully acted and shot, twisting, turning yarn with quirky, specific characters and acute relevancy to current international politics. Tom Hanks, in full Jimmy Stewart Everyman mode and knocking it out of the park, plays James B. Donovan, an insurance attorney who is quietly asked by the Feds to perfunctorily represent a Soviet spy they've captured. The film opens on said spy, Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance, giving an Oscar caliber performance) as he paints a self-portrait. It's a terrific opening shot, loaded with a wry sense of humor and multiple angles on the man to convey the layers to his character. There's no doubt from the outset that he is indeed a Russian spy, but it's the richness that follows which surprises. Soon, agents are pursuing him through the New York subway system in a bravura sequence of mounting tension, disorientation and stellar sound design. When Spielberg and his longtime collaborator, cinematographer Janusz Kaminski, become engaged with material as rich as this, it's a pleasure to watch. Once captured, Donovan is asked to give the appearance of caring just enough so that the American Justice System looks good, but not enough to prevent Abel from the electric chair. Donovan, however, has more compassion than they expected. What follows is a story which stresses the importance of maintaining who we are or would love to be as a country by how we treat our prisoners. It's so easy in times of terrorism to go the way of Guantanamo Bay and torture our captives, but perhaps more important to maintain our ideals of justice rather than surrender to barbarism. Ultimately, the story involves a more well-known hostage, Gary Powers (Austin Stowell), an American pilot commissioned by the CIA to spy on Russia. His capture provides another thrilling sequence, this one in mid-air. Without spoiling too much, Donovan travels to East Berlin to quietly swap hostages without any official U.S. backing. Complicating matters is the fact that another American is captures by the East Germans just as the Berlin Wall is being erected.It's in the passage that I saw something new, and clearly Spielberg is all in as we witness the wall going up brick by brick as desperate people attempt to escape the oncoming horrors of life in the other side of that border. It's stunning and told with such assuredness and clarity. Another unexpected bonus is the humor in this film. Matt Charman, along with the Coens, keeps each character grounded in reality and adds such wonderful touches as Abel's cousin joyfully coming to beg for his release, Donovan's nagging cold throughout, and Abel's fantastically dry response of "Would it help?" whenever Donovan asks him to present himself a certain way. The relationship between Donovan and Abel is the heart of this film, and both actors rise to the occasion. Abel is deceptively still and on-the-surface, an enigma. Rylance, however, brings such quiet heart to Abel, that it's easy to see this potentially dangerous spy as just a man serving his country. This is a no-brainer supporting actor Oscar nominee if there ever was one, and deservedly so. Amy Ryan as Donovan's wife is straddled with the "meanwhile back in the States scenes" but she meshes really well with Hanks, giving such a vivid portrait of a late 50s/early 60s housewife on the verge of asserting herself more and more. The film is not without its flaws. Clearly scenes were cut between Donovan's assistant and daughter, whose secret affair must have meant something to a story about sneaking around, but obvious not enough to matter. There's enough there to leave one hanging, perhaps because their scenes carry a lot of the early exposition of the story. Also, even Spielberg at his best can turn syrupy and obvious at the end of his films, and this is no exception. SCHINDLER'S LIST, which I consider a masterpiece, suffered from Liam Neeson's breakdown scene. Here, we get a way-too-obvious comparison between the lives of wall-hopping East Germans and free Americans. It's not enough to derail the exceptional film that precedes it, and Spielberg and Co. are wise enough to provide a crawl of what happened to each character over this scene....so the on-the-nose nature of it is slightly diffused...a minor step in this nostalgic, uplifting, classically told, perfectly written film.

'Bridge of Spies' is an espionage thriller at its finest. It's set in the late 50s & early 60s and certainly looks the part - I always love seeing the old cars driving around New York, looking classy. Starts off like any classic spy film, but then Abel (Rylance) is caught. In comes Donovan (Hanks), an insurance lawyer who is asked to defend Abel, so he can receive due legal practice. The first 45min or so is a good courtroom drama and moves along fast enough, with Hanks giving a few great speeches and making some solid points about what's right and what's best.The movie really captures well the Cold War tension in America and what families would've gone through. It helps that this is the best film Spielberg has made in a few years and the best film Hanks has been in for a while. Once the movie turns into political chess, with an exchange of Abel for Powers (Stowell) in Berlin, the stakes are raised and there's plenty of great subterfuge.Hanks basically owns the film, with everyone having some good moments (especially Rylance, with his "would it help?"s), but he really plays a great everyman who stands up to both Germany, Russia & his own country (mostly portrayed by the CIA/Shepherd) for what is morally right and just, not just what is politically acceptable at the current time.

I think the fact that simply adding: The Coen Brothers + Steven Spielberg + Tom Hanks, into a film = An amazing opportunity for an AMAZING FILM overall. Yep, once again do these veterans of Hollywood give us some new life into the Cold War espionage and make it so gosh darn enjoyable to relate to (from basically every aspect it can represent.) Essentially from the films: FANTASTIC opening scene that adds no dialogue, Oscar worthy performance from Tom Hanks, beautiful cinematography and sets that use great attention to detail, well made and (of course) funny writing from my favorite duo: The Coen Brothers, and overall is definitely worth seeing for its veteran writers, admirable director, and everyone's favorite actor that make it enjoyable to watch from start to finish (even if the pacing does tend to drag from time to time.) Definitely worthy of Oscar nomination from any of these people.

"Bridge of Spies" is a fascinating behind-the-scenes walk into the Cold War era. This is not the Fabulous Fifties of "American Bandstand". It's behind-the-scenes political maneuvers involving Russia, Germany and the United States. While young Baby Boomers hid beneath school desks during air raids, the real intrigue was far more subtle. Spies didn't drink martinis and wear black tie...they wore glasses. created oil paintings and listened to classical music.Thanks to masterful direction from Steven Spielberg, stunning cinematography by Janusz Kaminski, and the writing of the Cohen Brothers and Mat Charman, "Bridge of Spies" embodies a 1950s' attorney and family man portrayed by Tom Hanks. High-level international intrigue unfolds amid mundane bureaucracies.Yet Hanks' insurance lawyer maintains an unflinching desire to do the right thing, even when it's hard to know the difference in a gray, cold world as frigid as its politics. Mark Rylance gives a solid, nuanced performance as the spy caught between countries. He is torn by his art, his wife, and political loyalties. The friendship that evolves between Hank's attorney Jim Donovan and Rylance's Rudolph Abel serves as a metaphor for the confusion and fear that Americans and Russians must have experienced during the Cold War era. That's the funny thing about common ground. It does bring clarity...even in the cold. Oscar nominations are likely for Actor, Director, Cinematography and possibly Best Supporting Actor.

It's an interesting turn of events that I would see "Sicario" (2015), a movie for which I had no expectations, a week before seeing Steven Spielberg's historically based "Bridge of Spies," a movie for which I had plenty.Indeed, anyone going into the film after seeing the trailers could reasonably expect a well-acted, well-directed, humanistic period piece with some gorgeous sets - and "Bridge of Spies" is pretty much exactly that.Classic Hollywood good guy Tom Hanks plays good guy James B. Donovan, a lawyer tasked with defending Rudolf Ivanovich Abel (Mark Rylance), a Soviet intelligence officer with the KGB. Abel has been recently arrested and is to be tried for espionage.While many around Donovan (read: his family, coworkers, the CIA, and pretty much everyone else) pity him his thankless task of defending an enemy of the state, their opinion begins to shift as - what do you know? - he actually tries to do his job and get Abel a fair trial.An unknown amount of time later, the Soviets capture a downed U-2 spy plane pilot in Russian territory. Donovan is asked once more to step in to negotiate a prisoner swap in East Berlin: Abel for the pilot, one Francis Gary Powers (Austin Stowell).It's easy to see one of this movie's problems early on, as the first half or so is positively lethargic. We already know what will happen in Abel's trial, but we still have to sit through it to see lawyer Tom Hanks - er, Donovan - go to East Germany.This is true aside from the opening scene that tracks Abel as he paints, answers a phone, picks up a secret nickel, paints some more, and is ultimately captured by the CIA. As we follow Abel through the subway, the camera glides back and forth between him and the CIA agents in hot pursuit, and we're treated to probably the tensest scene in the film.With this opening scene, we also get to see relative-unknown actor Mark Rylance at work. Acting opposite Tom Hanks for any amount of time can't be easy, but Rylance pulls it off throughout in superb style, making a man who's supposed to be the enemy rather sympathetic and normal.That, I think, is the biggest achievement between Rylance, Spielberg, and the Coen brothers, who wrote the film alongside Matt Charman - humanizing the enemy and making it clear that things weren't always simple as "good vs. evil."But despite a message that said things aren't always simple, the plot was very straightforward. Events unfolded in a logical manner, with nothing getting too twisted up or surprising, and viewers can feel pretty good about the ending.What may come as a surprise is the film's humor, which actually shows up more often than you might think. While laughs aren't usually a problem (and can be necessary in heavier films), it's hard to see their purpose in "Bridge of Spies," which already carries so little tension."Bridge of Spies" also takes a few turns for the heavy-handed, such as when it cuts to a class of young students being shown a nuclear scare film (and tearing up for some reason), or when, from his train window, Donovan sees a delayed parallel between the Berlin Wall and children jumping a fence in Brooklyn.The film's aesthetics, though, are very solid, which is something of the norm for period pieces. The vibrant, bustling streets of Brooklyn and the derelict, crumbling buildings of East Berlin provide the movie's starkest contrast between the powers of the Cold War, and Thomas Newman's subdued score is a suitable backdrop.Overall, "Bridge of Spies" is good. The harshest critique I can level at the film is that it's fairly unspectacular, but that doesn't make it bad; indeed, its solid performances, direction, and general prettiness leave me wondering how anyone could thoroughly dislike it, even if they're not blown away.Like my reviews? Have a disagreement? Give me a shout on Twitter at @MovieMuseSean.

VIEWS ON FILM review by Jesse BurlesonSpielberg and Hanks. Hanks and Spielberg. Their collaborations have become legend. You've got 1998's Saving Private Ryan which I never went gaga over. Then there's The Terminal, not an awful film just meh. Finally, we have Catch Me If You Can, the duo's entertaining masterpiece (this is just my opinion). Bridge of Spies (my latest review) is the current synergy between these two celebrated, Hollywood giants. It's cinematic hot chocolate recommendable because of historical significance. "Bridge" with its darkly-lit scenes and bloated two hour-plus running time, falls into Steven's two categories of movies being hyperactive, action adventures and historical sagas. It hightails into the latter meaning it's talky, draggy, and mostly devoid of anything compelling. I felt as if I was watching Lincoln again minus the circa range of 1865. Translation: No second viewing for this camper.Taking place during the Cold War via 1957, featuring a cast of virtual unknowns (a Spielberg emblem), and written by none other than the Cohen brothers (Ethan and Joel Cohen of course), Bridge of Spies chronicles real-life insurance lawyer, James B. Donovan (Hanks). He's a family man, a dude bent on doing the right thing. When he gets saddled with defending a Russian spy (Rudolf Abel played uniquely by Mark Rylance), Donovan helps said spy avoid the death penalty while attempting to trade him for two American refugees (a fighter pilot and a graduate student who are both detained by way of espionage). The flick then involves globetrotting within the territories of Germany, Russia, and you guessed it, Brooklyn, New York. Scenes build to a slow creep combining negotiation dialogue that spews mannerisms at verbatim (Tom's James B. has the flu, we get it). I sensed that I'd been in the theater for ten hours and sat through three drawn-out endings (the final sequence is reminiscent of 1985's White Nights. It looks like a soundstage which is uncharacteristic of the mighty Steven Spielberg).In retrospect, the acting (as expected) is solid with Tom Hanks being well, Tom Hanks. We all know he's the quintessential everyman. Will he get a nomination from the Academy? Maybe but this is October so there's sixty days left in the fiscal year. Bottom line: The World's most socko director provides us with admirable storytelling, technical skill, and period detail of the highest order. Does he entertain the moviegoer in the process? Not entirely. Be sure to bring heightened intelligence and an attention span (the size of Texas) to actually feel immersed. This is a "bridge" too far if you ask me. Rating: 3 stars.

Bridge of Spies is Steven Spielberg's latest film, based on true stories of spy-swap negotiations during the Cold War. The story is intriguing and with Spielberg directing, the Coen Brothers co-writing the script and Tom Hanks starring in the lead role, this looks like one of the most exciting film projects in recent memory. Spielberg's filmography is fascinating; he is mostly known for his Hollywood blockbusters, but every now and then, he tackles a more serious subject in his direction. For every Indiana Jones, Jaws and Jurassic Park, we get Schindler's List, Munich and Lincoln. This is an admirable and diverse choice of direction by one of the most reliable film directors with a solid resume. This latest film, is full of his unique touches and while it will not be regarded as one of his best, it is certainly a solid and watchable piece of cinema.The story opens in Brooklyn, N.Y. during the late 1950s with the arrest by American authorities of suspected Soviet agent Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance). Concerned that the man receives top-notch representation, the government approaches attorney James Donovan (Tom Hanks) to defend Abel. Although initially reluctant, Donovan warms to the idea after meeting his would-be client. Although unable to secure a "Not Guilty" verdict, Donovan's arguments spare Abel the death penalty. However, his vociferous defense of such an anti-American criminal earns Donovan the ire of his fellow citizens. In a parallel storyline, the film introduces CIA pilot Gary Powers (Austin Stowell), who commands a US spy plane on a mission high over Soviet territory. He is given strict instructions that, if the aircraft is compromised and in danger of falling into enemy hands, he is to hit the self-destruct. He is also given orders about the conditions under which he is to end his own life. He fails in both regards and is captured by the Soviets. The CIA, concerned about the top secret information Powers might divulge, asks Donovan to broker a prisoner exchange: Powers for Abel. This requires the lawyer, who is sick with a cold, to travel to Berlin and meet with KGB and East German officials in circumstances that could best be described as precarious.The film doesn't waste any time and starts the main plot right away. This is a film with little to no action and is full of scenes with people talking, but it is never boring. Spielberg's direction mixed with fantastic performances from a solid cast keeps our interest throughout its somewhat long running time. Part of our interest grows from the period, when security is an obsessive concern. In the U.S. and the Soviet Union alike, an accelerating arms race has bred a not-unreasonable fear of nuclear war. Washington wants to give Abel, an enemy agent, the semblance of a fair trial, though only the semblance, and the judge in the case agrees: "He'll receive due process and, God willing, he'll be convicted." But Donovan believes that a fair trial means the best defense he can provide for his despised client. The film is shot well (with plenty of Spielbergian touches) and thoroughly American. One reason why Spielberg's dramas are such crown pleasures is that he never addresses the current events, preferring instead to mine the past. Sure, it is a politically safe approach, but it also makes his films more universal and timeless. He also never shies away from sentimentality and subtlety is something that can rarely be found in his direction. That is probably the biggest flaw in Bridge of Spies, which makes the whole experience feel safe and by the numbers. It still works for sure, but a riskier take and a less sentimental ending could have made the film stronger.The performances are fantastic across the board. Tom Hanks is great as always in the lead role, playing the paragon with stirring conviction leavened by enjoyable zest. His negotiation scenes are so entertaining and his deliveries are so spot on that we as the audience never get tired of the story getting unfolded. Amy Smart (as Donovan's wife) and Sebastian Koch (as the East German lawyer who becomes involved in the negotiations) provide solid support. But the real standout is Mark Rylance whose turn as the meek, composed Abel compels the viewer's attention. His performance is a minimalist wonder and he manages to steal scenes from Hanks and everyone else. His character is a principled man with a philosophical spirit that manages to create some of the film's best moments. The story is straightforward and easy to follow with small moments of quirkiness often associated with the Coens. Their off-killer sense of humor comes across in some of Hanks' lines, but the finished project seems to lean more towards Matt Charman's involvement in penning the script.All in all, Bridge of Spies is yet another win for Spielberg, Hanks and everyone involved who seem to be at the top of their game. This is a movie that fans of good cinema and general movie going audience members can easily enjoy equally. Yes, it is a safely made by the numbers movie with plenty of over-sentimentality, but it works and never talks down to its audience and that's what ultimately matters. It might not become a memorable experience, but it surely is a worth-while one.

I thought Bridge of Spies is good, but not great. It has solid dialogue, good characters, and a fascinatingly absorbing story, but it doesn't do much else. Bridge of spies is an emotional, plot heavy movie that manages to build lots of tension despite taking place over 65 years ago and having but a few, albeit effective, action sequences. Tom Hanks turns in a good performance as the well-intentioned insurance attorney turned defense attorney/ negotiator James Donovan, but it is Mark Rylance who steals the show as Rudolf Abel, the extremely calm and even-keeled yet captivating captured Soviet spy who lies at the center of the films plot. Overall, the historical basis for this film and the strong acting and cinematography achieve the movies intended goal of focusing on the unity of individuals in difficult situations, rather than the political divisions brought about by the Cold War.

Another solid Steven Spielberg drama with his golden boy Tom Hanks. Bridge of Spies is about the true story of a lawyer named Jim Donovan (Hanks) who in 1957 is tasked with representing a Soviet spy named Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance). Abel is caught in the U.S. under suspicions of spying for the Soviets and Jim is chosen by his firm to represent Abel. It's suppose to be a one and done deal with Jim at least showing that the U.S. used Due Process and gave Abel a chance. Things go South and soon enough Jim has himself questioning whats wrong and whats right regardless of being a US Citizen. Meanwhile a spy plane is shot over Russia and U.S. Pilot Francis Gary Powers (Austin Stowell) is captured by the Soviets. Also during this time period U.S. student Frederic Pryor (Will Rogers) is taken into custody by the German Republic for suspicion of spying. The CIA takes charge and tasks Jim to secretly go into East Berlin and negotiate a trade between Powers and possibly Pryor for Abel. What unfolds is a mind game between Jim, the KGB and the German Republic. Overall, it's an entertaining movie if and only if the subject matter seems interesting to you. History buffs and war enthusiasts will appreciate the accuracy of the story. The movie is a slow paced thriller and drama. Its 2 and a half hours long and at times it feels like its been going on. Hanks is solid though and has a fantastic performance here. The movie itself I would say isn't a "you have to see this while it's still in theaters!" kinda film I would say it would be a nice Friday night rental! Overall, i enjoyed it, but like I said it won't be for everyone!

A very good story, well told. A bit on the slow side, but still better than I expected. A bit more action would have given this a 4 star rating. Also surprised they snuck in 2 F bomb's for a PG-13 rating, I thought the limit was 1.

This is a well-done thriller with decent acting by Tom Hanks, (now blatantly channelling Jimmy Stewart). Yet compared to past thrillers such as Munich, this feels very lite and could've used a little more political relevance considering the revived Cold War tensions occurring in the world climate today.

Good news - a good movie. Hanks came through despite his facial posturing for too many scenes. He was solid and human. Fine direction by Spielberg. Perhaps the two biggest stars however were Mark Rylance and Amy Ryan. Rylance deserves to be mentioned for an award - his performance was air-tight. Ryan was a surprising presence who made the very most of her time. This film is worth seeing.

The fourth collaboration between Spielberg and Hanks is another surefire winner and a joy to watch the two masters at work together again. Sure, it could have been tightened up a little, but it's so well told and a nice Hollywood throwback it's easy to overlook. It's Spielberg's strongest work since 2005's Munich, and features a breakthrough screen performance from Mark Rylance as well.

Sometimes you have to make a decision between what is right and what is easy... Tom Hanks portrays a lawyer, caught up in the mania of the Cold War fear and could've easily rolled over to the whims of every legal wall he came up against. No one wanted him to win, no one wanted him to fight and yet, he did. Harder than he even thought himself capable of for this Russian Spy. In the end, it wasn't a grandiose war movie with high powered action sequences or overdone battle scenes that made this one of the greats... it was the humanity. One man, standing alone, trying to do what he felt was right and damn what the authorities said should be done. Tom Hanks really can't do a bad movie, but the fanfare for this movie lives up to any and all hype that is given.
Powerful cold war drama with thrilled and classy acting form Hanks and Rylance. Spielberg's best since SAVING PRIVATE RYAN

Lets see. A film directed by Spielberg, who is my all time favorite director, starring Tom Hanks, my all time favorite actor, with a screenplay written by the Coen brothers. This is a no brainer, I'm totally in, and in the end, I frekin love it.

Excellent movie. Another story based on true events, but it feels true in every aspect. Tom Hanks was at the top of his game. All the actors around him were solid. The guy playing the Russian spy was especially interesting and well-written. Full of nice script writing and small details making the people seem real. Was afraid that Hollyweird politics couldn't stop themselves from rewriting history, but the wasn't a whiff of revisionist history here. A brilliantly written, directed, and acted film. Executed incredibly. So much meaning and symbolism behind every moment in the film. It wasn't just a great story, but it was also really fun to watch. Spielberg also deals with the obvious elements of politics, humanity, etc., but also has a beautiful perspective to show us on the different cultures depicted in this movie. A pretty much perfect example of superior craftsmanship in all departments.

Bridge of Spies is one of the best films of the year. It is grand and successful at all levels. Once again, Spielberg offers us a delightful and inspiring human story.

"Bridge of Spies" is an espionage thriller starring Tom Hanks as an insurance lawyer who is commissioned by the CIA to defend an accused Soviet Spy. In a subsequent deal he is asked to unofficially negotiate a trade with the Soviet Union for two Americans being detained as suspected spies themselves. I thought this film authentically captured the atmosphere of the Cold War and all the paranoia associated with it. Tom Hanks also does fine work and may be headed for another Oscar nomination. Spielbergs direction is spectacular as well as the genuine set pieces, making this a legitimate period piece. The cinematography is also exemplary ------------------------------------------ A-

This movie had the type of screenplay that American Hustle should have had...here you have a story with a WHOLE lot going on, lots of characters, and plot points, which could easily/understandably get the viewer lost. But where this movie succeeds and American Hustle didn't (IMHO), is that you have incredible screenwriting and editing teams who crafted the story so well that the audience is able to easily follow along and also remains invested and drawn into the story. Also great directing, acting, and a solid score.

A quick quiz to exercise your vision on patriotism and betrayal: let's say there's this RAW agent who is embedded in Pakistan, carrying out espionage on India's behalf. Completely dedicated to our country's cause, he's a thorough gentleman in every sense, a well-behaved citizen in Pakistan, but stealing information from there to pass on to our agents here. Would you call him a patriot? Hang on to that answer. Now, imagine his counterpart from Pakistan, operating in India, following the same decorum and dignity, and completely true to his country's cause. Would he meet your rigorous specifications of a patriot? Another sub-question - imagine both these agents get caught while carrying out service to their respective countries. How would you want Pakistan to deal with our RAW agent? And how would you want the agent from Pakistan to be handled? Would you wear the same lens for both situations? Or, is it myopia in one eye and hypermetropia in the other?This is the blurring dilemma that director Steven Spielberg handles in his latest venture from behind the lens, "Bridge Of Spies". Based on the amazing true story of James B. Donovan (played by Tom Hanks) in 1957, and written by Matt Charman and the Coen brothers (Ethan and Joel), this is fine drama, handled with dignified maturity and finesse by the director and his band of high-class writers. Donovan is a successful insurance lawyer, a partner in a top insurance litigation firm. He's roped in to represent Rudolph Abel (Mark Rylance), a Russian spy operating in Brooklyn, to show the world that the United States gives a fair trial and chance to one and all, and to ensure that the USSR does not capitalize on this incident. Donovan, initially hesitant, is egged on by the senior partner in his firm, Thomas Watters Jr. (Alan Alda), to take on the case for the country's sake. Donovan plunges into the case in right earnest, meeting up with Abel, getting to know him, and even going to the judge for a mistrial because there wasn't a proper arrest warrant. As the case progresses, the American public, the judge, Donovan's wife, Mary (Amy Ryan), his children, partners, and the folks on the subway he travels on, all look at him in askance, at best questioning his trenchant pursuit for justice, at worst attacking his home and accusing him of betrayal.In tandem unfolds the story of pilot Francis Gary Powers (Austin Stowell), who's one of four pilots picked for a secret mission to fly the U-2 aircraft from the American airbase in Islamabad over Russian skies, and take photographs. As luck and true story would have it, his plane is shot down, he's captured, and taken in for interrogation by the Russians. This sets in motion a mission kicked off by the CIA to exchange Abel and Powers, and Donovan is asked if he'd carry out the negotiations with the Russians. Donovan agrees, but the talks must take place in East Berlin (the wall is being built as the story progresses). Add to this mix some mysterious messages from Abel's family, the arrest of American student Frederic Pryor (Will Rogers) in East Berlin, and Donovan's insistence on getting back both Powers and Pryor for handing over Abel, and what you have a miasma of drama and engaging storytelling that keeps you hooked till the last frame.Director Spielberg is in fine form, capturing the gloom and gloam of Brooklyn and Germany, even as he nuances out beautiful scenes in the movie. He bathes the movie with gentle humor and underplayed drama, even as he moves it along at a pace that's steady, firm, and gripping, shorn of any bathetic pretensions or jingoism. The film is nicely atmospheric, and Spielberg is helped by his keen and able editor Michael Kahn, who is in superb form as he places the Abel and Powers track side-by-side, beautifully seguing from one to the other in the most unaffected way. Note the scene where the judge comes into the courtroom and the bailiff announces "All rise", and Kahn and Spielberg show you children getting up in their classroom. This is classy stuff. Spielberg also makes the exchange scene an unforgettable one. This is the most humorous and moving exchange scenes I have ever seen. It makes you smile, laugh in relief, and fight back tears, all at the same time."Bridge of Spies" has a commendable star cast, right from the officer who arrests Abel in the beginning, Agent Blasco, played by the superb Domenick Lombardozzi (from the fantastic TV show, "The Wire"). Amy Ryan as Donovan's wife is quietly effective, not aiming to bamboozle, but conveying her worry and angst beautifully. And it is such an effusive pleasure to watch Alan Alda, as always. In the few scenes he is up there, he's smooth as single malt, happy to be supportive and critical of Donovan, as required. Dakin Mathews as Judge Byers is superb, stupefied by Donovan's persistence, and then delivering a judgment that makes the exchange possible at all.But the movie belongs to Tom Hanks and Mark Rylance. They complement each other brilliantly, playing off each other in scenes with dialogues that are gentle word plays, yet agile and nimble footed, meaningful, yet humorous. As Donovan, Tom Hanks nails it deep and proper. He's superb, a submarine of assertiveness, while showing a calm and almost fastidious surface. His is a performance that comes along and simply guides you by the hand into beautiful cinema. As in the scene where he realizes he's being followed one rainy night; or the scene where his house is attacked; or when he tries to explain to his son why defending Abel isn't the wrong thing; his horror at the murders on the Berlin wall, and the beautiful moving end scene on the subway train. Tom Hanks makes you want shake his hand and say, "Well done, Donovan!" , even as you're worried you'll catch his cold and sniffles.Mark Rylance is equally brilliant as the reticent, eyebrows-raised, poker-faced, soft-spoken Russian spy. He's so good, your heart goes out to him, as does Donovan's. Rylance conveys his story and his expressions softly, with a beautiful feather-like touch that moves you, makes you laugh, and go along with him for the exchange. There's this beautiful scene between Hanks and Rylance in the jail, when the latter's telling a story of his childhood, and talks of a man who he came to call "The standing man." That scene is so well directed and acted, it goes from humor to a gentle-tug-at-your-heart in a twirl.And there's the background score by Thomas Newman that's as good as the lead actors. Newman rustles up his orchestra 20 minutes into the movie, and that's for the scene where Hanks is being followed. That's some beautiful horns, the piano tinkling like raindrops, and the violins halting and faltering, like Hanks himself. Also the "Standing Man" theme in the aforementioned scene in the jail - when the violins glide in gently into the scene, they bring with them a gentle gush of emotions that you simply flow into, such a beautiful piece that is. Then, there's the negotiation scene between the Russian official and Hanks. Thomas Newman ushers in male chorals that are haunting, unnerving, and make you shiver at the hostile environs you find Donovan in. Equally moving is the music for the climactic exchange, as Newman gets you engaged and into it. Or the beautiful violins and horns for the homecoming scene, the piano so lovely and gracefully moving with the violins.As the credits roll, and Spielberg superbly rings out a comparison between the Berlin wall horror and schoolkids in the US jumping over a wall, playing, you know there's much that humanity has suffered in wars, cold or otherwise. And having the freedom for kids to play out in the open is just one of the privileges that you cannot and should not take for granted. It's a gift that you don't realize you're lucky to have even as wars continue to ravage countries, and you look for an exchange program in this madness that'll bring back a semblance of humane behavior. A tall order that, even for Donovan.

Bridge of Spies is a flat, anemic telling of the Gary Powers spy swap of the early 60's. The narrative has few dramatic points, and relies too much on Spielberg's rose-colored historical gaze, from dining room scenes to ridiculous over-the-head symbolic moments. No time is given to the political issues that surrounded the development of the U-2 spy plane program, and little is learned about "Rudolf Abel," the Soviet spy in the swap. The negotiations have little dramatic substance; apart from Power's plane being hit, there is almost no dynamic range to this film, save some witty quips offered by the Coen brothers. A sleepy, thin story that would better serve as a tv movie.
Bridge of Spzzzzzzzzzzzzz. A Cold War that Tom Hanks channeling Jimmy Stewart can thaw is a Cold War drained of suspense.
Overall OK, a bit slow moving and with little payoff. Hanks is definitely the best part of the movie - still at the top of his game.

It could have been better and more daring, but overall it's a great movie with a poignant commentary. Hanks basically plays himself, which is somewhat distracting, though he is able to effectively get your sympathy and make the jokes it has hit. There's no real suspense though, given how high the stakes were and how the scenario kind of demands it.
