I don't know what it is about 2015, but I think this year has been full of films that don't entirely meet your expectations. I don't necessarily mean that those films are bad by any stretch of the imagination, but it seems like film after film end up making me feel a bit letdown. Bridge of Spies is the new Steven Spielberg directed film based on true events during the cold war. It focuses on James B. Donovan, played by Tom Hanks, who is thrust into representing a supposed Soviet spy in court and Donovan's further involvement in executing an exchange of prisoners with Russia.Much like Crimson Peak, this film is not really what the trailers make it out to be. The trailers heavily focused on the relationship between Donovan and his client, Rudolf Abel. The film gives us maybe 20 minutes between them in the beginning, but really that's all. To me, their relationship and the scenes between Hanks and Mark Rylance, who plays Abel, are easily the best the film has to offer. Even though it's never truly clear as to why Donovan backs this man so much and his motivations behind continuing the negotiations, I really bought into their dynamic. In fact, it's the only true payoff you get in the end is their relationship and its outcome.By no means is Bridge of Spies a bad film, it's not. It doesn't help that it's directed by perhaps the greatest director of all time, in Steven Spielberg. Expectations are sometimes far too high for his films. But I think the problem here is that there's just not a ton of meat to this story and it's one of Spielberg's weaker films in recent memory, but really he doesn't make any bad films. Some things did bother me about his directing here though. For example, there is a character introduced within the first 10 minutes as Donovan's associate and partner. He attends Donovan's family dinner and seems to be set up as help to Donovan and a slight possible romance is hinted at with this character and Donovan's daughter. Well, after one scene we don't see this character ever again.Amy Ryan plays Donovan's wife, who I absolutely adore as an actress, is also incredibly underused. I guess what I'm trying to get across here is that there is no flow to the movie. Or rather, no arc. It's very predictable, being a true story, but the tension isn't there either. It's a slow moving picture with a great climax but not a ton of build to get to that great climax. Surprisingly, this could be contributed to Spielberg. Spielberg does do a great job of taking us to the time of the Cold War. He certainly gives us the feeling that at any moment war could have been truly started by either side. The performances are all really good. Mark Rylance who plays Abel does a magnificent job in his limited screen-time and rightfully never gives one way or another in terms of his innocence. Tom Hanks is, well, Tom Hanks. And Thomas Newman replaces John Williams as the composer and does a wonderful job as he always does. There's a lot to really like about Bridge of Spies, more than not. But for me, it was just a bit of a letdown in its lack of intensity and pay off. I wouldn't have known it was the Coen Bros script and Spielberg's directing if it wasn't for the trailers and marketing.+Rylance & Hanks togther+Spielberg transports you to the Cold War+Newman's score+Climax-Lack of intensity-Didn't get enough of Donovan and Abel together7.0/10

Loved this movie ... can't believe I've never heard of Donovan, who is a great American hero who should be discussed in our history lessons. We need more people willing to stand up for humanity and what is right versus what is politically expedient.

Potential Oscar Front Runner for Best Picture. Have to see the film overall it was an excellent performance mainly Tom Hank's role as James B.Donovan Base on what the movie was all about inspired them true stories & fictional characters on the film During the cold war History shows the powers to be between The U.S & Russia it is important to show their expressions on what the film is about I enjoyed it Two thumbs up!!!!

Despite the title, there's actually very little spy in the film; there's some, but mostly this is a film about negotiations and perceptions, and how in particular one man battles for what he sees as the right thing to do regardless of said perceptions. The film looks beautiful, ranging from nice long shots, to close ups, to dark and shadowy. Interestingly, I found it was often close-up shots that were used to frame those who had the wider view of the situation, while wider shots were used on those whose view was narrower. Interesting choice. The acting is stellar all around, with Hanks being particularly good, and Rylance being phenomenal. The story, if I'm honest, dragged a bit at first as it set up the various pieces, and as such there's practical no time spent on the trial itself. However, once the various plot elements are set up, it becomes fascinating watching Hanks' Donovan work to do what he sees as right, against both what his own government wants, and the partially unknown desires of the USSR and GDR. The final scene, which mirrors two prior scenes, I don't think was completely necessary but it is understandable why it's there. Fairly minor quibbles to an enjoyable film.

This is a top notch movie, but I still find it difficult to be excited about it. Hanks and Speilberg weave some magic with the Cohen brothers scripted docu-drama. The period tale (1940, 1957-early 1960s) grabs us and holds us through its slightly over 2hr running time. There is not a wasted frame or moment. This is a master class in film making. And it is beautiful on the screen. I don't know if people see that any more, when they are looking for the movement of the superheros of dinosaurs (but I digress). Would I see this again in theater or highly recommend it? Probably not. Mark Rylance as Rudolf Abel (our Russian spy) is truly standout brillant here.
Brilliant look at a time in history most people have forgotten.

First class acting and directing. What I really noticed was the film's attention to detail of that era. The period clothing, buildings, signs, cars, hair styles, eye glasses, television sets, even the Corning blue cornflower casserole dish used when the Donovan family sat down to dinner. If you haven't seen this movie, go see it!!!

October 16, 2016At its beginning, "Bridge of Spies" leads us to believe it's going to be a traditional courtroom drama about a level-headed lawyer who must defend a man whom everybody automatically assumes is guilty--everyone except the lawyer, that is. Through reasons of conscious and due process, he's determined to operate under the guiding principle that anyone accused of a crime is "innocent until proven guilty," despite the repercussions such a stance will have on him, his family and his career. And while the film is about this to a degree, it's not all it's about, and around the one-third mark, "Bridge of Spies" begins to add unexpected developments to its story. Even though it's based on fact, director Steven Spielberg and the three screenwriters still could have chosen to play things safe and simply glossed over or rushed through the less "Hollywood" events, but they take their time with it and really delve into the thickness of the situation. As a result, the film informs and challenges us just as the plot simultaneously intensifies.The story recounts a well-known case mandated to James B. Donovan (Tom Hanks), a New York City lawyer who began his career as a criminal attorney but who eventually segued into insurance. In 1957, amidst the Cold War, Donovan's law partners, Thomas Watters Jr. (Alan Alda) and John Rue (Lynn Goodnough), ask him to defend Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance), a seemingly gentle old man whom the FBI has been watching for some time on suspicions he's a Soviet spy and whom they've recently arrested based on questionable evidence. The Federal Government asks Watters and Rue to take his case and they accept it because they feel it's their patriotic duty, although it's obvious their real motivation is they think the notoriety will be a good PR move because it will be their organization that helps convict a Soviet spy, who was America's sworn enemy at the time. Watters and Rue, along Judge Byers (Dakin Matthews), believe the matter will essentially be open and shut, and indeed the judge flippantly says to Donovan, "Let's just get this over with."But Donovan isn't about to compromise his integrity just to expedite the proceedings or to merely get in good with the public. He rightly sees Abel as an "alleged" criminal and not as an automatic enemy, and he vows to defend him as a man who has the same rights as any other client. Of course, no one else shares Donovan's perspective, including his wife Mary (Amy Ryan), who's nervous about the effect the case will have on her family since her husband will now be viewed as a Soviet sympathizer and traitor.Still, Donovan sticks to his guns and convinces the judge that, despite his convicting Abel for conspiracy, keeping him alive could prove to be in the best interest of the country because Donovan knows there are American spies just like Abel in the Soviet Union and if one of them was to be captured, the U.S. treating Abel civilly and with honor could persuade the Soviets to do the same to their guys. Plus, Abel could also become a potential bargaining chip.As it turns out, in a parallel plot, the U.S. military recruits a group of air force pilots for a mission to fly custom jets over the Soviet Union and take pictures using highly sophisticated cameras. One of these pilots is Francis Powers (Austin Stowell) and during his endeavor, the Soviets shoot him down, but rather than self-sacrifice like he was told, Powers ejects himself and is subsequently captured. Later on, in an unrelated case that will eventually relate to both Powers' and Abel's, an American graduate student named Frederic Pryor (Will Rogers) is arrested in East Germany on suspicions of being a spy just as the German Democratic Republic is erecting the Berlin Wall. Because of Donovan's personal connection with Abel, the Federal Governments asks him to go to East Germany as a "private citizen," and not as a representative of the government, to speak with the Soviet ambassador. His objective: strike a deal that would exchange Abel for Powers. But upon hearing about Pryor, Donovan takes it upon himself to take the deal even further and, in separate negotiations, asks that the Germans release Pryor as well. So he makes it own mission to have the Soviets release Powers and the Germans release Pryor, both in exchange for Abel, whom both Germany and the Soviet Union have a vested interest.History aside, the drama and suspense of "Bridge of Spies" stems from Donovan's sheer will and whether or not his convictions will survive the odds and stakes that are pitted against him. The film paints him as an obvious hero and good guy, and Hanks, as usual, lends the character an everyman, down-to-earth quality. Naturally, we like and admire him, which is one of the reasons it's so easy to get involved in this story. But in addition to that, "Bridge of Spies" shares the same kind of storytelling as Ridley Scott's "The Martian" in that the plot continually adds hurdles for its characters to deal with and attempt to overcome. Just when we think things are going to play out smoothly and in their favor, new dilemmas arise and we're honestly not fully convinced Donovan's determination and strategy will win out, which makes it all the more engaging. Of course, there's the lingering notion that because this is, in fact, a mainstream Hollywood movie, the ending will inevitably be a happy one, but Spielberg and his writers don't make it an all-out guarantee, and that's what makes it so watchable right up to a key scene that takes place on two different bridges in Germany. The tension builds and builds until finally...Well I won't reveal what happens, but I will say the film pays off both dramatically and as an intriguing historical document. It's also a crowning technical achievement, with production designer Adam Stockhausen, who won a well deserved Oscar for "The Grand Budapest Hotel," creating a dark, brooding atmosphere and faithfully recreating a 1950s New York City and Berlin that transports us to a different time and world altogether. You wouldn't think a dramatic thriller would be so striking and absorbing on a visual level, but "Bridge of Spies" is.I'm not sure how I feel about the film's closing scene, which perhaps goes one step too far with its romance and bookending a previous shot just to bring the story full circle. This is the kind of Hollywood underlining that Spielberg sometimes finds hard to resist just so he can appease and bring comfort to the audience. Luckily, it's more unnecessary than harmful, but I still wish he'd chosen a more subtle approach. Still, the essence of the story remains intact and the film serves as a veritable thriller as well as an intriguing history lesson.

Great! Films like this are so old school good, so well crafted, and so normal for a master like Spielberg that we almost take it for granted. There wasn't a single thing wrong with it that I could find. It was mature and rock solid filmmaking at it's finest. Mark Rylance was fantastic in it, the Coens brought their wit, and Tom Hanks yet again solidifies his status as an iconic actor, a sure-fire everyman, and the Jimmy Stewart of his generation.

A solid political thriller that may lack many thrills but enough is happening to keep you until the end. Tom Hanks does a fine job here but he never really sheds Tom Hanks off this character. Hanks is just naturally great that you'll enjoy watching him even if you don't believe him as a different character. Mark Rylance is great as the spy captured in the movie and Alan Alda and Amy Ryan are severely under utilized. Spielberg really hasn't been doing great movies this century besides the amazing Catch Me if You Can and the fun Indiana Jones 4 and solid Adventures of Tin Tin. This movie will be like War Horse (except more interesting. I didn't fall asleep during this one) where it will get nominated for some tech awards and Picture since it is that type of subject matter that the Academy loves but I don't think the actors nor Spielberg will be rewarded. Rylance is the only hope but he may be too subtle to make it in. The writing is good and the Coen Brothers add a nice wit to the screenplay that Hanks is great at delivering. The cinematography is just sloppy and ugly here. This was one of my issues with Lincoln as well where it just is so overexposed at times that it just takes you out of the movie and makes you think you are watching a movie and not a window into these people's lives as movies are supposed to be. The pacing is a little slow and the whole sub plot with Jesse Plemmons and Austin Stowell isn't developed well enough in the beginning to understand the relevance to Hanks' storyline that it just becomes distracting and gets in the way. The movie feels like a 3 part mini series on HBO honestly with the first chapter dealing with Rylance's court case, the second chapter dealing with the two Americans being captured and Hanks having to go reduce them in the final chapter. That would have been a little better and may have added some better explaining of the prisoners to have the audience truly care about them rather than only caring about them getting out of Germany and the Soviet's hands just because they are Americans. The movie just lacks any emotional pull. It's a little boring at times but Hanks makes his parts worthy of your attention even if they run too long. The 50 and over crowd will love this but for the young whipper snappers, you may have your patience tested slightly.

Sometimes you might forget how wonderful an actor , Tom Hanks is. If you have forgotten lately, then you will be reminded of how great an actor he is in "Bridge of spies". Tom Hanks is , in my opinion, the greatest actor of my generation, and I'm 51 years old. This move keeps you paying close attention, to every word, every scene, every actor. The story is so well told, a story I must admit, didn't know of. Im not big with words, but this movie is an A+, or as Homer would reply, "Woo Hoo!".
A tad formulaic, but its an awesome story told well with standout performances from Hanks and Rylance

Acting and directing are terrific, the story was good even though it was not true. It is based on a true story but the lawyer was not involved in the negations in real life only the defending of the spy. He was there, but the negations were done by Embassy Officials and CIA.
Spielberg and Hanks are in fine form in this intelligent spy thriller co-written by the Coen Brothers.
Tom Hanks delivers as usual.
Outstanding. Touches on the historical background needed to understand the times. Great acting by all.

Movie: Bridge of SpiesRating: PG-13, 2 hours 15 minutesGrade: AIn a Nutshell: "1957. The height of the Cold War. The United States and the Soviet Union fear each other's nuclear capabilities - and intentions. Both sides deploy spies - and hunt for them." And so the movie begins.This is not a bang-bang, shoot 'em up James Bond kind of spy film, but a thinking-man's movie. It's a true story, which gives it all the "wow factor" the movie needs. Thank you, Steven Spielberg, for another powerful movie. He and Tom Hanks know how to do it right. Uplifting Theme:� Justice� "It doesn't matter what other people think. You know what you did." - James Donovan� Good vs. Bad vs. something in between...- Patriotism comes in many colors. - Which is more important: the ends or the means?Things I liked:� Written by the Coen brothers. Humor. Tension. Historical drama. Great job!� Good for Amy Ryan for starring in two movies in theaters at the same time! (Goosebumps)- I loved the contrast between the 2 scenes that showed people jumping over a fence.- Some of the most powerful statements were never spoken. Tom Hanks is the master of subtlety.Things I didn't like:� It's a little slow-moving at times. Those who require non-stop action in their movie-going will get a good nap. Funny lines: � "You don't look worried." - James Donovan"Would it help?" - Rudolph Abel� "I'm not afraid to die, Mr. Donovan, although it wouldn't be my first choice." - Rudolph Abel (played extremely well by Rudolf Rylance. Best Supporting Actor Oscar?)� Interesting lines:� "We need to have a conversation our governments can't." James Donovan� "Everyone deserves a defense. Every person matters." - DonovanTips for Parents:� 1 F-bomb by Tom Hanks. Aw, doggonit.- Children will snooze and not be interested. Teens might snooze, but will be rewarded if they can stick it out until the end.� You see innocent people being gunned down as they try to get over the East Berlin Wall. Your children may not know about this point in history and the dangers of the Cold War after WWII. I remember watching in utter amazement when the Berlin Wall finally came down. I never thought it would happen. - "Checkpoint Charlie" is also shown in the film. Talk to your kids or grandkids about what life was like back then. George Santayana is quoted as saying "Those who do not read history are doomed to repeat it. Those who fail to learn from the mistakes of their predecessors are destined to repeat them."
perfect casting, awesome acting from everyone in the cast. Enjoyed every minute!
Hanks and Spielberg put in their typical stellar performances.

Many people are calling this the "Gary Powers" movie, but it's not about Gary Powers. In fact, his storyline doesn't even show up until the movie is well underway. The focus of this movie is on the attorney, portrayed by Tom Hanks, who represented the Soviet spy Abel in his criminal trial & later negotiated the release of Powers & a US student held by the East Germans in exchange for Abel. As an attorney, to me this movie demonstrated the difficulties attorneys representing unpopular, demonised clients always face: the obligation to zealously represent their client according to the laws & Constitution of this country vs. popular "String 'em up" opinion. It's always sad when those who are doing the right thing are punished & treated poorly for it. As Donovan points out, what makes us "Americans" is our belief in the Constitution & the rule of law. Without that, we're just a bunch of immigrants from other countries with nothing in common. Another thing this movie portrayed in vivid detail was the abject fear of nuclear war that was being taught to children in school. "Duck & Cover" is laughable today, especially to those growing up in a post-Cold War world, but to those of us who were taught to fear the evil communists, those scenes are very difficult to sit through without having a PTSD-like flashback. The movie is based on actual events, & the story is fascinating. The visuals are beautiful & depictions of post-war Berlin as the Wall goes up are stark reminders of how bleak things were near the height of the Cold War. Mark Rylance is brilliant as the Soviet spy & should expect Supporting Actor nods (& IMO wins) come awards season. Tom Hanks should also expect a Best Actor nod, but although he turns in a great performance, nothing I've seen this year has topped Johnny Depp in "Black Mass." All in all, a great movie, well told, very much worth the price of admission.

Spielberg is still the master, he can inject suspense and thrills into a cold-war story that is basically all talk and that requires the minimal of action! Or perhaps the Coen Brothers' screenplay helps it along a bit. Mark Rylance's performance is superb, might win him an Oscar nomination. Hanks is as good as ever. Thoroughly enjoyed it.

Whenever Spielberg makes a movie, usually it should probably be called one of the best directed films that will come out that year. Spielberg is one of the still working directors who still knows how to tell a story the best way, to stage his scenes the best, to understand filmmaking, and to play an audience like a fiddle. Here is no exception in what is one of his more quiet pictures, Spielberg's presence is still there, but it's also impossible not to admire or watch with the joy of seeing his hand at work again. He's also taken his collaboration with Tom Hanks to yet again to actually take advantage of the actors soft spoken nature and us Hanks' acting to enhance the performance, rather than work against it. Mark Rylance is also very good in a far to small of a role as the Rudolf Abel, the often quiet and closed off Soviet spy taken in by the U.S. It's a beautiful looking film, a fantastically directed one, and a well acted one, and yet if there wasn't one problem: the script. Spielberg is one of the best directors working today, but he also has a weakness for relatively unremarkable screenplays for him to work his incredibly overqualified hands on. The screenplay isn't bad, but it's also clear that it could've gone through another round with the Coens (by the way, I swear they only did one page of this screenplay because it feels nothing like them outside of it), because it's the main writer's first screenplay, and it shows. Not to say the script is bad, it's perfectly serviceable with moments of greatness, but it's by far the weakest link in what would otherwise be a fantastic addition to Spielberg's filmography without it. Despite it, Bridge of Spies is a good film, even a very good one, but it could also have been better, and considering it's Spielberg, it's a bit of a disappointment
Ho-hum. The trailer is better than the movie. This was not the exciting spy thriller I was expecting. Tom Hanks' performance was good. Has Spielberg lost his touch? This was just meh.

I will go see anything(A) starring Tom Hanks, (B) directed by Steven Spielberg, or (C) written by the Coen brothers, so how could this miss? It doesn't. Terrific film with first-rate performances from Hanks and Mark Rylance.

Tom Hanks. That is all. But really, this was such a return of old cinema with Spielberg. The story, while doesn't do anything over the top, keeps you interested from beginning to end. It's edited so well that every transition relates to the next. If you love real spy stories, you'll definitely love this. And honestly, this is what I wanted out of other spy movies like Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy.

Bridge of Spies was an OKAY film. To the uninitiated who have no expectations from a Spielberg film this was a good educational Cold War period drama. For folks like me who love Spielberg and his almost magical story telling abilities this film felt short on many frontsOne of Spielberg's great abilities is the intrinsic knowledge about the pacing of a film. He has an uncanny ability to delve into the viewer subconscious and understand what exactly the audience would expect and be excited by at different junctures in the film. This film sort of fails to take off. I loved the fact that it juxtaposes two parallels - the capture of a Soviet spy and his trial in the US courts and the tribulations of a United States fighter pilot who is drafted for reconnaissance missions over Soviet territory and whose plane is shot down with him getting captured. The parallels got off the blocks pretty smart but you never got the acceleration you expected to happen. I was not expecting an espionage thriller but half an hour into the film I was expecting a "Catch me if you can" playbook to unfold - instead it took the same meandering path it started off with.The acting performances were just fine. Tom Hanks is cr�me de la cr�me of American actors and puts in a fine performance in this one. Here in this film I felt though that he was somehow constrained by the screenplay into playing the justice seeking affable, "can't do a thing wrong" American lawyer a little too much. When I think of Tom Hanks I think of Captain Miller in Saving Private Ryan - a formidable actor that can display a wide range of emotions - wry humor, guilt, justified anger, sorrow, resignation. In this film he gets into the conversationalist mode a little too much. The performance I gravitated towards was of the actor who played the Soviet spy - Colonel Abel. You almost seem to root for the guy by the end of the film - In his quiet way he conveys that the spies are nothing but puppets of their governments - same as soldiers in the battlefield - valuable as assets at the time of engagement but frowned upon and neglected once they return to their homeland.The cinematography of the film is stunning. The d�cor and sets are outstanding - reminiscent of the World War II era and the immediate Cold War aftermath that followed it. There are very little action sequences in the film - one of them of the U2 reconnaissance plane shot down over Soviet territory is breath taking. But all in all the film felt like a stage play and long winded. With Spielberg we expect the gold medal, bronze just does not do it...
While it's nothing groundbreaking from Hanks or Spielberg, the script is smart and it's a fun time at the movies.

For the fourth time in they're respective careers, Tom Hanks and Steven Spielberg have come together to make a movie. This time set during the Cold War, Tom Hanks ( James Donovan) is required to represent Mark Rylance (Rudolf Abel), a Soviet Spy. But when an American spy is captured by the Soviets, it's up to Donovan to negotiate an exchange between two opposing nations.Seeing the trailers and knowing who was involved in this film, it would make one excited (if you know anything about Steven Spielberg or Tom Hanks). Bridge of Spies is a great example of historical story telling done at it's finest. Spielberg is no stranger to this feat. However this is an example of old school hollywood, and it is not for everyone.There are two types of Spielberg history movies, the Saving Private Ryan (action packed, thrilling) and the Lincoln (great performances, talking based). Both are incredible movies for different reasons, and Bridge of Spies falls into the Lincoln category, where there isn't action, it is a film with a lot of talking. But it's those talking scenes where the movie comes to life, and a lot of that is thanks to the masterful directing of Steven Spielberg.Another big part why this movie is great are the performances. You have Tom Hanks, two time oscar winner (Philadelphia 1993 and Forrest Gump 1994) who does amazing. What else can you expect from one of the best actors of all time. Also you have Mark Rylance (Rudolf Abel) who does, maybe just as good or even better than Hanks. Whenever he appeared on screen, he was electrifying. I wouldn't be surprised if he gets a nomination for best supporting actor come the Oscars.This is definitely not Spielberg's best, and has some slight negatives. At times, felt slow and the second act was not as strong as the first or third, but still solid.Overall, Bridge of Spies is a beautifully directed film, with amazing performances, and a great history lesson. It is written by the Coen Brothers, and composed wonderfully by Thomas Newman. This movie is not for everyone, but if your the type that gets goosebumps from watching people talk in a perfectly crafted scene, then this movie is for you.
Steven Spielberg/Tom Hanks is a winning formula. Well done!
Slow but meticulously crafted in writing and filming, Bridge of Spies proves that Spielberg and Hanks are still very much in their A-game

Absolutely Perfect!Thank you Steven Spielberg, Tom Hanks, et. al.; and congratulations on an epic film!I love everything about this film, the acting is superb, the setting and accuracy of the Berlin Wall is a tribute to all of those that suffered and died there. A very well testament that this really did happen and has not been forgotten; as well as the intuitive implication that concentration/gas camps of the Third Reich existed and that the 6+ millions of Jews, et. al. who died or suffered there as well. While I know this was not the point of the movie, the bigger picture must be remembered, or else history shall repeat itself. As far as the story, a true story, you must watch the film LOL.
Another brillant film for Tom Hanks and Steven Spielberg.

Saw this today and was enthralled with every aspect of this film. The story, the cast of characters, the feel for the times, not one false step that I could see. Move over Leonardo, Johnny, Will, etc., I'd be willing to bet that once again you'll see Tom Hanks, what the Russian calls his character "a standing man", stand up when called and walk away with Oscar come March.

I figured with this movie being released in October, being about the Soviet Union, being inspired by true events, and with this movie having Tom Hanks, I would think this has academy award nominee written all over it. I can tell you that this movie does have an interesting story, and the cast was pretty good. I do think that this movie went on a little long though. All in all, in my opinion, this is a pretty good movie, but I do not see it as one of the best movies of the year.

This latest collaboration between Academy Award winners Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks offers an engrossing behind-the-scenes flashback into the high-stakes Cold War dynamics of U.S. and Soviet Union relations in 1957. A fascinating legal and political chess match that spotlights each superpower's desperate need to win the information war using spooks and the court of public opinion. "Bridge of Spies" takes viewers on a brisk history lesson through a series of true events, all designed around the nuclear distrust and tension leading up the United States vs. Soviet Union stare down during the Cuban Missile Crisis in October of 1962.Tom Hanks is perfectly cast as real-life attorney James Donovan, an affable family man who defends our legal system and a client's right to a fair shake in court--even when his defendant is an accused Soviet spy and the American public is willing, momentarily, to turn its back to our U.S. Constitution."Bridge of Spies" is not an action-packed military affair or even a political suspense thriller. It's a personal story about Jim Donovan (Hanks) and his attorney-client relationship that grows out of a mutual respect and sense of duty. The screenplay's collaborative effort by newcomer Matt Charman and the Oscar-winning Coen brothers (Ethan and Joel), provides an accelerated timeline which blurs collective years in order to give Hanks more screen time as the head-strong legal defender Donovan.As issues with fairness, due process and negotiations slowly unfold over a possible prisoner exchange in Germany, "Bridge of Spies" only faintly draws on the escalating geopolitical tension with a military twist. This mistakenly downplays Soviet spy Rudolf Abel's actual 4 years spent in a U.S. prison and American U-2 spy plane pilot Gary Powers' 10-year espionage conviction-along with Powers' nearly 2 years of being jailed outside Moscow.Movie-goers seeking an intriguing legal drama amidst two adversaries holding men with vast knowledge of their homeland's secrets will find "Bridges of Spies" a captivating gambit to watch. This Cold War dialogue of mistrust and intelligence gathering offers Hanks' portrayal of James Donovan the opportunity to stack our U.S. Constitution and legal fairness against any other system in the world.Both Hanks and Mark Rylance (as Soviet spy Abel) give standout and convincing performances. Although this film lacks some depth of coverage for certain historic events, it fields early proof of the cooperative ways between the U.S. and Soviet Union when a country's security needs must be met. A dramatic willingness to step away from the ledge--by both nuclear sides. And eight months after these "Bridge of Spies" events took place at Berlin's Glienicke Bridge and Checkpoint Charlie, another test of U.S.-Soviet wills ensued in the waters surrounding Cuba. But that's a different story and time.Grade: B+

Steven Spielberg strikes again with another outstanding movie! Based on a true fascinating story, that you will not want to put on pause or go to the bathroom in a movie theater. Tom Hanks once again gives a masterful performance, so the Academy better nominate him for best actor. Mark Rylance's performance as the spy makes him a possible candidate for best supporting actor. The camera work and cinematography is just astonishing. The story keeps you on the edge of your seat. I predict this will be an Academy award favorite film. I predict 6 to 7 nominations. My grade=97%(A+).

Hanks-Spielberg duo never disappoints. Add Coen Brothers to that, and we have a truly masterful film. Bridge of Spies may not have the classic Spielberg magic to it, but it manages to be thrilling, exciting and entertaining in its own right.
Not as gripping in its political maneuvering as Lincoln was before it, but Hanks' heart is onscreen and more than enough to engage.

Anchored by yet another excellent performance by Tom Hanks and Steven Spielberg's flawless direction, Bridge of Spies is an eminently effective old-school spy thriller that's both uplifting and surprisingly funny even though it hits a few narrative bumps along the way.

A well acted and directed movie by the Speilberg-Hanks machine. I thought it would be a weak plot but I was pleasantly surprised. The message is very clear, what keeps our freedoms are the laws we have in place. Without a civil and fair trial for each individual, anarchy and lawlessness will prevail.

Steven Spielberg's engrossing period drama which is based on a true life incident, in 1957 the Soviet spy Rudolf Abel, impressively played by Mark Rylance was capture in New York City, his defense is assigned to American lawyer, James B. Donovan, played magnificently by Tom Hanks, he makes a selfless sacrifice out of his sense of patriotic duty, but then is recruited by CIA director Allen Dulles, well-played by Peter McRobbie to secretly negotiate and arranged a prisoner swap of Abel for U.S. pilot Francis Gary Powers who's U2 spy plane was shot down over the Soviet Union by there armed forces. Masterful direction by the great Spielberg, with extraordinary cinematography by Janusz Kaminski. great supporting performances by Alan Alda, Domenick Lombardozzi, Amy Ryan, John Rue, Billy Magussen, and Henny Russell, but its Hank's searing performance of great dignity and total conviction that steals this film completely. A taut thriller and fascination motion picture, one of the year's very best. Highly Recommended.

It's hard to rate a Spielberg movie. Do I fault it for its unabashed sentimentality? Or, do I praise it? Bridge Of Spies is a neat and tidy movie. There's nothing sloppy about it. In fact, it looks great! But there's no real intensity to it...no momentum. And you never get the feeling things are going to turn out bad. BoS gives you what you usually get from a Spielberg movie: reassurance.

Excellent movie for all times and all ages. You don't have to remember the Cold War to appreciate the tensions between powers that distrust each other. And you don't have to sympathize with the Nazi's to still feel for post WW2 Germany. War is hell and post war mistrust isn't much better. Fantastic acting (of course). I was on the edge of my seat.
This awas a great movie. The cinematography was excellent especially the shots done in Poland that simulated East Berlin in 1960.

A great story of a man standing up for the right thing despite being in a country in a state of fear. Hanks does a great job playing a great lawyer while constantly reminding you that that same lawyer is just an average guy. "Aren't you worried?" "Would it help?"
Top notch work from Hanks, Spielberg and Kaminski. Rylance is a revelation.

A great story told by masters of their craft. A solid cast is complemented with tight production and camerawork thanks to Spielberg. But his classic, sometimes nostalgic direction was brought together with a stunning script penned by the Coen brothers and Matt Charman. The experience behind and in front of the camera really shows on this modern classic. The film was shaky only a few times throughout it's 2 hr. 15 min. runtime, but always managed to reel us back in just in time. We rally with the protagonist throughout the ending, even after when we question the humanistic nature of the exchange versus social atmosphere of the time. Thought-provoking for some and pure thrills for others. Even if we still need the approval of an old white lady on the train.

"Some could argue that its a bit too Hollywood-ized. But frankly, If you got talented people who know what they're doing behind it, it works wonderfully. The beautiful direction and cinematography mixed in with terrific performances and a perfect script that blends drama, heart, and even a little humor. I saw this with a theater full of old people who erupted in applause at the end. It was great to join in."

Who would have thought that a movie could be so fantastic where the most interesting parts are human interactions. Everything about it was great - the overall story, cinematography, acting, etc., but the most intense scenes were when two people were simply talking to each other - no fanfare, so special effects...just sitting in chairs and planning and negotiating. What was also amazing was Spielberg's ability to move the story along without spending too much time on one scene. You could see the mastery at work in the way he jumped around from scene to scene since in order for the story to move forward three or four things needed to happen first. This could have easily been a boring movie since the subject matter was relatively mundane, but Spielberg elevated it to an artform.
The symphonic score Thomas Newman has written for this film is superb. Needless to say that Newman was Spielberg's first choice to replace legendary composer John Williams.
Another Masterpiece by Spielberg!

Director Steven Spielberg is the conscience of American film-makers, delving into the dark places of our history - the morally shaky ground of policymaking in a country that prides itself on its belief in upholding the principles of the U.S.Constitution. In his latest film, BRIDGE OF SPIES, he pokes a stick into the headlines of Cold War events - the 1960 U-2 Spy plane incident, in order to shed air and light into the dark reaches of official myth-making. Aware that this can be done most powerfully through precise direction, detailed sets, soaring soundtracks, and cinematography that echoes the dreary mood of the times - bright sunshine recedes behind the shadows of deception. The audience is always entertained, despite the subject matter's depiction of the murkiness of ethics and morality. Like the great illustrator Norman Rockwell - we are seduced by an "apple pie" ethos, except there are worms wriggling around in the crust.Tom Hanks is perfectly cast - an actor who I cannot remember ever playing a "bad" guy - as James Donovan, an insurance lawyer conscripted by the CIA in 1957 during the height of the Cold War hysteria to defend the arrested Soviet mole, Rudolf Abel, (an academy award winning performance by Mark Rylance,) and participate in a US government programmed "kangaroo-court" trial. Except James Donovan believes in the right of an individual to the best defense as the bedrock of our democracy, not willing to compromise his deeply held integrity.BRIDGE OF SPIES begins with a panning of a dreary Brooklyn street with the Manhattan Bridge in the background looming over the landscape, the camera eventually lands upstairs in a tenement building where Mark Rylance/Rudolf Abel is looking at himself in a mirror painting a quite good traditional self-portrait. This double view is our introduction to the personality of a seemingly Walter Mitty-like individual, his physiognomy imprinted with a haunting and magnetic expressiveness, conveying adversity and conviction. Rylance's sympathetic portrayal of Abel is seductive and thrilling; this spy is a mystery and remains so.Tom Hanks/James Donovan - a reincarnation of Jimmy Stewart (thicker in physique) lives a 1950's dream life in suburbia; three children and a clueless stay-at-home wife and mother (played by Amy Ryan in a thankless part.) Women are just accessories in this movie - indicative of how they were considered at the time. Thank goodness for the Feminist Movement 20 years later! Getting involved with cloak and dagger politics does not change Donovan - he is incorruptible and strongly rooted to the ideals of American values as put forth in the Constitution and Bill of Rights.At the same time as the Abel trial - America is preparing to send a U-2 spy plane equipped with surveillance equipment over Soviet territory and the Central Intelligence Agency recruits a young pilot Francis Gary Powers (a bland, handsome Austin Stowell) to complete the reconnaissance mission. In 1960, the operation is implemented and shortly thereafter the U-2 spy plane is shot down by a Soviet surface-to-air missile and Powers parachutes unto Russian soil still alive and is captured and sentenced to a long term of imprisonment and hard labor. A politically heated issue and an embarrassment for the Eisenhower administration - the incident was vigorously denied by the USA and a cover-up was attempted, but the covert military maneuver was ultimately exposed.Attempts are made to return Gary Francis Power to the USA in order to interrogate him about how much classified information he revealed to the Soviets. The authorities turn again to Attorney James Donovan to negotiate the exchange of spies on Glienicker Bridge in East Germany - Rudolf Abel for Gary Francis Powers; the tension and drama of BRIDGE OF SPIES begins against the backdrop of the Wall being erected in East Berlin - a bleak city in contrast to its counterpart in the Western sector. Pragmatic political behavior by officials in the KGB, CIA and FBI are all stick figures in the chess game of diplomacy and Tom Hanks deftly navigates his way through the labyrinth of innuendo and deceit. Espionage, duplicity, betrayal are at the heart of this film. What makes it palatable is the humanity of both Tom Hanks and Mark Rylance's characters who bond with mutual respect, despite their opposing ideological viewpoints. Director Spielberg can be sentimental, but is able to tunnel through the sappiness with humor and affection. He really likes his two leading men and so do we.

A very fine film. Spielberg is back! Hanks is great once again! And the Cold War seems to be back also as a fave theme for Hollywood. I really liked the little touches of 1950s America, with the TV shows and the Duck'n Cover nonsense. A true (though embellished) story that gripped America during those very tense days.
Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks continue to be masters at their respective crafts.

This is the big drama you may, or may not, have been waiting for. It is another wonderful collaboration of Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks. The critics are already lining up to suggest multiple Academy Awards here, mostly deserved. The story is about one of the most important actions of the cold war between the USA and Russia. A lot of the action here is court room and negotiation dialogue, but done so well you do not get bored. There is some great CGI action and it is suspenseful at all times. Probably a great movie, you should go see it.

Well crafted and well acted spy thriller. Mark Rylance is particularly good as the soviet spy and Tom Hanks does a good job as the man who negotiates a swap for a captures american pilot in this true story. Spielberg and company do a good job of creating the tone and look of early 1960s East Berlin for the second half of the film. I was loosely familiar with the historical aspects of the film but those who arent, which will probably make up a good portion of the audience, will learn some stuff about some real cold war stuff.

Bridge of Spies is a slow-paced hybrid between a courtroom drama and a diplomatic thriller, with Tom Hanks in the role of a civilian unexpectedly plunged into the midst of a tense international negotiation. Within this context, the film explores themes of honor, loyalty, and human dignity, and while the film feels a little slow to a modern viewer (what, no Michael Bay explosions?), the payoff at the end is more than worth it. Strongly recommended to anyone who likes dramas, thrillers, or Tom Hanks.

The first time I heard of James B. Donovan was when I was very young and his way of negotiating with world leaders, most especially Fidel Castro, was praised. I never "followed" his career and I never "met" Rudolf Abel before watching this film. All I knew was that this was a Steven Spielberg film starring Tom Hanks based on true events. That's all. I never saw a trailer or a review or whatever kind of teaser. I guess that was just a well because I really paid attention to the film.At first I thought I was going to be bored or confused because it seemed that way during the first part of the film. Little by little my interest in the film grew and after half an hour, I was drawn to it that I even clapped towards the end of the film. The last time I clapped was when I watched Heneral Luna. The rest of the films I watched after that epic paled in comparison, but this period film set during the COLD WAR left a mark in my heart. From an ostracized person to becoming a hero....James B. Donovan was, I mean is, a very inspiring person. My favorite line: It doesn't matter what other people think of you. What matters is knowing you did the right thing.- Jimmy Donovan to a trembling Gary Powers
I saw this movie tonight... wonderful story and acting....
Well done! A little slow, but what they had wasn't superfluous. It was necessary. Tom hanks was, as usual, genius!

Fascinating, interesting, and surprisingly filled with humour, Bridge of Spies offers nothing short of typical brilliant work from the Steven Spielberg-Tom Hanks union, with an unexpected outstanding performance from Mark Rylance.
For dumb people and smart people who have decided to stop worrying and love chestnut creme.

Steven Spielberg certainly delivers in this instant classic. A film that will keep you emerge in the story, and wanting to know what will happen next. The cast does an amazing job the entire movie. Tom Hanks always delivers, but the performance of Mark Rylance is incredibly memorable! Scenes are done extremely well and will stick with you long after this film is out of theaters. To anyone looking for a great suspenseful film should definitely check this one out!
Steven Spielberg. Tom Hanks. What more do you need to know?
Another great Tom Hanks movie. He will get an Oscar nod for this one. Very interesting story, tense but not stressful, held my interest through the entire movie. Must see!

If Saving Private Ryan is an A, Catch Me If You Can an A-, and The Terminal a B+, then Bridge of Spies-director Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks' fourth collaboration together-is a solid B: there's little here that will knock your socks off, yet it's hard to imagine anyone walking out of the theater feeling seriously dissatisfied with the experience. See, Bridge of Spies is EXACTLY the movie that the trailers make it out to be: a well-acted, suitably entertaining walk through history from Mr. Spielberg, with a reliably charming turn from Mr. Hanks. Sure, maybe such 'adequateness' is a little disappointing, especially when we've seen the heights that both of these guys are capable of scaling together... but let's face it: even 'minor' work from Spielberg and Hanks tends to make for pretty darn good cinema, which is exactly what Bridge of Spies is.

The late 1950s portrayed in film. That is what Bridge of Spies accomplishes better than any modern film I have seen in my life. The dynamic and slick, calculating and smart approach to a complicated story adds up to a harrowing and thrilling tale of moral ambiguity. The script is sharp and full of memorable lines and philosophies for the audience and characters involved, which Matt Charman and the Coens deserve a hand for. The magnificent direction of Steven Spielberg makes a story which could have been a complicated slog turn into a compelling well-crafted espionage story akin to the 1950s and 1960s spy movies. The two forefront performances of Tom Hanks as Jim Donavan and Mark Rylance as Rudolf Abel are enthralling and brilliant. Hanks' Donavan is forced to deal with the true state of his government and people while trying to defend a man no one will give the light of day, while Rylance's Abel appears to be a simple man who understands perfectly what his situation is and accepts it.
With the subtle humor throughout the movie I wasn't at all surprised to see Joel and Ethan Coen credited as screenwriters.

Featuring a compelling true story with lots of heart and surprising wit, Bridge of Spies is another great addition to Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks's memorable filmographies. And offers a pleasantly more optimistic tone to a bleak era of time with just enough honesty
We enjoyed this movie a lot. Good to see Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks together again.
A inspiring true story that is a victim of Dreamworks sugar.

This movie had somehow slipped under my radar before its release. I didn't even realize it was a new Steven Spielberg film. Perhaps its�terribly generic poster pushed my thoughts towards dismissal. That would have been a shame, as�?Bridge of Spies,? poster notwithstanding, is quite a fine espionage thriller. If it gets a bit unfocused in its final act, that doesn't take away from the solid filmmaking of the first two thirds. What's particularly refreshing about the way Spielberg and his screenwriters (two of whom are Ethan and Joel Coen!) present the material is that the government spies�at work within the story are anything but Bondian. Instead, it's an insurance lawyer who saves the day. The film is also a wonderful�meditation on the meaning of ostensible American values: what good is liberty and justice if we ignore them when times get tough?The film opens with a big unknown. A man looks in the mirror, painting his self-portrait. At first, even though a title card had just announced that this was a movie about the Cold War, I thought it might be Norman Rockwell, but when the phone rang and he ran out without a word, jumping into a New York subway car, I thought otherwise. This mystery man is played by�Mark Rylance (?Angels & Insects?), and though he has done more British TV and stage work than Hollywood films, he is an extraordinary presence in front of the camera. Which is good, because it turns out that he is a Soviet spy, Rudolf Abel, and so needs all of the sympathy that a great actor can give him.�In a bit that recalls the great 1953 communist-paranoia thriller�?Pickup on South Street,? Abel is pursued by the FBI on that subway, and then home, where he has taken a secret bit of possibly classified information he surreptitiously picked up on his journey. The G-men bust in, grab him, and that's the end of it.Or not. We then meet James B. Donovan�-�played by Tom Hanks (?Saving Mr. Banks?) with his usual folksy charm�-�a star insurance lawyer whose firm�has been asked by the U.S. government to defend Abel, to show the rest of the world that the Americans offer justice even to those who would destroy us. Donovan gets the short straw, and like a good boy scout is soon annoying those very forces that wanted him to put on a good show. To him, that means offering the best defense possible. To his superiors, that means doing the bare minimum. We sense a showdown.Meanwhile, Spielberg starts cutting back and forth between scenes of Donovan and Abel and scenes of Francis Gary Powers�- stoically played by Austin Stowell (Miles Teller's drum rival in�?Whiplash?) - as he is first selected, and then trained, to fly a high-altitude spy plane over the Soviet Union. As history tells us (kind of hard to ignore it), he is shot down on his first mission�and�taken captive, and soon we have parallel captured-spy scenarios. Before long, we find ourselves in East Berlin, where a new wall is going up, as Donovan - reviled at home for defending a "Russkie" but now freelancing for the CIA - tries to negotiate a prisoner exchange. As a cloak and dagger procedural, it's fascinating stuff, until it all gets just a little too long.No matter the length, though, this is good storytelling. The terrific�actress Amy Ryan (?Gone Baby Gone?) may be relegated to the role of "the wife" - shame, Hollywood, shame! - and there may be nary a face of color in sight - shame, Hollywood, shame! - but otherwise this is a very fine historical thriller that reminds us of our best moments�as a country. A good lesson for the upcoming election year!
My only complaint is it wasn't in black and white.

Exciting film about a reluctant lawyer (Tom Hanks) persuaded to defend a man accused of being a Russian spy during the cold war. Fascinating juxtaposition between America and the Soviet Union adds to the intensity. Meanwhile, the Soviets have captured their own spy and that person is Francis Gary Powers. You SHOULD know who that is! Tom Hanks is perfect in the role of James Donovan, a true hero if there ever was a hero during the cold war !
Solid film with solid performances. Could have been a lot more tense if it wanted to, but wasn't. It was just trying to be good, and that it was.

A friend of mine recently posted on Facebook that his daughter had asked him who played the character called Hawkeye. "Alan Alda," was my friend's reply, thinking of the surgeon on TV's "M*A*S*H". But my friend's daughter was asking about the Marvel Comics character in the "Avengers" films (played by Jeremy Renner). Besides amusing me, that little story got me thinking about how I was going to write my review of Steven Spielberg's historical drama "Bridge of Spies" (PG-13, 2:21). If I'm going to discuss a movie in which "The U-2 Incident" plays such a big part, it might be a good idea to point out that this reference has nothing to do with ticket scalping at a rock concert or anything of the sort. In fact, to better appreciate this review and, more importantly, Spielberg's film, you might want to do what I just did - reinforce and add to your historical knowledge of the aforementioned Cold War crisis, the Hollow Nickel Case and Rudolf Abel, Francis Gary Powers and James Donovan. Or... you could just read my review and then go to the film, not just for a great cinematic history lesson but to see one terrific movie.Tom Hanks stars as James Donovan, a New York insurance lawyer in the 1950s. Donovan is smart, honest, hard-working and, most importantly, he has principles and integrity - especially when it comes to the law. He has also served his country in uniform and assisted in the prosecution of Nazi war criminals in the post-World War II Nuremberg Trials. Donovan's law firm's senior partner (played, coincidentally, by the same Alan Alda mentioned in my previous paragraph) asks him to accept the thankless task of defending accused Soviet spy, Rudolf Abel (multiple Tony Award winner Mark Rylance).Donovan is understandably less than enthusiastic about all of this, but his sincere belief that "everyone deserves a defense" leads him to take the case. In spite of (and because of) his patriotism, he represents this obviously guilty spy as zealously and ethically as he represents all his clients. In the vehement and almost universal anti-communism of 1950s America, Donovan runs down every ground ball, making him one of the most hated men in America - and even endangering his family. His wife (Amy Ryan) supports him throughout the case, but she has some trouble understanding the lengths that he goes to for Abel.Fast-forward a few years. Abel is still in prison, and Donovan brings him a letter supposedly from his wife in the U.S.S.R. The letter amounts to a back-channel proposal from the Soviets to discuss trading Abel for recently captured U-2 spy plane pilot Francis Gary Powers (Austin Stowell). C.I.A. director Allen Dulles personally asks Donovan to negotiate the swap - but as a private citizen, NOT as a representative of the U.S. government. Telling his wife he's going on a business trip to London, Donovan heads to East Berlin, just as the politically divided city is being physically divided by the construction of the Berlin Wall.With a C.I.A. employee (Scott Shepherd) briefing and supporting him, but needing to otherwise keep his distance, Donovan begins his dangerous mission. Navigating check points and a street gang, he walks alone from West to East Berlin for an appointment inside the Soviet embassy. He meets unofficially with another man to, as Donovan says, "have the conversation that our governments can't". Further complicating an already tenuous negotiation is Donovan's personal decision to insist that the prisoner swap include an innocent American university student recently detained by East German authorities. Clearly, it's going to take every ounce of Donovan's intelligence, skill and nerve to accomplish his objectives, not the least of which is avoiding getting shot or even detained and put on trial himself."Bridge of Spies" is that rare movie that can make history come to life and give it the immediacy of a first-class cinematic drama/thriller. Of course, there are those (as two people behind me in the theater seemed to do) who will walk out of a movie if it isn't very quickly filled with explosions, murders or at least a good chase scene, but short-sighted individuals like that miss an opportunity to enjoy the artistry of well-crafted stories that, sadly, are not as common as they used to be. This entire cast is exceptional, especially Hanks, who is as at the top of his game in full-on thinking man's "boy scout" mode, and Mark Rylance who deserves significant awards season recognition and, of course, the always impressive Ryan.I should mention that the Cold War intrigue highlighted in the film's trailers is all in the second half of the film, but the script, co-written by Matt Charman and none other than Ethan and Joel Coen, is smart and compelling throughout. That story, coupled with Spielberg's expert touch, impressively recalls a time and tone that few Americans still remember, while giving us the twin dramas of a Soviet spy in the U.S. and a downed U.S. pilot in the Soviet Union. These two tales are seamlessly woven together and perfectly edited. The film also reminds us that what makes all of us Americans are not the political or religious beliefs we hold, but the principles we all stand for. "Bridge of Spies" is as American as apple pie and about as rewarding an experience as anyone, regardless of nationality, could hope a film to be. "A"

Once again Spielberg and Hanks hit a home run. Terrific story of little known American Hero. Loved a movie about someone who stood on principle to do the right thing. The period was just as I remembered it to be, even to the tears by the children when they are taught about nuclear war. Highly recommend.
Mark Rylance stole this movie - I hate hokey- that marmalade bit was hokey with a capital H!

It does not surprise me that this film has received very high ratings. It was a good movie. Solid Spielberg and Hanks effort. The problem I had with it was how glaringly "left" the movie was, which again, coming from Spielberg doesn't surprise me. The movie is very sympathetic to a Soviet spy who was in this country stealing classified information for the Soviets. Spielberg wants us to down right like this character. This plays well in today's society but it loses its base on reality when taken out of context which is the time the activities occurred. There was during the Cold War, and still is for me, a line between providing a competent defense under the Constitution for an agent from a nation who's interests were hostile regarding our nation, and befriending the same.

Spielberg and Hanks pretty much represent a sure a "winner" as possible. Like "Saving Private Ryan," "The Terminal," and "Catch Me If You Can," this one scores. Hanks is the "everyman" who is the moral center of this movie,as he is nearly every time. Mark Rylance, as convicted Soviet spy Rudolf Abel, matches Hanks in talent. The story of Francis Gary Powers played out during my lifetime, but I really wasn't following the news at age one.:) The details were mostly new to me. Spielberg does his best to evoke the fear and paranoia of the Cold War era, though my 21 year old couldn't quite "get" it.
Really good movie. Sicaro is next.

Movie lived up to the hype! High entertainment value. Time flies by and you don't want it to end. If you want to see the art side of negotiation, this movie has it. I look forward now to learning what is historic truth and what is the liberty and license we give to the art of a fine movie.

It's difficult to make a film about calculation and restraint and still pack an emotional wallop. Only the combination of Spielberg, the Coen Brothers, and Tom Hanks could pull a feat like that effortlessly. With a beautifully nuanced performance by Mark Rylance (hand him the Supporting Oscar now) and reliably solid filmmaking, Bridge of Spies is one of the year's best films, hands down.

What I got to say about "Bridge of Spies" is a true story that is so riveting movie. The performances by the whole cast is good. "Tom Hanks is at his very best." As per usual, this Spielberg film is well crafted, with great cinematography, engrossing acting performances, and completely convincing atmosphere. The only thing that could waiver is the level of interest in the material, depending on the viewer.

This flick is to be compared to "Saving Ryan Ryan", which likely will be regarded as the most admired of Spielberg's works. After 36 hours reflection, I liked "Bridge of Spies" as much as I did "Ryan", but for different reasons. There is a moral ambiguity to Bridge that is largely lacking in Ryan. Any character in Ryan could be killed at any moment; in Bridge, the fear is loss of soul. The protagonist, played by Tom Hanks, is a New York insurance lawyer and former Nuremberg prosecutor recommended by the Bar Association to defend a Soviet spy at the beginning of the Kennedy administration. I lived through that period, and think Spielberg is a bit over the top in illustrating the fear of nuclear destruction from the Soviets. Nonetheless the script, apparently by the Coen brothers, brilliantly demonstrates how our lawyer hero manages to save the Soviet spy from capital punishment, and of course becomes reviled by everyone except his immediate family for saving this nasty "Russian". In the end, it is made clear how and why this lawyer, a paragon of American legal virtues, became a much-sought-after negotiator of prisoners, eventually freeing more than 10 thousand.

The first third of this movie was kinda slow, I almost fell asleep and somebody in the cinema did so, snoring and with people trying to hush and wake him up. But the movie does pick up steam once the negotiations for the exchange of prisoners started. I liked the exotic Cold War locales of West and East Berlin, and some of the scenes were just poster-perfect gorgeous. I also liked how Donovan, Tom Hank's character didn't seem extraordinary except when the negotiations reallys started to bog down and you start to see how smart and shrewd he was in manipulating events. It was shocking to see how much bias the Judge and Policemen were able to get away with in 1950s America, something which isn't likely to happen that often anymore nowadays. Overall a pretty good movie, highly recommended despite its slow start.

Twice now in 3 weeks has a director, with a career of great films spanning back to the 1970s, made a great film that I can recommend to everyone who asks! "Bridge of Spies" is the best movie that either Steven Spielberg or Tom Hanks have been a part of since their last collaboration in "Catch Me If You Can" unless the word "Toy" is in the title. In a role that seems like it was written for James Stewart or Gregory Peck, Tom Hanks flourishes as a man of conviction and high integrity who never wavers in these dark times. Spielberg does a fantastic job dropping the viewer into the late 50s in the U.S. and also the early 60s in Berlin, and does a masterful building tension and keeping the audience thoroughly invested in the fate of the main characters. The only film that I can think of that felt similar to this in recent memory is "Argo", but I enjoyed this more! If you only have time to see one movie in the next couple of weeks, better make it this one!

I am a Historian of WWII, The Cold War and the Space Race. I was excited to see this movie was going to be inspired by historical events. Tom Hanks delivers as the man who stands up no matter times they knock him down. Donovan is a man of clear ethics and deep morality and fights for what he believes is justice under out Constitution. He finds opposition at home, at work, on the train ride to work, in the office and in the courts. Abel is a Soviet spy but Donovan was able to defend him and kept him from facing execution. This sets up the B story about the U2 spy plane being run by the CIA and their recruited pilots sheep-dipped from the USAF. Gary Powers is one of the drivers for these reconnaissance missions over Soviet territory. The U2 was not immune at 70,000+ feet as the Soviets had developed SAMs to take the jet down. Being that it was on May 1st (May Day) really infuriated the Kremlin. Donovan is now called in by the CIA to make the trade with the Soviets to get Powers back. Berlin is in chaos as the Wall had just been erected to stop the hemorrhaging of skilled people crossing the border and moving on to West Germany. The film depicts the tension between the Russians in Moscow versus the East German officials who were demanding to be a power player at the big table. They did a good job of portraying Abel as a man who carried out his mission in an honorable fashion. The reaction to Donovan defending Abel showed how passions aroused by ideology can incite a mob mentality and violence. In the end this film showed how the security state has a different view of how rules and ethics apply to them and their work. This still goes on today but we have replaced the evil Communists with the evil Islamic extremists as our current boogeyman that allows us to violate the values we claim we are defending as Americans. Excellent slice of the tense Cold War world of paranoia, mistrust and intense dislike of the other.

In classic, old-style Steven Spielberg fashion, Bridge of Spies is an excellent piece of film that tells an intense story at a casual pace, and finds both Spielberg and Tom Hanks in their elements. A great film.

Long-time director Master Steven Spielberg, once again proves why he is one of the best in the business. It has a committed performance by Tom Hanks, a good supporting role in Mark Rylance, really great film and sound editing, and it has one of the best cinematographies of all-time by Janusz Kaminski. For me, Thomas Newman felt like a replacement of John Williams instead of doing music that didn't feel like John Williams, but if that is what Spielberg wanted, well, he was a fine replacement. The writing by Oscar Winners Joel and Ethan Coen had enough humor to keep you invested, and they really did a good job of telling the story the way they envisioned , Overall, Bridge of Spies is another masterful film made by legendary Steven Spielberg. It is thrilling, entertaining, provocative, and enduring.

Found it overrated. It's still good because the story can still get you interested. Though like a normal recent Spielberg production; he pounds you over the head with lengthy dialogue. He does sustain that present human nature element in the movie. Though the commercials are deceiving. This isn't some epic battle between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. It's backward dealings with a bunch of talking. It's kind of interesting but I fell asleep watching it. I can't say it's back because yet again Tom Hanks knocks it out of the park. It seems though that they were trying to make a movie for the Oscars. Hilariously know as "Oscar Bait". This is really what it is. It's good but I'm just jumping up and down to go see it again. 7/10
